38715876.review:
this game is so frickin cool. you cant imagine.

you play randomly generated liberators who have to complete different missions. your main task is to complete your personal story mission and liberate areas to unlock new cool gadgets and stuff so you can retire. 

in short:
hijacking ships, explosions, timeslowing ninja assassin style with longblade and silencer pistol, dual wielding grenade launcher, one sticky remote, one impact detonation, accidents, accidents, accidents, people getting sucked out of the ship into space, catching them with your remote pod, hacking turrets and doors, timeshifting while disarming shields and turrets, finding a breach grenade in a chest to kill a shielded target in a cool way while blowing up the whole room because you ran out of ammo.

you can combine so much stuff and kill or disarm people in a clever way while pausing and planning every step, its incredible! and so much fun!! looking for certain items to attempt a mission is very motivating. unique weapons do exist too!! about a 100 (?) special missions. bored of missions? raid random ships and find rare loot.
sometimes you are forced to do the craziest sh*t and you wonder how the hell did you manage within 3 seconds to smack a guard out of the ship, teleporting to another one, slowing the time while disarming his shield with a cash trap, exectue him with a silencer armor piercing pistol, just to reach the pilot of the ship 10 rooms away to slice his throat just in time so you wont be captured.

it has a medium learning curve but once you know how things work you can confidently attempt hard missions with standard gear. verrry rewarding! just go crazy and try new stuff.
danger!!: expect some tragedy. accidents can happen in the last second of your last mission and one manly tear will be shed.

super cool feature:

if you have some friends who play this game too, it is possible find your friend's equipment which they pass into a pool as you retire. you can even rescue captured liberators which your friends have lost.

Mechanics are awesome and controls are as always on point. This developer should get universal praise. Together with many new systems and upgrades, basically infinite replayability and making you feel awesome in every fight. 38635451.review:
A surprisingly fun, randomly generated rogue-lite with a gorgeous aesthetic. Tom Francis's magnum opus presents us with endless hours of wacky fun and space banter. Take the role of multiple different bounty hunters/freedom fighters/fun-seekers and set off on a variety of missions to inflitrate spaceships. With a large variety of mission types, and an insane amount of tools at your disposal (not to mention frequent updates), the fun literally never ends. 

Enough with the endless praise, time to answer a few questions which might be making you doubt this potential purchase:

"But won't it get repetitive, especially since it's a rogue-lite and death is just one bad bullet away?". 

To that i say "...Maybe". Heat Signature is a rogue-lite because there is a progression system, and its in the form of unlocks. Enemy space stations can be taken over and new gear (plus optional missions) can be unlocked. This gear is permanently now put into your item pool and can randomly appear at any of your friendly stations for purchase, so even if your character does end up dying prematurely (and trust me, he/she will), you'll still make some progress towards the end goal. The repetitive nature is also...not really present, since there'll always be a selection of missions of varying difficulty for you to choose from and if you do feel the game is repetitive, take something above your paygrade (suffer a bit) and you'll be back to having fun in no time.  

"Hows the price to game length ratio looking?"

Trust me you're good in that department, this game will entertain you for a countless amount of hours, i can already tell. 

"Any game breaking bugs? How's the games upkeep looking?"

The developers are wonderful people, frequent updates and bugfixes, no problems there. 

All in all, the game is a pretty solid purchase, i'd highly recommend it.

This game is Hotline Miami in space but with an added layer of badassery and bravado i've never seen anywhere else. If that's not enough, let me tell you a story

I was not sold on this game until i attempted an extraction on a huge ship, horribly under geared for the mission. But there was a time limit on it, and i knew i'd never get another chance at it. Finding specific moments to use my teleporter gadget, and waiting for the opportune time to use one of my 3 grenades was exhilirating in it of itself, but i had rescued my target. The whole ship was on alert and multiple guards were chasing me. I was completely out of supplies, and only had ineffectual handguns in my inventory. There were far too many guards and not enough hiding spots between me and my escape pod, so i contemplated for a solid 20 minutes when i realized i could shoot out the glass on the ship. i equipped my handgun and shot the glass, hurling both me and my target into space. I remote controlled my escape pod and collected both of us, narrowly avoiding a passing space station in the midst of collecting the target. That mission alone left me more white knuckled and gratified than i have been at any video game in the past decade.

38573914.review:
Одна из тех игр, которые "ещё один ход и спать" - а потом четыре часа ночи. 
Мы в глубоком космосе, на границе облачности из экономически привлекательной кислоты. Берём на себя роль маленького человека, которого одна из местных группировок чем-то толкнула на вендетту. Загнали в долги, забрали в рабство или убили кого-то из родни: дикий фронтир, не до защиты прав человека.
Чтобы отомстить, нам нужна информация. Информация стоит денег. Мы зарабатыаем деньги, выполняя задания других людей. Задания понятны нашему мстительному сознанию: украсть, захватить, спасти, убить, угнать. 
Купив информацию о нашей личной цели, выходим на задание категорической сложности. Успех - и можно выйти на покой. 
И тогда уже другой человек вступает в личную вендетту под нашим управлением. Недостатка ультранасилия на берегу кислотного облака не наблюдается.
Иногда мы не справляемся. И тогда человек становится безжизненным космическим мусором, а на его место приходит другой, со своими проблемами.

По геймплею это хотлайн маями в процедурно-генерируемых модульных кораблях, с телепортерами, энергетическими щитами и всякими туррелями. Почти любой корабль можно зачистить имея в руках только разводной ключ, но это тот ещё челленж. Прогрессия идёт через инвентарь: нашёл хороший девайс - жить стало легче. Новые персонажи начинают со случайным малополезным барахлом. Уходя на пенсию, персонаж может оставить одну вещь, чтобы она стала случайным лутом в ящиках. Напрямую ничего не передать. Так что разводной ключ - лучший друг мстителей даже через десять часов игры. :)

Крайне рекомендую, даже за полную цену.

38431812.review:
What if you had FTL's space thematic and pause mechanic, but with topdown combat with lots of weapons and gadgets. That's basically Heat Signature.

Thanks to all the mechanics (weapons, teleporters, enemies, other gadgets and so on) this game is really skillful. I'm still figuring out more and more interactions and clever uses of already known mechanics and it's really satisfying. There's different weapons, teleporters and various gadgets all with their advantages and drawbacks. All of that going into different ship layouts, enemies and mission types. An argument I've seen from other reviewers is how the game is repetitive, but the core loop is good and there's enough of variety that I didn't find that as a problem.

As far as difficulty goes, game is quite easy. Progression keeps going forward no matter what. Character dies? Pick another. At worst you fail every mission and stagnate, in which case, the game happily throws an overpowered character at you so you can hopefully progress. The game is easy in other ways as well: guards are predictable and slow at reacting to you, loot is plentiful and powerful and some missions are just straight up easy (liberations especially). I mentioned previously how skillful the game is, that's still true, but you can definitely progress and beat the game either way. It feels like the game is trying to appease players of any skill level.

This brings me to my last point: speedrunning. This is one of the few games that got me interested into speedrunning it. Suddenly, being skillfull matters a lot more. Although it might also involve abusing certain items (looking at you, stealth shield), it's still really fun and I'm having fun attempting a record. Do join in! Leaderboard are not exactly populated as of this review.

In conclusion: I recommend the game, althought I warn that if you're looking for something especially difficult, this isn't it. If you're into speedrunning, that's a plus.

38431783.review: This game is something great. I bought it on a whim during the recent sales and it blew me away. It scratched that Hotline Miami itch with its top-down, fast-paced action but the variety of weapons, tools, and mission conditions adds a deeper layer of strategy. Finding a creative way to accomplish your mission objective is rewarding and fun. I'd definitely recommend this game.

38421782.review: Heat Signature is a fun game about sneaking onto a spaceship with a tiny pod, going to steal something/kill/rescue/capture someone, and then either ultimately leaving a massive trail of corpses or unconcious people or something went wrong. Or you have a key card cloner and a stealth shield and you never made contact with the guards. Over all, it is a very fun game that ultimately has a few shortcomings; mainly in difficulty and variety, but it will pull you in nonetheless. Once you hit a certain level of progression and/or skill, death becomes a fantasy. Oh no! 5 guards with guns have noticed you! Sidewinder, no longer in lign of sight. Stealth shield, no longer in line of sight. Slipstream, easily incapacitate all guards. Swapper, make the guards shoot them self. Double wrench, knock into one guard, throw the wrench you just used at another, knock into another guard, throw that wrench, pick up the first wrench you threw, and throw it at the final guard. The difficulty largely is based on shields and/or armor, which is merely beaten by having the right items to deal with, or more guards. The game, however, is still engaging. You rush through liberations, taking bigger and bigger missions until you can get a new liberation in 2 missions, and then do the admittedly extremely fun defector missions, if ultimately useless. You gain all the good items until almost nothing can beat you, or if it can, offworld angel angels you from death,  and then you retire, selling all your hard earned crap to try to get a self-charging item to retire with, letting one of your later characters obtain the admittedly OP self-charging items. And then you build your characters up again. And again. And again. And again.

38421421.review:

38393904.review:
I can't possibly put it any better than the trailer: "A game where you go inside a spaceship, make terrible mistakes, and think of clever ways to get yourself out of them." This game is so much fun! The utterly ridiculous situations you find yourself in will never cease to amaze you, and there are no limits to the number of ways you can come up with you get yourself out of them. Whether you're failing epicly (or perhaps not-so-epicly) or pulling off the heist of the century against impossible odds, this game always manages to be fun. It's been a long time since I've seen a game that delivered so thoroughly on the promises made by its developers. Let me be clear: I am not a twitch gamer. I'm about as far as you can from a twitch gamer. This game makes me feel like an amazing ninja anyway.

Whether you're the slow and methodical gamer who takes his time with everything, or the gamer who rushes in and makes things happen at the speed of light, I promise you'll enjoy Heat Signature. If the premise sounds even remotely similar, buy it! You won't regret it.

38260105.review:
Sus gráficos, historia o personajes no calaran en ti, pero su jugabilidad seguro te divertida por unas cuantas horas. 
Tu misión es dominar todas las estaciones espaciales de una galaxia, y para ellos te valdrás de unos cuantos piratas espaciales a los que controlaras. Tu solo controlaras a uno, pero el juego es un Roguelite, lo que implica que la muerte de tu personaje sera permanente, y aun que no afecte al progreso global de tu campaña de dominio, si que implicara empezar de cero con otro personaje. 

El juego se basa enteramente en abordar naves enemigas repletas de enemigos, y esto puedes hacerlo de dos formas, tratando de ser sigiloso, evitando que te vean, escuchen o den la alarma.... o desatando un infierno de disparos, explosiones y acción desenfrenada que deberás controlar con una precisión milimétrica para evitar morir o que te capturen.

Aun que la mayoría de misiones puedes elegir como hacerlos y probablemente acabes combinando ambas, hay algunas misiones que te forzaran a utilizar el sigilo o la acción mas directa. 
Cuantas mas naves asaltes, mas enemigos derrotaras y mas cargamentos robaras, lo que te dará acceso a un arsenal de armas y gadgets para ir mejorando a tu personaje. 

La jugabilidad es muy simple, pero el amplio repertorio de gadgets al que tienes acceso lo hace suficientemente profundo para poder suponer un buen reto. 
Cuantas mas estaciones domines, mas objetos se añadiran a la pool de objetos aleatorios que puedes conseguir. 

El juego se basa en hacer lo mismo una y otra vez, pero es tan divertido, que no te importara hacerlo durante horas,
¿Podría ser mas profundo? Sí. 
¿Podría ser mas variado? Sí.
pero
¿merece la pena? Sí. 

Como he leído en un análisis de otro usuario: "Es como jugar al Hotline miami mientras la IA juega al faster than light"

Nota: 8/10

38089151.review:
I think the trailer does a perfect job of explaining what this game's about.All of the things you see in the trailer just become a part of regular play. And even still, the first scenario shown in the trailer isn't as badass as it gets. 5 guys standing right in the entrance of the ship? No problem. Go inside, cope with the fact that everyone in that room has spotted you and wants you dead, bash the first guy you see with the wrench in your right hand, bash the second guy with your left-hand wrench, throw a wrench at the third guy, throw your other wrench at the fourth guy, pick up one of their guns, and use it to shoot the fifth guy. Did someone just waltz to the same room in the time it took that to transpire? No problem, if your gun's still reloading, you can throw that at him to knock him unconscious, too.

If I had to describe the two "focus points" of the game, it's about feeling (and looking) like a badass, and finding solutions to tricky problems.

Does the guy you want dead have a shield that prevents you from shooting him? You know that Subverter thing from the trailer, that lets you hack enemy turrets to shoot the ship's crew instead of you? It works on shields, too. Invert it so that instead of letting bullets out but not in, it lets bullets in but not out. And before you know it, the guy's bullet just bounced off his own shield, and killed him for you.

Did EVERYONE on the 50-something crew ship just hear you? Well... Figure it out on your own, you're gonna have to make the best of what you've got to get out of that one. That's actually happened, though. I had to knock 50 people out, and the mission required me to leave no witnesses, so I gathered all of their bodies in one of the engine rooms, shot the fuel tank, and sent all of them into space. That was fun.

As you play more, liberating stations and breaking into harder ships, you unlock new toys to solve new kinds of problems. Like armored enemies. So... You're saying it's like a shotgun, but instead of bullets, it fires acid, which dissolves the enemy's armor, followed by their flesh, followed by their skeletons and vital organs? Sign me up!

This game really is a sandbox where you can feel badass any time you want. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone and everyone. If the trailer interests you, of course.

38002554.review:
Having previously greatly enjoyed Gunpoint from the same developer, it's not really a surprise that I enjoy Heat Signature, but the extent to which it delights me caught me by surprise.

It plays like something somewhere between the original top-down GTA and Hotline Miami, with only small character-specific storylines (in the form of a one-per-character "personal mission" that motivates them) and the threat of permadeath ever-present. Normally that combination puts me off, because of what feels to me like a high risk of losing a character (and the time spent honing their skills and/or equipment)  for little specific benefit to the game overall. But Heat Signature balances it nicely, partly because the wider setting of the game is effectively an insurrection movement across a whole system of space stations, and partly because it has core mechanics which make it a joy to dip into for five minutes if you don't want to get stuck into tackling full-on missions.

Like the original GTA, this is a game where, if you don't want to tackle any specific missions, you can just pop out in your pod and either jaunt around space listening to the lovely soundtrack or randomly board passing vessels to see what things you can steal. Or hijack the ship and go around senselessly firing on other vessels just for the hell of it.

This is also a game where, as soon as you grasp the tools available, you're encouraged to think of different ways to use them and different approaches to given tasks. I hesitate to list too many examples here, because it's so much fun to discover them - but I would say that looking through the available achievements should provide some examples.

If I absolutely had to find fault with it, I'd say that the lack of a docking-helper function when flying your pod can occasionally be irritating - I've had a few cases where I needed to board a ship that was flying in a circular holding pattern, which is a pain since your pod flight tools are of the straight-line "fire thrusters, go thataway" type.

37973594.review:
Let me preface this review by saing that although I think the game is fine, I cannot really recommend it. I finished the game and had good fun the first 4-5 hours playing this and I'm perfectly ok with that. However, this brings me to my first problem with the game:

The difficulty curve. At the start of the game, there's a lot going on and you're trying to make sense of the different weapons and gadgets as well as the flow of the game. This is fun. However, once you get 4-5 hours in, you have gotten the flow of the game down and realize that you actually only need a couple of gadgets to defeat a mission of any difficulty. Coupled with the fact that you get better and better starting equipment the longer you progress in the game, this makes the game too easy at this point. So, the latter half of the game is pretty much an excercise in grinding liberations as quick as possible in order to get to the stronghold missions.

Which is my second gripe. The stronghold missions are also way too easy. Clone keys, slow down time, run to captain, done. Or approach it however you want. As long as you have some key items, you'll have no problems with them. This brings me to my third point:

The incoporation of randomness in the ships layout is not a good choice for a game of this type. The ships play out too similarly, which adds to the repetitive feeling during the latter half of the game. I feel that you need level design in order to make it interesting during the whole game. A good example here would be Hotline Miami, which makes better use of ramping difficulty because of level design.

As far as positive notes go, I did enjoy the flow of the game and the chaining of orders overall. It's very fun to execute orders and watch your character dismember the opposition with swords. I also really appreciated the way the game generate stories for you to elaborate. For example, the time I got sucked out a window with my captured person and managed to pick up both of us with a second to spare. I found that pretty cool, and there's a lot of that stuff happening.

All in all, it's an ok game, but I didn't find it that enjoyable all together. If you're interested in this game I would recommend Hotline Miami, Invisible Inc., or FTL instead. All of which have some of the same mechanics as Heat Signature, but in my opinion, better executed.

La guardia non ti ha visto? Chiave inglese in testa.
La guardia ti ha visto e sta per chiamare l'allarme? Chiave inglese in testa.
Le guardie sono tre e stanno per farti ripensare alle tue scelte di vita? Questo è il motivo per cui ti porti dietro tre chiavi inglesi.

Per capirci, questo gioco è Hotline Miami nello spazio e il suono della chiave inglese in testa è ESTREMAMENTE soddisfacente.

Ci sono molte altre situazioni che (ahimè) non possono essere risolte con una chiave inglese in testa (come nella vita reale, purtroppo), ma Heat Signature propone fortunatamente un arsenale di soluzioni. Teletrasporti temporanei, distorsori temporali, granate concussive, spade, fucili, trappole, raggi che disattivano i dispositivi elettronici... c'è da divertirsi.

Mi piace la libertà d'azione, e mi piace che gli errori sono puniti ma quasi mai in maniera definitiva (come in molti altri roguelike). Ci sono sempre uno o più modi per riparare alle cazzate fatte, anche quando ci sono solo 15 secondi per ripercorrere di corsa tutta la nave per andare a prendere a chiavi inglesi in testa il pilota, in modo da evitare la cattura (e relativo fallimento della missione).

Intorno alla struttura principale delle missioni a bordo di navi nemiche, c'è una mappa galattica da liberare una base alla volta, vari personaggi generati casualmente (ognuno con la sua storia e la sua missione personale) e un sistema di "eredità" che permette ai personaggi di andare in pensione e lasciare dietro di sè un oggetto in eredità, che può essere trovato da altri amici su Steam o da altri personaggi dello stesso giocatore.

Ottimo da giocare anche in sessioni da 5-10 minuti, con la possibilità di scegliere svariati livelli di difficoltà e tipi di missioni.

Assolutamente consigliato a chiunque.

Three hours in and I have to say, I like this a lot!

For the uninitiated I could say this feels a lot like Hotline Miami in space.
  
   Heat Signature has the same frantic feel, but this game is more merciful in that it lets you pause the action at any time.
While paused you can pan around, plan ahead and even change weapons and equipment. That means you can execute very elaborate combos and when you add teleporters, swappers, traps and more to the mix, things can and will get kinda crazy. In a good way!
   
   Missions are generated procedurally (like everything these days) and the harder ones include restrictions (not mandatory, but they pay better if you follow them). The game can feel like a puzzle game at times, but things heat up when the unexpected happens (and it will!) ie. the ship you are on gets attacked mid mission and half of it explodes resulting in you and your mission objective being sucked into space.

If you like roguelikes/-lites with a dash more action and tactics on the side, this just might be the game for you.

37891979.review:
Heat Signature, pretty much "Choose how you want to play it"
It's a game that gets both easier and harder as you progress with your [strike]Nebula[/strike] Galaxy. Easier because you unlock new gear to buy at store, when you liberate outposts. Harder because with outposts liberated to get new contracts, that add up requirements and deadlier additions. You can ignore that part of the game by doing easy missions, but you will progress slower towards your next outpost. You have wide variety of gadgets to choose from. 
Guns - there's pistols, rifles and shotguns. 
Melee - wrench, long- and shortblades. More rare concussion hammer that will send your victim flying across the room. 
Throwables. - usual grenades, hack grenades, breaching nades - as in make a hole in ship. Grenade launchers come too.
Traps that will hack guard's equipment, let him come into trap range, melt his armor off, or teleport him elsewhere on, or outside the ship. 
Personal-use gadgets - teleporters there too. Stealth gear, hack gear, energy shields. 
Hell, you even get to control the time. Game literally screams it at you - Stop time to do cool.
But who needs all that when you can just pickpocket a guard for key, and get to your objective that way then throw yourself to space through the window, then catch yourself with pod and fly to the station.

I've played each of the Dishonored games, the mainline Metal Gears, and a bunch of other immersive sim / stealth games that attempt this similar "Mess up and find a clever way out" gameplay, but Heat Signature is the only one that I was so well incentivised to get creative with, and enjoy the immense pleasure of actually coming up with something amazing. Not just once either, as the 10 hours I've spent with Heat Signature so far has been chock-full of discovery and delight. This is without a doubt my favorite stealth game of all time.

Suggestions:
1 - Liberators that appear at your bar after the latest update are really powerful, and sort of ruined the progression for me due to their self-charging items. Maybe you should only be able to use them for their liberator mission, or maybe they shouldn't have self-charging items, only rechargeable? Maybe I should've just steered clear of using them entirely, but you know the old adage that if players see an optimal path they'll take it even if it's less fun.
2 - It would be amazing if there was a Super Meatboy / Super Hot playback function where at the end of a mission you're given the option to watch it without any pauses / slow-mo. I understand that this would probably be a ton of work to implement, but I think it would be a perfect inclusion.

The main reason you play Heat Signature isn't for the fast-paced playstyle with a pause feature for planning maneuvers. You don't play it for the infinite replayability caused by randomized missions, spaceships, characters, and even entire galaxies. You don't play it for the insane gadgets, teleporters, and weapons allowing for complex strategies.
All of these things help, but the main reason you play Heat Signature is when you combine all of them together to face a difficult challenge that you overcome with the stupidest plan you could possibly conceive. However simple the game may be, if you look at all the creative ways to hijack an enemy ship, you'll see that the simplicity of the game is actually a facade. 37832236.review:
Stealth fans and roguelite fans rejoice: Heat Signature is one of the best games I've played in either category. The developer(s) made many smart design decisions and created a game with fun core gameplay and a very satisfying gameplay loop. The pausing mechanic might seem cheap at first but the game makes up for it by being truly difficult at times. It's always fun to be spotted unexpectedly and pausing the action to take a moment and figure out how you're going to get yourself out of the situation. Your failures are always your own fault, too; there's no death-by-RNG here. Only poor planning or execution on the player's part.

Good variety in the missions, with modifiers like "no alerts" or "no kills" to keep things from getting stale (there's like six or eight modifiers total). It's got that classic roguelite progression grind of unlocking better gear for use in your next mission, and permadeath that honestly isn't too punishing (you lose your character--which is really just their equipment--but you don't lose your overall progress in the game).

Highly recommended.

37827807.review:
Heat Signature is a game of systems, a sandbox for tactics and murder... or not. Setting out on missions is an exercise in planning and flawed execution, as things will probably go wrong, but still mostly okay, some times. The approach to missions and the playstyle to employ are entirely up to the player; the punishment of defeat is only as great as the goals one sets out to achieve. Mastering the game or failing completely go hand-in-hand and both are essential in truly appreciating what is on offer here.

I've found myself beating everything the game has to offer in 20 hours at most, and yet I keep coming back, setting limits and rules for myself, testing the limits of what the weapons and gadgets can do and discovering combinations that eluded me during my first playthrough. Some might see this as a game lacking in content; I found it liberating and engaging.

A couple of hours later and I'm running around with multiple grenade launchers, finding amusing ways to capture targets (non-lethal weapons are required according to the tool tip) by blowing up the room, venting them into space and grabbing them with the pod.

It can get a little repetitive in some ways but it would well worth dipping into again in the future

37815256.review:
There's no explicit storyline, only individual characters and their personal missions, vendettas and hopes.

I got attached to the first character I played. He was awesome. He had awesome kit. But then he messed up, well, I did. And he ended up captive aboard some Sovereign ship.

Fortunately, his mate turned up, and I could try and rescue him. So I worked my new character, got some kit together, and launched an audacious mission to rescue his mate (my first character). All was going well, until I misused a teleporter and got pinned in a deadly firefight with some armoured units. There was only one thing to it: I blasted us all into space... forgetting that I had under 10 seconds of oxygen to get picked up.

My flying wasn't good enough. It was all very tragic.

That was my first hour of Heat Signature.

In the following hours, I've since refined the delicate art of invading ships at warp speed, juggling items and guns to wreak mayhem as efficiently as possible.

It's a top-down shooter/puzzler that lets you figure out your own solutions in as much time as you need whilst still moving at a pace that leaves you breathless. It's visually pleasing, comic-book like, and plays fast enough to let you squeeze a mission in any ten-minute slot you've got.

I can't recommend it enough.

37802302.review:
Heat Signature is a pretty fun game, what I really like is
+ good game for short sessions as it doesn't have long loading times and one missions takes about 5 min
+ different playstyles
-> defector missions are really good, because you have little, but good equipment and don't have to navigate your pod
-> also the different clauses require different ways of playing.
+ possibility of upgrading your character step by step.

but there are some flaws, like
- the story-missions feel totally like the other missions, exept that you have to pay for it. It would have been way better, if they had kind of an climax leading towards them, and not just pay 200 Credits and probably need an armour-piercieng weapon. I think especially with the station-liberating missions, there are some great opportunities wasted, you just have to capture a siege ship and ram the station??? so you destroy the station, then they like you, then you get the station??? why not sneak onto a transport ship which is navigating to the station and then have several levels/areas there, were you are killed, when you fail? The way it is, it feels kind of unsatisfying
-(minor spoiler!!!) I think, when you are captured and rescue your character, the rescued person should lose all his equipment not stashed, sure, it's nice, not to lose your good stuff, but it's really illogical to simply keep it.
- no coop-mode, which would be really nice
- after some time it becomes kind of easy, also because most of the time, you have to fear no consequences, just catch yourself with your pod, redock, maybe hurry up and kill the captain, and you're fine. It would be great, if another crew member started flying the ship, after they saw that the captain is uncapable of doing so.

Even though some things about this game bother me, it's still really fun to play, but more as a game in between. If you liked gunpoint, you probably could check it out.

37771456.review:
This game feels like Hotline Miami, except it's easier to avoid death. It's still pretty easy to die, but you can pause your game and plan out how you want to tackle whatever challenge you're up against. There's something so very satisfying about jumping into a room with a sword to kill one dude, shoot another guy, throw a knife at another guard, and use teleportation to make a guy kill himself with his own bullet.

But when your character dies, they die. It's kind of like Rogue Legacy where you play as a whole new character after the previous one died. But if you don't want your character to die because you want a happy ending to their story, you can just have them retire, You won't be able to play as a retired character, but you can pick an item of theirs to put into the item pool so future characters can discover.

And the freedom you have when doing a mission is great. You just need to have the right supplies. You can sneak in and out without being seen with the teleporters and stealth shield, or you could just charge in guns blazing, and escape the ship by blowing up some fuel storage and blasting your way out into space where your little escape pod can catch you.

I've waited 3 years for this, and I must say, it was well worth the wait. There's always a new way to complete a mission that you haven't tried yet.

37748817.review:
At the moment, very easy. Whether it's due to the Fair Points update or not, you can essentially make a character that can ghost 9/10 of the hardest missions you see. While it makes it fun to speedrun, it's quite easy to do succeed at almost anything if you're even a little bit cautious. Slipstream, stealth field, and most particularly, key cloner helps in that regard. It also seems that it's the equipment that make the player, and nothing else. You're only distinct visually otherwise.

My suggestions: 

Jammers, can't use equipment such as key cloners/teleporters etc. in radius/on ship. Perhaps also prevent self-charging. This would be good for difficulty.

Competent Enemies: Shout intruder if they see a glimpse of you when you're literally right beside them (so to avoid just using stealth field all the time, going right past them.) Shouts intruder if you swap with them. If you peek around the corner, they'll go in a group, not by themselves, to investigate. They're able to switch weapons like you, and use grenades effectively around corners, shouting as to prevent friendly fire. Being able to lunge against the player with appropiate melee weapons would be also cool, giving priority to who wins by who lunges first.

Grapple Hooks: Chain an enemy temporarily to a location, also making them aggressive, but unable to chase. Targetting yourself prevents you from being shot out into space.

No rechargable 5/5 stealth fields or 5/5 key cloners. Those things should be unique, not on sale for 20 at the store.

Slipstream should make you 1.5x faster while slowing down time 2x. At 5x speed, you go so fast that enemies can't react to anything you do, whether rushing it, grabbing the key, and getting out, or simply using it as improv stealth field. It's a freebie. If you get the 5/5 slipstream, it's 5 freebies.

Unlimited item teleporting once the ship is secure, no cooldown.

Make it so that the option to grab the body of the pilot vs. getting into the pilot's seat is distinct. They seem to overlap too much in the same space to select on or the other.

Unique missions: Mistake missions in which the objective is stealing a unique item for yourself. No money reward, just unique and some liberty.

37743195.review:
Not often do I see a game that lets me do almost whatever I want to complete an objective, whether it be by completely obliterating a ship my assasination target is on (At the lost of any loot on the ship), or meticulously sneaking past guards and skillfully using key-cloners to be able to easily avoid any conflict as I approach my rescue target, or going in guns-blazing, taking out every guard I see in a mad dash towards the engines of the ship to disable it before continuing on to grab the secret project located on the other side of the ship.

    This is a game with almost limitless possiblities for approaching any objective. There is always a set way you can take on an objective, usually just taking out anyone in your path and performing the goal of the mission, but that's not what makes this game fun. You can play a character however you wish, with 4 playable characters at any given time. As the player, you are capable of choosing what to do with a character, whether it's one who doesn't believe in killing, using only concussive guns (Which, surprisingly does not mean you don't have to take assasination missions, you can deliver a target much like a rescue mission target, and it even nets an achievement) or one that is the exact opposite, going in with two shotguns and clearing rooms like there is no tomorrow, and anything in-between.

    The game has one singular goal, and that is to essentially eliminate all the other factions by liberating all faction strongholds (There are 4 factions, one which uses "non-lethal" weapons against you, one which I think relates to teleporters, one which uses ballistic weapons, and one which uses swords.) and then the game essentially "ends." but much like the missions the game has, the way to achieve this is very open-ended. You can either go straight to eliminating each faction, and finish it in the quickest way allowed, or go and liberate every single space-station (For that sweet-sweet achievement) before liberating the last strongholds. Otherwise the other objective is to retire your characters. Each character has a "Personal Mission" to perform before they are retired, it costs quite a bit to unlock the mission, and it is quite difficult to perform, often requiring cheesing the system or pure luck/skill, but when you do you get the option to retire the character and pass on one of their items to be able to be used by another character, provided you find it in a loot box. This can be done with every character you play as and is quite helpful, especially if you can find multiple of these items as a later character.

    Among the other features, this game allows the player character to do plenty of amazing feats with it's pause feature, allowing you to pause the action, take a look at your options, and decide how you'll be playing the next few moments out in order to avoid being injured. Pausing is available at any time during gameplay, so as long as you don't forget it exists you can pull off pretty much any feat to eliminate as many enemies as possible and possibly survive.

    Other notable things about this game include a really nice soundtrack, I enjoy listening to it while I play the game, as well as an interesting lore and different features for each mission you perform, enemies will constantly be changing kit based on which faction's ship you'll be boarding and the difficulty of the level. The lore exists through ex-members of each faction, located in space-stations liberated from those factions. The game is also frequently updated, which does help since bugs get patched incredibly quickly and the developers are constantly looking at issues in the game and balancing them. Also, the game isn't multiplayer, but does have some interaction with steam friends where you can rescue characters a friend might have had captured and be able to use it with all it's equipment or find the item of a steam-friend's retired character.

    I purchased this game at launch, and the only issue I really have with it, and the only reason i'm currently on hiatus with not many hours played on it is that it does get repetitive. I found myself getting bored because the missions have very little variety, indeed there are different missions, but once you've played the same on on the same ship 10 times it does get slightly aggravating, to the point where when steam randomly decided the game wasn't installed and I had to reinstall I just wasn't willing to go through all I went through over again, although that's not to say I won't go back.

    Overall, on my completely subjective and arbitrary rating scale, this game is a solid 8/10 in it's category, and it is one that I would honestly recommend to anyone I know, especially those that like either strategy, or shooters in the vein of Hotline Miami.

Every time I play a few rounds of Heat Signature I find some wacky new way to be a space hijacker. Every time I lament that there aren't dozens of types gadgets to pick up, it's not five minutes later I find a new hilarious combination to use what's available. Every time I look at a mission and think that it's impossible with my current kit, I force myself to take the mission anyway and succeed. 

From tactically stun-hammering people out windows to desperately slow motion sprinting through a dozen guys to steal a single keycard. From using six temporary teleporters in rapid succession to zoom across a ship for a split second to literally cutting a ship in half to make an access point because I jetisoned the other keycard into space by accident. From smashing my delicate space pirate pod into ships to assassinate passengers to pushing an armored, shielded, invulnerable pilot off his helm station so he can't sound alarms and no matter how many times the AI shoots me and tosses me out the airlock I can just rescue myself in a hospital pod and keep coming back.

Gosh dang amazing fun.

37704532.review:
This game is so much fun.  Do yourself a favor and experiment with the different techs, get in over your head, force yourself to fix problems in a way you never would otherwise.

Example: in a mission to hijack a siege ship, all the enemies were permenantly shielded.  I had managed to kill the pilot, but about 15 enemies were in the control room, idling about.  I was out of Subverter and Crash ammunition, had exhausted my Sidewinder teleporter and Stealth Shield, and had only a gun useless against shields and a Slipstream personal accelerator.  I used my Slipstream to sprint past all of the guards, shoot out a nearby window to suck a few of them into space, and hop into the pilot's seat.  Once there, I set a collision course with an enemy station.  Then, the enemies nearby (there were still over 10 in the room while I did this) shot me and threw me out the window I'd shot out earlier.  I remote-piloted my pod to rescue myself, and watched as the siege ship collided with my target station.

It shouldn't have worked.  Given any other choice, I would never have done it.  But in desperation, I said "... Eh, why not?"

13/10 would undermine the Sovereign economy again.

Pros:
- Space Pirate Ninja Gunfighter Magician pausable action
- Varied enemy types and mission objectives
- Fun problem solving gameplay allows many different solutions


Cons(ish):
- It can be a little hard to see keys/guards on some of the ship types.  There is a simple mode that helps with this, though.
- It took some googling to figure out that the little blue and orange cards on my inventory screen, next to my money, were Standard and Armor Piercing ammo counts.

Look, just buy it.  It's so much fun.

37700934.review:
This is a 2D game where you go around space like a space pirate would with crazy gadgets, guns, explosions, even ripping whole bad guy ships in half, all to fuel a revolution against the 4 factions of the game. That's already pretty cool, but the way Heat Signature pulls all those simple ideas into a crazy game is fantastic.

The description on the Steam page here already describes what the game is pretty well, which is a real shocker, but those things in the description make for a cool real time stratgey game (that works because it can be paused at any time-like FTL) with lots of choices to make. Even if one of those choices is to not make a stratgey at all.

I gotta say, what I love most about this game is how easy it is to make those mistakes, how quickly everything in a mission falls apart, how much I am to blame for those mistakes, and how interesting it is to get around those mistakes. Because there are so many strategies, screwing up forces you to try new and unique ways to use all of that cool equipment you gather up. That all works because there is almost always a way to fix any mistakes made. Just don't mess up fixing mistakes, because characters can die, and die for good-taking all the cool gear with them.


The chaos and variety of regular gameplay makes this one cool game. And Tom Francis is cool too. Support this dude if you like the sound of the game!

37689358.review:
On first glance this game looks like a space-themed top-down actioner in the spirit of Hotline Miami and others.

But this glance couldn't be more wrong.

Through the use of a pause mode the game gives way more room to planning and tactical decision making, while (mostly) taking out the need for split-second reflexes. You are always able to try and make the best out of a difficult situation by cleverly and creatively utilizing the various gadgets at your disposal, which leads to a much more cerebral gameplay approach.

The 'roguelite' elements in the game (random but persistant map with permadeath for player characters) help with keeping the action tense but never too frustrating. The game progress through station liberations works kind of like a semi-random technology tree, where you can plan your progress to try and optimize the possible loadout for your current and future characters.

Overall the game is very fun and, through randomisation, offers a very high amount of replay value.

Highly recommended.

37684755.review:
Pros: Stable, Smooth graphics and gameplay, nice effects

Cons: clunky controls (should have options for gamepad), lack of voice acting, lack of direction, top down view is disorienting

Thoughts: 

It's easy to tell a lot of passion and effort was put into this game, it's just not my cup of tea and it definitly has some interface issues. I rarely post reviews but felt this one merited one.

I would like the "pause" menu to be called something else. "pause" kills immersion. Also, instead of pausing in and pausing out, how about an option for "holding" the key (or button/trigger if gamepad can be added) and then let go to get back into the action. There's the additional, disorienting effect of having the pause menu but also having a slowed-down framerate whenever I come freshly out of combat. Maybe this is just me. This was executed beautifully in DOOM with the weapon wheel.


Why are there cooldown timers? Just require a reload key'button from outside the pause menu to remind me that I'm empty. I forget about the cooldown and since they are different for every weapon I stutter over my tactics everytime I change weapons. Why have a primary and a secondary? You can only fire/use one weapon at a time, and you can change to ANY weapon at ANY time from the pause menu. Make weapon selection mouse wheel scroll or pad/bumper selection from the gamepad.

Switching between mouse controls for the pod and WASD for interior shop/station control also clunky and kills immersion. Again, with gamepad it could be done seamlessly between two joysticks so I never have to go from a nice smooth mouse to a Cherry MX mechanical key slap.

I think the reason for this review is that I don't want to write this game off, I think it has a LOT of potential and I'd like to see it progress, but for now I's just too unplayable for me, and I can't recommend it.

[b]This was a critical mistake. Why?[/b]

37576578.review:
[b]Roug Like im Weltraum mit taktischer tiefe.[/b]

[h1]Story[/h1]
Nicht gerade viel. Man übernimmt einen Charakter mit Zufälliger Ausrüstung, der auf einer „persönlichen“ Mission ist (Rette Bruder, Ehemann, töte Mörder des Sohnes...) und muss genügend Geld verdienen um die Infos zu bekommen, diese Mission zu starten.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Auf der Station sucht man sich einen Zufälligen Auftrag aus, wobei man den Schwierigkeitsgrad und die vorhanden Bedrohung angezeigt bekommt. Danach schwingt man sich in seinen kleinen Pot und düst zu dem markierten Schiff. Hier geht das eigentliche Gameplay erst richtig los. Den man muss taktisch mit seiner Ausrüstung (von der es viele verschiedene gibt) einen taktischen Weg finden um gegen die in Überzahl anwesenden Gegner zu gewinnen.

[h1]Fazit[/h1]
Wer hier ein „[i]Hotline Miami[/i]“ erwartet wird enttäuscht, da es hier mehr um das einsetzten der richtigen Ausrüstung ankommt als auf schnelle Reaktionen (das Spiel muss oft pausiert werden um zu gewinnen). Für zwischendurch eine Runde zum spielen ist es aber sehr zu empfehlen.

37565869.review: Great rogue-lite game with top-down twin-stick style gameplay (of course you use mouse and keyboard rather than sticks, but you get the idea). A lot of people have likened the core gameplay to Hotline Miami, but the range and nature of the weapons and gadgets, combined with the fact that they can be activated from the pause screen, gives it a completely different feel. Instead of training twitch reactions, attempting the same part of a level over and over in Hotline Miani, you are given one shot at a particular mission, but almost infinite time to think about exactly what you want to do. The latest update has also made a lot of improvements to the game to speed up progression and eliminate risk of a character dying (if that's a problem for you).

37547043.review:
Heat Signature combines puzzling, sci-fi, and badassery in a tight, replayable package. The regular missions provide excellent variety, real danger, and great sense of accomplishment. The 'Liberator' missions stand out, as they are so tough that they make me fully explore each and every mechanic in the game, however you can replay them endlessly until you get it right. Can you knock out a room with 4 guards in before they sound the alarm, with just a blade and a short range teleporter? You will find out how, and once you've learned, you take those skills into the real world missions. Rarely have I played a game that teaches it's core mechanics in such an ingenius way. 10/10. 
See story-time below.

I choose to accept a rescue mission. The mission is labeled a 'Mistake' and has the 'Ghost' clause: No deaths, no incapacitations, don't be seen. Just snag a guy and ghost the place. I pick my loadout, optimize it for stealth and throw in a few key cloners, as well as my trusty self-charging EMP gun, to deactivate any electronics that could detect me. I hop into my pod, and zip off in pursuit of my target. It's a ship belonging to the Offworld Security faction, so it's going to be close quarters. 
I dock my pod with their airlock. They don't know I'm here. I sneak my way into a hallway. Ahead is corrdidor with 5 guards, one of them carrying a key. First I deactivate their shields and infrared detector fields. Then I use the key cloner to snag the key. That was the easy part, now it's time to get up close and personal. My stealth shield only has a 5 second charge, only works across 180 degree angle, and the approaching hallway is long. I don't know if this will work. It's go time: I activate my shield, and immediately start to move. I enter the corridor with 3 seconds to spare. Sneaking past two guards no problem. The  guard blocking the other entrance of the corridor is closer to the wall than I would like. I hold my breath as I squeeze past. He doesn't notice. 
I use the stealth shield once more to sneak past an easier group of guards, and make it to the prisoner. Shit, I can't carry the prisoner and use the stealth shield at the same time. I physically throw the stealth field generator down a hallway, the noise catches the attention of the group of guards. There's my chance: I pick up the prisoner, and dash past them. I run to a control room with viewing deck, which I passed earlier. There's no time for finesse, the guards are on their way back. I pull out my silenced shotgun and blast the plasteel glass window. It explodes outward, in a shower of glass and air escaping into space: We're out of here. I feel like a badass. Even as the vacuum pulls us through this newly created door, I start remote controlling my pod. First it picks up the prisoner, then myself. The package is secure, and I'm on my way home. They never even knew what was happening until I was long gone.

37474698.review:
Zugegeben, bei "Äußerst Positiv" bewerteten Spielen bin ich extrem skeptisch, wie in diesem Fall.

Allerdings ist dieses Spiel zurecht so gut bewertet, denn es hat ein Sandboxartiges Missionsdesign, das einem dutzende Möglichkeiten gibt eine Situation zu meistern. 

Es gibt so viele tolle Gegenstände, die im Video zu sehenden sind nur wenige. Eines kann die Zeit extrem verlangsamen und den Spieler doppelt so schnell machen. Für mich mit meinem Hammer genau das richtige um 5 Feinde im nu auszuschalten. Oder man stellt eine Falle: Man läuft durch den Sichtbereich eines Gegners, dieser kommt schauen was da los ist, man lässt einen kleinen Teleporter fallen und stellt ihn so ein, dass der Gegner in den Weltraum geportet wird.

Genau so kann man es auch, wie von vielen beschrieben, als Hotline Miami spielen.

Oder ein bisschen Weltraumshooter. Einmal war der Pilot des Schiffs sehr nah an meinem Einstieg, wenn man den umbringt, dann fliegt das Schiff nicht zur nächsten Station, wenn es angegriffen oder man als Eindringling erkannt wird. Also hab ich ihn getötet und musste noch jemanden retten, der ziemlich weit am anderen ende lag. Es waren viel zu starke Gegner auf dem Weg dahin, also habe ich ein kleineres Schiff gekapert und das andere Schiff zu Klump geschossen. Schon konnte ich viel näher an der Zielperson andocken und ihn direkt rausholen.

Es gibt einfach so viele tolle Variationen, wie man dieses Spiel spielen kann. Für die 10,39 EUIR derzeit kann man nichts falsch machen.

Ach und Missionen gibt es auch unendlich, ich dachte anfangs, dass jeder Stern für eine Mission steht. Das sind einfach Stationen, die man befreien kann. Überall treiben Schiffe durchs All und es gibt genug zu tun.

So I snuck into a ship, gadget in hand. It lets me teleport a certain distance for a few seconds, then return to my original position after a couple of seconds.

The room next door has four guards. No blind spots to take advantage of to get around them.  With no way to sneak around without getting noticed, I teleport into the room and brandish the four wrenches I had brought with me. You know, just in case.

One after the other, the four guards go down in an flash. The teleporter takes me back to where I was and I continue on my way to send this enemy ship on a crash course to a space station.

I only had ten seconds to get out. Knowing I won't make it back to my ship in time, I shoot out a window and let the vacuum of space sweep me away to (relative) safety, barreling in the general direction of my ship.

Show me another game where you can quadruple wield four wrenches and escape a ship via space vacuum.

37399152.review:
In the short 4.3 hours I currently have played I can say this game certainly has a lot of replay value purely due to the fact that each mission plays out differently. Trying new things is really where the depth of this game shows.

Easily my favorite encounter so far was where I stumbled into a fight that wound up exploding one of the ships thrusters... and also severed the ship in two. Fortunately I was still on the section that had my objective in it. Unfortunately there was a locked door in my way with the only key still on board the other chunk of ship spinning through space. So naturally I flew to the other part to retrieve the key of course! after docking with the lost piece of the ship, killing the guards inside and then catching back up to the other part of the ship, I had a total of 32 seconds left to complete my mission before being caught. I hauled ass through the ship to grab the item I was asked to steal where I then paused the game and looked at a bright read number 5 at the top of my screen. I managed to just barely turn the corner of the next room fast enough to shoot the captain from 4 rooms away and with only 1 second left before being captured.

A game that emphasizes thinking, that's what this is. Not just one type of thinking either. You can sit and plan out your mission from the very start with the information provided at the job listings board and even scout the ship completely as soon as you dock with it. You can alternatively just run in without any planning and figure things out as you go. Both will likely end up needing some mid-mission adjustments depending on how things play out.

Don't let the simplistic top down art style keep you from giving this excellent game a chance.

Challenging, hilarious, and super fun. If you play it straight, it's more like a puzzle game: amass high power items in high quantities, and proceed through each mission in the proper order, collecting more items etc.

Screw that, though: start tossing guards out windows, blowing up the engine sections of ships, and flying captured ships into other hostile ships.

Don't let the difficulty scare you. I'm mediocre at most "difficult" games, but the pause feature lets you take all the time you need to examine the ridiculous situation you find yourself in, and formulate an equally ridiculous plan.

37336253.review:
When you look into a game of this type, The most important thing is [b] how much stuff [/b] you can do.

So let me tell you a story.

I was playing the Personal Mission. You only get one of those per character, it's a "losing is not an option" type of thing. I had to rescue a target, using the stuff I found throughout the game.
Only thing, I never found an armor-penetrating gun. So I got creative.
Used a key-cloner to avoid contact with the first group. Snuck by a couple of guards with a stealth shield. Found a short-range teleporter, distracted a guard and stole the cell key.
When I entered the cell, one of the guards saw me. Immidiately I saw a swarm of shotgun blasts directed at me. It was bad. Luckily, at the last millisecond, I placed a teleporter trap, before falling down, bleeding. So everybody who tried to pick me up (and throw into space to die), got trapped in space himself. Ok, I got the target, time to get out.

And then another ship attacked.

The extraction point was demolished in seconds. I was honestly about to give up. But then a crazy idea passed my mind.
I took out the last gadget I had: a one-use time slowdown for everyone except me. Turned it on, picked up the body, and ran towards the window.
As the slowdown stopped, it became clear how fast I was [i] actually [/i] running. I threw my target through the window like a goddamn superman. Immediately we both got sucked into space.
On my last bit of oxygen, I turned on the remote control for my space pod. I directed it towards us with the rear door open, and saved both myself and the target.

Achievement get: White knuckle exctraction.

37335853.review:
Be hired to steal an object. Notice there are items that let you teleport anywhere within a range for a limited time, before pulling you back. Wonder why you bothered unlocking doors.
See an achievement for using two of those items at a time. Wonder how many you can chain together. Go on a heist with five of those things, chain enough together to get into the room with the item you need to steal. Notice you're being pulled back in the same order you teleported in, instead of the reverse. Be stuck in a locked room.

Be tasked with an assassination on a large ship full of guards, armed with a sword and a kind of teleporter.
Jump right into the middle of five guards. Kill the first, throw your sword at the second, teleport the two now unused swords into your hands to kill the next two guards and throw one at the last, before any of them even realised what just happened.

Every character comes with their own bit of backstory and motivation, defining their personal goals. They all work towards the common goal of freeing their little patch of the galaxy from four different factions. Characters that are captured can be freed by others and played again.
The beginnings are humble. But as you progress your equipment gets better and you grow bolder, which can lead to both, hilarious failures and epic successes.
While the missions don't vary that much the bonus targets and randomly generated ships and crews bring in enough change that things don't get boring.
With time you're not just playing some guy trying to pay off his sister's debt, avenge his mother or free his buddy. You're playing a force of nature. And just when you think you know all of the game you find a new way to apply a known mechanic. I can absolutely recommend this game.

So today in Heat Signature I:

1. Stripped the flesh from my enemies bodies with a shotgun that uses acidic currency for ammo.
2. Bifurcated a space ship with a well-timed shot to a poorly placed fuel tank.
3. Killed 6 people in the space of a moment using a nothing but a sword.
4. Assassinated a target by throwing them and myself out of a breached window into the cold void of space.
5. Hijacked one ship for the sole purpose of ramming it into another ship as a means of creating an opening to a hard to reach target.
6. Siphoned fuel from a larger ship like a tick to get my damaged pod back to my home station.
7. Stole something without once being seen by anyone.
8. Found a gun left by a retired friend.
9. Used a personal shield to deflect a point blank bullet back at my attacker.
10. Died in the cold vastness of space, my wife's death unavenged because my ship got obliterated in a warzone.

Play Heat Signature if you wanna feel like the greatest badass in the Galaxy. Play Heat Signature if you wanna laugh at your ridiculous failures. Play Heat Signature if you want to get hopelessly attached to a piece of kit you know you're gonna have to give up (either in death or retirement). Play Heat Signature, it's a good game.

37282256.review:
I manage to sneak past the guards for most of the mission, but now I'm in a right tight spot.

2 full kit squads of 4 guards are nearby, and one of them is nearly in view.  Firing up my trusty Sidewinder I glitch past the guard and make it to the loot, finally fulfilling my lifelong goal.

Just one problem.  That was the last charge on my Sidewinder, meaning it's dead until I get back.  Or...well...die.

I'm not kitted with a stealth shield.  Just didn't have one but sure wishing for it now.  Then a thought strikes me.  Break the window.  Nothing standing between me and freedom but fragile glass.  Well...that and an endless vacuum of nothingness waiting to make my eyes explode.

No airlock nearby...no way past the guard...too many guards to book for the exit...I pull out my shotgun, take careful aim, squeeze...

And hold my breath.  And start the timer.  20 seconds.

The glass shatters and vanishes without sound.  After all there's no air in space.  19 seconds.

The maw of nothingness slurps me into the void, and my breath is almost stolen from me.  18.

And I'm free.  Well, free to die.  I put my breacher on autopilot.  It takes longer than normal.  Too long.  13.

I see the lights.  12.

It's still so far away...11.

I blink...and loose count.  My lungs start to burn.

And just when I cannot hold my breath anymore...the breacher scoops me up and I am GONE.

While normally I wouldn't mind taking a shot and getting carried to freedom...I don't have any blood to spare.  I'd die the moment they put me out the airlock.  And bullets sting worse than stun rounds.

As I look back, I spot another little prize.  No...too risky...and yet...

The sheer satisfaction of riding in on someone's elses ship just can't be beat.

Heat Signature is a delightful game from a delightful designer. Gunpoint was already a fantastic playground for devious thinking, spur of the moment experimentation, and cartoony but hilarious violence, and Heat Signature retains all of those qualities while changing all the things you'd think would render concepts unrecognizable - setting, interface, perspective, level design. Doesn't matter. Still feels like a great addition to the same design principles, and it's a blast.

Also, has one of the best game launch trailers of all time, has received frequent meaningful updates, and Tom Francis is just a joy to follow and read the thoughts of. Highly recommended. Don't miss.

Heat signature is an apt metaphor for life; in that it's chaos.

Be prepared to create elaborate plans, and then use those blueprints as a rolled up bat to whack all the enemies you run past in your mad dash to salvage what little of your plan is still intact. Things will go wrong, but that's the whole point. The game is pseudo turn based in that at any moment you can pause and set up your next action.

Every item you brought along for your incredible plan, can all be used in emergent ways, completely unintended to how you set out. Likely you can save the situation. But if you die, don't worry, someone else will take your place.

If you survive, then maybe you'll be smart and retire while you're alive; your legend to continue onwards.

37245917.review:
Have you played Hotline: Miami? This is Hotline: Miami... but in SPAAAAAACE!

[h1]Let's make this simple...[/h1]
[list]
[*]When you have a gun, you shoot people.
[*]When you run out of ammo, you throw the gun.
[*]When you don't have a gun you hit them with a wrench.
[*]When you're too far away you throw the wrench.
[*]Sometimes you hit yourself with the wrench.
[*]Can't take out a guard because he has armour? Just teleport him outside the ship. His armour won't help him when he can't breathe.
[*]Wanna be a space ninja? Use the longblade. Maybe two.
[*]Thrown all your shit on the floor? Use the Everything Gun.
[*]Want the enemy to shoot themselves? Swap places with them.
[*]Want them to shoot themselves again? Hack their bubble so their bullets bounce back.
[*]Hate turrets? Hack the turrets so they shoot enemies for you.
[/list]

Or you can just lurk around all sneaky-beaky-like and pretend you're a ghost.

Sometimes the mean guards toss you out of the ship, then you just scoop yourself back up. Unlike literally all the guards, you came prepared, so you can survive in space for a few seconds.

Have too much money? Literally shoot money at the bad guys with the Fleshstripper. Makes the bad guys strip... but they won't stop till they're all bones.

37234215.review:
I've played Heat Signature for at least 20 hours offline. It's a fantastic game. Basically, you fly about in a little pod, board enemy spaceships, take out everyone aboard, and return to your base. Really, there are different sorts of missions available, such as "steal the thing", "assassinate the dude", or "steal the ship", but effectively it usually comes down to, "go about and take everyone out, then do the thing" as the most expedient method. Sometimes you can't kill anyone, but that's mostly just a gear check, requiring a wrench instead of a sword or a concussive gun instead of a lethal one. The tactics don't change much. They do change some, though, and deny you the use of cool things like traps that teleport enemies into space, as they'll suffocate. It actually reminds me a lot of how a non-lethal Dishonored run made you unable to use many of the cool gadgets. It's similarly a bit sad, but as in this it's on a ship by ship basis, it can be a nice change of pace. Unless you have a bunch of cool lethal weapons you're itching to use and instead have to go about knocking people out with a wrench like a lamebutt.

And if you're like me, you must get past its graphics. They're quite ugly, to my eyes. Less subjectively, it can often be very difficult to tell what objects in a level are passable set dressing, and which block movement and line of sight. I got shot a few times due to this, expecting enemies to not see me and instead being shot as I tried furiously to backpedal. However, characters are immenently replaceable, so even the one I lost due to this I didn't mind too much.

I have other gripes - many, in fact. The AI's patrol routines are far too exploitable, which can make missions meant to be hard (or even "audacious" or "mistake") too easy, but slow and boring. Forcing you to play suboptimally to make the game fun. Never a good thing to the force the player to do.

And the enemies could use some variety. They're all humans, with a handful of pieces of equipment available to them - mostly just shields, teleportation, armour, and explosives that go off if they die violently (though if you knock them out and THEN kill them, for some reason they don't explode - perhaps you're disarming them? I dunno.).

There are also only two types of enemy per level. The mooks have one combination of gear, the "bosses" have another, usually one that makes them a little trikier to deal with. But not remotely deserving of the title "boss."

The changing combinations of gear in each ship do provide a good deal of variety. Hours worth of it, even. And combine this with the changing gear you have as you retire characters and start new ones, and your playstyle will change often, keeping things fresh a lot longer.

The ship layouts are also quite boring. Mostly square rooms, the occasional bigger rectangular room, connected by straight hallways. It gets old.

If they put out a DLC with more enemy types and fights on planet surfaces or something - anything with more open, chaotic environments that made you think harder about each new level - I'd jump on it so fast. Which goes to show how happy I really am with the game. I've gotten my money's worth, even if I may be done now.

The joy of teleporting dudes into space, hijacking a turret so it takes everyone out for you, or just being a timestopping badass shotgunning and slashing your way through a horde in under a second is just so great. The core gmeplay loop is very enjoyable.

I wish there were more just because what there is is so fantastic, but that just means it's worth the price and worth buying any theoretical DLC in the future.

37214652.review:
This is the type of game where strategies you wouldn't expect to work anywhere else do.

I got caught trying to sneak through a ship and they were twenty seconds from safety and capturing me....So I blew out all their engines and took my time.

I couldn't see an easy way through a mass of armoured, shielded guards on a large ship. So I stole another one and rammed them together. 

I had to assassinate someone behind way too many defenses. So I tele-swapped places with a nearby guard and shiv'd the target, swapping back before the other guards could raise their weapons.

I got spotted down a corridor with no nearby exits. So I threw my hammer at the guy and knocked him out.

I didn't want to backtrack a rescued target through a ship I'd snuck through...So I blew out a window and caught us both with my pod.

That's the kind of things you will end up doing. This game is great. Quick sessions and long marathons still manage to feel rewarding on one level or another.

And the Devs seem to be listening. Just look at the 'Fair Points' update, it balances out some annoyances by giving you more strategies...ones you have to work a little to get working for you. Actual balance there, and thought put into mechanical solutions to problems. 

I wholeheartedly reccomend at least giving it a try.

37171326.review: Heat signature is a game about taking on challenges that don't seem possible and then completing them by knocking people out of windows. If you don't like taking on ridiculous risks and challenges, you will be able to play this game but you will not enjoy it as much as if you love surviving by the skin of your teeth and your wit. There isn't much as satisfying as killing a target you are unprepared to kill by luck and incredibly careful planning, and having a backup meticulous plan when your first one fails. 37171286.review:
A really well-made (if somewhat simplistic) little gem of a game.

Each mission generates a random ship with various rooms and then you try to complete the objective using whatever tools you have at your disposal including teleporters, traps, guns, swords and various tech.

You can pause whenever you want, which allows you to set up fun and/or insane combos.

Any items you find can be named & stashed for your steam friends to discover in their own games.

Honestly there isn't much negative to say about Heat Signature other than it can get a bit grindy for certain achievements, especially once you know all the game mechanics really well. The music could have been slightly more energetic during the missions but that's probably just personal taste. It would have been really cool if the music was synched with your in-game actions à la Doom.

Good value for money even if it's not on sale.

[b] Overall score: 9/10 [/b]

37165561.review:
[i](I assume you've read the "About this game" section on this store page, everything the developer says there I can 100% guarantee is in the game (23.11.2017))[/i]

(Disclaimer: I bought this game as soon as it hit Early Access because I already like the previous game of this developer, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/206190/Gunpoint/]Gunpoint[/url]. My review however will be only about Heat Signature and why I would buy it if I had never known before that this developer is capable of making interesting games)

[h1]Heat Signature is one of those games that is easy to start but hard to master.[/h1]

Heat signature is a fantastic game. It offers a clear path of progression, a setting that fits the narrative, keyboard/mouse controls which feel like this game was designed for PC gaming and it rewards you with LOOT, LOOT and more LOOT.

After a while you'll find your favourite weapon(s)/gadget(s) (for me that's [spoiler]the armor pircing shortblade and the rechargable cloak[/spoiler]) that you'll take with you as a no-brainer on every mission, but thanks to the randomness of found loot on ships you'll most certainly find new equipment of which you can take advantage by chaning your playstyle. So do not worry about repetitiveness, while mission types are set, the way you complete those missions varies.

[u]Whom would I reccomend this game?[/u]

[list]
    [*]Players who like [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/212680/FTL_Faster_Than_Light/]Faster than Light[/url]
    [*]Players who like [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/322500/SUPERHOT/]SUPERHOT[/url]
    [*]Players who like [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/219150/Hotline_Miami/]Hotline Miami[/url] (no worries, Heat Signature is more forgiving than Hotline Miami, so if you just didn't like the difficulty of Hotline Miami, Heat Signature might still be a game for you)
    [*]Players who favor playing a game more than watching a story unfold (if you can only play games that have an interesting story, this might not be a game for you)
    [*]Players who want to feel like they've actually accomplished something after taking a risk
[/list]

This is a game that does permadeath right! If you screw up - you're not gonna die right away. No... that's when the fun part starts. Now you have to do everything you can to salvage the mission. 36977384.review:
For the first 10 or so hours, I quite liked Heat Signature. The gameplay is fun and unique, without being too gimicky. It scratches same itch that Hotline Miami does, with fast paced, top-down combat, and encouraging multiple ways to get through a level. The game world feel conquerable and populated but without losing the vast emptyness of space. Outside of this initial experience with the game, I won't list every pro and con; there are many other reviews and blogs that have that covered. I have played many more hours of Heat Signature than my 10ish hours on Steam would indicate (I bought the DRM-free version from Humble Store).

With the most recent update, several features have been added, seemingly to make the game easier. One of my major gripes with this game is how easy it becomes after liberating a few stations. Unlock just a few decent weapons and tools and you'll be good to go on any new character. Several of these changes simply modify in game textures to make certain types of npcs and bits of terrain easier to distinguish, and that's fine. In fact, all of these changes were fine, even the 'cheat' to turn off permadeath. All these features appeal to at least some of the player base. 

What I would have liked to have seen in addition to these changes, would be some options for increasing the difficulty and challenge level. In my main save file, even losing my most geared up character isn't a huge deal, because after a few missions I can afford the same 'rare' gear that I've unlocked from liberating stations. Retiring a character, and being able to leave a custom named heirloom behind for other characters, while a very cool idea, doesn't really work in the context of the game. The drop rates are too low to be likely to find one before you unlock the exact same weapon in the shop.

One thing that I find very concerning, is a line from the changlog of the most recent update (at the time of posting).
"This update is a one-off, we don’t plan to do updates like this on a regular basis. We might add items from time to time, but only buy the game if you want the game as it stands – we don’t make promises about future content."
This game as it is currently, is lacking content. Adding a new gun every once and a while will not provide enough new and exciting action to support, what is already a game that is too repetitive. I would like to see at least one major content update (even as a dlc expansion), or support for modifications. 

I very rarely find a game that makes me excited to wake up the next day in order to resume playing it. I can honestly say that Heat Signature was one of those games. Considering the most recent update addressed many 'fair points' brought up by the community, I have faith that the developers are listening and willing to make changes where it's deemed necessary. As the game is now, I cannot recommend it, at least not at the current price, with the knowledge that major content updates are not guarenteed, or even in the works. I have a huge amount of respect for the developers, especially for developing the game for three years before release, when so many others pump out half finished games in early access, and settle for the cash grab. I look forward to rewriting this review in the future, and giving the game my recommendation.
