Heat Signature gives you randomly generated missions and a slew of interesting tools, weapons, and mechanics to achieve them.  The game is sufficiently challenging, but gives you enough leeway to experiment around and discover how all the different pieces of the game interact and is very good at doing what you expect when using items in novel ways.

As an example, here are some of the ways I have assassinated targets.  (Spoiler Alert, if you'd prefer to find these out yourself).

-Shot target with a gun
-Sliced target with a sword
-Teleported target into space
-Ejected myself into space and then used a teleporter to switch places with target
-Threw a corpse into a window causing it to shatter, ejecting target (and myself) into space
-Left a remotely detonated grenade on the floor for target's friend to pick up and deliver to target
-Lured target to engines, then exploded ship's fuel
-Smashed my ship into enemy ship so hard the section of the ship my target was in exploded
-Hijacked another ship and shot at enemy ship until it was no more
-Took over automated turret as target was passing by
-And much much more.

36933119.review: First off, I will say that I enjoy this game and I personally think it is quite a fun and unique idea.  However, there are a few things that I want to say to people who are considering buying this game.  I recommend buying it if you can stay dedicated just by doing missions over and over again.  If I'm being honest, I had probably discovered most if not all of the weapons and items by the time I had liberated my first outpost.  That said, there are a decent number of modifiers to be discovered which add a bit more content to it, but overall there isn't that much weapon-wise.  Most of this game's content lies within the randomly generated(I assume, otherwise props to the devs for hand-crafting just about infinity ships) ships and extensive missions, as well as the permadeath randomly generated(again, if the characters aren't randomly created, props to the devs) characters.  Each and every mission is different, and you have to think and use the charges of your weapons carefully each time.  You will always end up getting new characters, however, as there are just so many features in the game that *suggest*(assertively) that you make new characters.  So, if you are looking for a ton of cool weapons to use to kill people in space, this might not be for you, but I still recommend you try it because I have had a lot of fun just from the extensiveness of the ships and characters.  Overall, it's a great game!

36883100.review:
Roguelike/permadeath features aren't generally my thing, but Heat Signature manages to soften the blow in at least two significant ways: success, ultimately, loses you just as much as failure; and failure doesn't stop you, it just makes you rethink your next mission's strategy. I'd say "it slows you down," but given you have faster liberation rates on newer characters, depending on how deep into a character's run you were when you died, it might not really even do that.

Probably the most fun I've had with a top-down style game in quite a while. It's not perfect (though its recent update addressed some of the more popular issues, like densely-populated missions with all the guards protected by shields), but most of its flaws work through the game's various challenge systems to make things more interesting, rather than frustrating. I feel pretty good recommending it to anyone who likes top-down action games.

36845465.review:
I fucked up the mission, and Eden Phase was caught, taken away, and imprisoned by Offworld Security. Up until that point, she had been the most successful galactic renaissance leader we'd ever seen, ruthlessly hijacking any ship she deemed fit weilding concussion hammers, traveling so quickly no one person ever saw her for a mere second before flying down the corridor, ribs shattered from the impact. Up until the last mission at least. She miscalculated, didn't have enough time. Didn't have the key, or the tools, to get through the door to get to the pilot before they arrived at the station, and was caught.

This is where Pavo Starspelt came in. Eden Phase's father. He heard that his daughter was abducted and threw his life away to hunt down the Offworld Security ship that had Eden, and swore to bring her to safety. He armed himself with anything he could find, including a silenced shotgun, a self-charging visitor, a concussive grenade launcher, a subverter, a long-range extreme capacity key cloner, and a personal shield amoung other things.

He finally hunted down the ship with Eden inside and went to infiltrate. Eight layers of security. He didn't have enough memory on the key cloner to get through quietly. He managed to sneak past the first four layers of security without much hastle, stealing a key from one of the guards while he wasn't looking and getting into the fifth to kill off the pilot. They weren't going anywhere any time soon. He managed to sneak past a group of five guards and hack one of the panels, unlocking level 6. This is where he started to run out of utility. 

There were turrets around every other corner at this point, and hordes of police that would swarm him if any of them went off. He had to time his movements perfectly to get past everything without being seen and sneak up behind them, which he managed. He got to level 7 security - and that's where he messed up. 

There was a turret on the other side he hadn't seen that immediately went to shoot him. In a split second he managed to pop the security shield that absorbed the rounds and teleport away with the visitor to kill every guard within range of the sound with the silenced shotgun, trying to wipe any form of alert from the ship. But it was too late. He had to fight his way through. He killed everyone that came towards him, coming inches from getting shot on multiple occasions. Always on the move, eventually getting close enough to the turret to subvert it, turning it to his side. He was lucky enough that the guy with the key card turned the corner and was shot by the same turret, grabbed the key card, and sprinted through the security 8 door. 

This is the area Eden was in, but he had used almost all of his utility to get to this point, and there were still guards in the first 4 levels of security he had bypassed, so he couldn't go back to his ship, not directly at least. He popped a shield and ran directly for Eden, the single room surrounded by at least 12 guards. At this point, he had no more ammo, and no more grenades. The key cloner was useless, and the visitor would only bring him back to where he was after a second and leave Eden behind if he were carrying her, so he couldn't use it for getaways. That left the two charges he had left on the personal shield.

He managed to make it to Eden, using his shield again to protect her as he ran away. One charge remaining. There were too many guards to make it out the same way he came in, so he had to find another way. The glass. He ran past a corridor with one of the police looking for him. He had a personal shield as well. Running back towards the way he came, careful not to round any corners before the enemy could see him, luring him back to the Security 7 zone, and past the turret he had subverted. The only problem is the round would bounce right off his shield.

He rounded the corner to the hallway the turret protected as it turned to face his direction, the Offworld Security Officer followed, and was nearly instantly barraged with a burst of ammo from the turret. The rounds passed Pavo, inches away, and slammed into the Offworld Security Officer's shield, bouncing back towards him. He threw Eden behind him and popped the last charge of his shield, and the ammo bounced off of him. It went flying straight though the massive observatory window, shattering it and sucking all of them; Officer, Pavo, and Eden, into the depths of space.

Pavo knew he had to exhale in order to get all the air he could out of his lungs. Otherwise, they'd expand inside him and kill him. He looked around for Eden, having been ripped from his Offworld Security ship as the glass broke, thrown out into the vacuum of space. She was floating away from him. He went for the remote control band on his arm and undocked his ship, hurriedly flying it past the wreckage he had just been through and towards Eden, trying desperately to catch her first incase he suffocated there in space, at least knowing she would be safe. He managed to catch her as he was starting to black out, and throttled the ship towards himself as he started to lose his own vision, managing by some sliver of a hair to catch himself in the depths of space before passing out on the floor of his ship, drifting deeper into space.

They eventually woke up and flew back to their home system, where Pavo retired. And rightfully so. He had "Eden's Protection" engraved on the side of the silenced shotgun he had used, and gave it to Eden. He would have used the personal shield, but it had been though so much it wouldn't work any more. Since then, Eden has been the most successful Legend, liberating over 7 star systems single-handedly with the help of her father's shotgun. And she continues to do so to this day.

All of this happened in this game.

This game is incredible. The basic premise is pretty simple - break into spaceships, use your cool gadgets to complete the objective, and get out without dying. Withing that framework, however, there's really no end to what you can do.

Want to teleport around and swap places with guards so they all kill each other with friendly fire? You can do that.
Want to smash windows and throw guards into the icy vacuum of space? You can do that too.
Want to just carry around 8 swords and chain-stab your way through an entire room full of angry people with guns? Go for it.
Want to propel yourself into the airlock from the icy vacuum of space with nothing but a shotgun? You just might have to.
Want to blow everyone up with a grenade launcher that fires 5 grenades at once? That can be arranged.

There are loads more crazy tools that I haven't even mentioned here. If you can think of an insane way to get through an enemy ship, chances are it can be done in Heat Signature. This game is worth every penny. If you enjoy fun, buy it.

Oh gosh is this game the best. It feels like an old roguelike: there are many ways to grab the key. Run into the room and shotgun everyone? Use your stealth shield and steal it from that guard? Lure them into your trap and teleport them out into space? A combination of the said tactics? Since each ship is randomly generated, the adventure is always different and never gets old. And while you think that your plan is airtight, the shotgun blast misses a few of those guards. so you pause: 
you could pull your pistol out, but that would take to long to reload and shoot the other one. That swapper would be useful, but it only has one use left. You're just too far away to use your concussion hammer. But you find a plan: shoot one guard, wait until the other one shoots, and swap with them so they take the hit. And you feel brilliant. 36776757.review:
Heat Signature is a pretty great game. Upon initially discovering that the amount of progress that your characters get towards conquering the overworld from each mission trails off into nothing after a while (forcing you to retire characters to keep progressing), I was disappointed.

However, after playing longer I understand and think it's actually a good feature. Lots of items in the game are so powerful as to be game-breaking if abused. A single Visitor, a teleporter that lets you jump anywhere briefly before warping back, is a powerful but limited tool. Two Visitors can start to become cheesy, allowing you to warp "back" to the first location you jumped to when used in quick succession. Two rechargeable Visitors allow for even more cheese. Two self-charging Visitors completely break the game.

As you progress through the overworld you get more guaranteed access to this powerful gear, having it available in the shop rather than needing to loot it from fallen enemies or chests. This is great for letting you try out insane combos, but also gives you the ability to just buy insane gear and eliminate all challenge from the game. The mechanics of retirement and completing the "campaign" and resetting your world do a great job of letting you have all that power, but giving you reasons to choose to start fresh. This seems novel in the face of so many games that curtail the power of the player in pursuit of balance.

36682622.review:
[i]UPDATE: There was one. To the game, I mean. This review too. But the game mostly. It added some new content, which is totally appreciated. I'll spend some more hours in-game and adjust my review then.[/i]

Fantastic and unique core gameplay, expanded on using roguelike elements, but limited by a lack of long-term consequences, variety, and narrative, plus confusing graphics and UI. If you're like me, I'd recommend it on the basis of being interestingly innovative alone, but you'll also get a ~12 hour playthrough if you only play the enjoyable parts. A 100% completion run isn't worth it, though you'll probably keep popping in during lunch break.

I wouldn't ask you to believe me without verification, so let's go over some specific examples (without spoilers):

[b]CORE GAMEPLAY![/b] Real-time-with-pause top-down 2D shooter with one-hit-kills/knockouts. WASD to move, mouse to aim, click to fire, all controls rebindable. Missions rarely last more than five minutes, and you can speed through most in under thirty seconds. However, you have infinite slo-mo (automatically applies while in sight of an enemy, but can also be bound to a key), and can pause, adjust your aim, and fire. Thrown in the mix is a simple stealth system; there's no fog of war on the player's end, but stay in a guard's cone of vision and an alarm sounds, causing a doom timer to start (game time; pausing and slo-mo stop and slow the timer, respectively). Expect to ask yourself "If I pop out of cover, can I shoot everyone in the room before they raise the alarm/shoot back?", and "Can I use a gadget to lure people out of the room, sneak by, or give myself extra time to shoot?" The quick time to kill makes combat visceral, ala twitch shooters, but adjustable pacing prioritizes thinking over reflexes and marksmanship, ala tactical shooters. It's beautiful.

[b]ROGUELIKE ELEMENTS![/b] "Soft" permadeath: death wipes your cash and inventory, but campaign progress remains. Also noteworthy: getting hit knocks you out even with weapons that kill everyone else. However, taking hits reduces the likelihood you'll survive next time. The game randomly generates the player characters, mission layouts and objectives, guard positions and equipment, unlock trees, and shop inventories, but tempers this with player choice; get a mission or character you don't like and you can choose another from a small list. There's little overarching story besides "end the war", but there is some short, structures, and surprisingly philosophical and funny conversations to unlock (When is it right to kill? What constitutes a person? What drives corporations? Why does the training machine have a "MORE VIOLENCE" button?).

[b]LACK OF CONSEQUENCES![/b] We've gone over how bullets treat you special. There's stat tracking for kills, knockouts, alarms, and living witnesses, but these oddly don't matter outside the occasional bonus objective. Kill with impunity and guards never think to ditch stun guns. Cause alarms and no one steps up security. Leave witnesses and no one comes after you. It's a fantastic foundation for a reputation system, and nothing's utilized. The absolute worst setback the game throws at you is death, but you only lose your cash and inventory (replaceable with a half hour's play at most, and you'll still progress the campaign during that time). There's never any meaningfully risky missions, which means you're never too worried about consequences, which robs the game of meaningful long-term choices, which limits long-term replay value.

[b]LACK OF VARIETY![/b] The positions of rooms themselves vary, but you'll recognize room every layout within an hour. You'll have seen most of the gear in six, minus a few rare variants you'll never get to keep anyways. Not helping matters are the defector missions; optional challenges that give you limited but interesting gear restrictions in an effort to make you aware of new playstyles. Unfortunately, this spoils a lot of mechanics while giving no progress whatsoever, thus making the rest of the game a retread. Even the guards follow predictable patterns, never looking for missing comrades or leaving their designated section unprovoked. There's missed opportunities for variety everywhere; every bullet flies the same speed, room layouts never combine into larger rooms, guards use only a handful of available weapons, the game's set in space but never uses aliens, and so on.

[b]LACK OF NARRATIVE![/b] Am I the good guy? Who am I working for? What am I working for? Supposedly the region's at war, but who does that affect? What's at stake? There's the extremely well-written conversations that flesh out the faction's beliefs and government, but there's not much payoff besides a few laughs and some interesting ideological discussion. The characters you're talking to never do anything, the factions function mostly the same gameplay-wise (good idea making the police faction use non-lethal weapons, but the illusion was broken when they put missile launchers on their ships). I have very little reason to suspend disbelief, which makes caring about the story or messaging near impossible. I mean, I guess there's some anarchist theming? You're fighting for the region's independence, and that corporate faction's pretty bad, so I guess it's better than those guys. But there's three other factions with roughly the same influence, and there's no obvious ideological reason they can't get along. You got an engineer faction, a police faction, and a nomad faction, with no known history between them. Not exactly Sunnis and Shias. Why are we fighting again? Oh, right, it's a videogame.

[b]CONFUSING GRAPHICS AND UI![/b] This is better served with screenshots. Best of times [url=https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/857236050649859360/CCDD59000B124F0BFA70A3853D354A3E7AB57ABD/]here[/url], worst of times [url=https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/857236050652732362/DAE80188BE8D238B5BD6FB2B2A9B427B794B2283/]here[/url]. They should speak for themselves.

[b]ALSO THE MUSIC'S FUNCTIONAL BUT FORGETABLE![/b] It's all instrumental tracks and they're typical sci-fi-esque. Mysterious electronic theme while flying through space, neutral electronic theme while at a friendly station, slightly more intense electronic theme while on enemy spaceships, you get the drill. Not that it's phoned in; the beeps and boops have just the right amount of polish to convey the tone. Unfortunately, that tone is too generic to convey anything interesting. I blame the narrative; without anything interesting to say, the composer doesn't have anything to reinforce. Maybe if the factions had individual themes? The mechanic faction could mix in industrial, the corporate faction could mix in pop chords and beats, the police faction could mix in academy-style drums, the nomad faction could mix in classical strings. Right now, the music just...exists.

[u]Final Verdict:[/u] Buy it, the core gameplay's just that good. Avoid the defector missions that aren't labeled "special". Hunt achievements, they're decent enough excuses to play. I'd love to see some tweaks, and I'd pay money for an expansion, maybe something a little more narrative focused or with long-term consequences. Regardless, it's enjoyable as is. I'll miss real-time-with-pause when move on to other shooters, top-down or otherwise.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
话说在前头，这游戏并不是很需要读懂里面的英文。你只需要记住Capture 绑架, steal偷窃, rescue救人，这一类重点词汇，以及武器上的那些消音，穿甲等等等等的附魔英文。 当然你英文好也可以看看剧情（基本上没有
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
我目前是Hummer+SC Slipstream冲进去开无双的打法，但是这个游戏提供的多样性是无限的。例如绑架任务，你可以传送到绑架目标面前吓他一跳再传送回去，然后等他过来追你走到玻璃窗旁边时打碎玻璃 让他被吸入太空，再回到你的飞船上驾驶飞船在他窒息之前接住他。偷窃任务你可以开着抢来的飞船直接把目标飞船炸开，再从炸开的缺口冲进去抢了东西直接飞身跳入太空，然后再远程驾驶你的飞船接住在太空里以每秒11km速度漫游的你。
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
看了下大家的测评，其实大家都没有意识到作者的用心，也有可能是我想多了233。作者其实是在想尝试做一个类似于迈阿密热线（快节奏）+回合制的一种游戏。游戏中按下空格可以完全暂停时间，这给了你回合制的优势：你有很长的时间想你能干嘛。游戏战斗的爽快和流畅又能给你迈阿密热线那种快节奏游戏的刺激。在游戏初期我装备不是很完善的时候， 我往往会遇到一个问题，我的装备不能解决我遇到的危机。怎么办？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？？这时我会按下空格，暂停时间，查看装备，冷静思考，脑子里开始想，这个传送可以把我送到右边的房间，右边的房间里有个黑客卡，我可以用来黑掉这个该死的炮塔。但是我传送过去之后房间里有3个敌人，我不能在他们打死我之前杀了他们。那我就传送过去拿起黑客卡，黑掉炮塔，打碎玻璃，让所有人都被吸进太空，所有人都会窒息而死，而我在房间里放下了一个传送点，我被吸入太空后3秒，将会被传送回目标飞船里，我偷走客户需要的文件，我拿钱，我睡觉。
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
总之 这是一个3小时上手 5小时上瘾 剩下全是追求极致装备的刷刷刷游戏。很好玩   推荐

Simply put; This game is a masterpiece. 

If you want to feel like a master assasin, thief, mercenary, hostage-rescue-guy, or whatever, look no further.  And once you have done a few [spoiler]"Mistake" difficulty[/spoiler] missions and collected some decent gear, you'll feel ike a one man army, an unstoppable weapon, a boogeyman, a nightmare. 
The mechanics are fair and rewarding, if you get injured, it's because you made a mistake, didn't notice something, or just plain bit off more than you could chew. When everything goes right though, it feels extremely satisfying. 
The dificulty regulates itself by letting you chose which difficulty missions you want to take. There is also a mechanic to make it more rewarding to start over with new characters and retire your accomplished ones which I won't get into but it is well executed. 

This game ticks so many boxes for what I enjoy in a game, it really is a rare gem, and deserves a place in the Indie Hall of Fame. If you consider yourself a gamer, and don't get around to playing Heat Signature, you are depriving yourself of what could be the best gaming experience of the year in my opinion.

£10.99 is a bargain, support the devs.

36484428.review: Heat Signature is a game of intergalactic heists on board randomly-generated spaceships. With a combination of real-time action that keeps you on your toes and strategy-based game pausing, Heat Signature delivers an excellent style of gameplay that has drawn over 30 hours from me in the past few weeks. This game never feels repetitive thanks to its basis on an untouched and unique gameplay element: improvisation. With any normal heist, plans aren't meant to always work out, and spaceship heists are no exception. My experience was always built upon falling into bad situations and attempting to pull myself out, whether I'm unsuccessful or not. If you're a fan of sci-fi games: buy this game. If you're a fan of strategy games: buy this game. Hell, you should buy this game no matter what you enjoy, I can guarantee you'll love it.

36481606.review:
Heat Signature is a lot of things, but the best way I can describe it as is a huge sandbox.  You have goals, but you don't have to do them if you don't want to.  You have missions, but you can accomplish them any way you want.  Even the character you play as doesn't have to complete his personal missions, sometimes things don't get done.  You instead are set loose into this world of spacestations and ships, and you learn to use the systems.  At first, its going to feel simple, then as you learn and can get to the harder missions, you will see the number of options given to you.  The best way to learn of each tools usefulness is by completing the little defector missions that appear. Besides that, just experiment or more than likely you will accidently stumble upon it and it will kill you.  This is a bite sized experience that you can seriously dig into.  One thing about it though is when you have unlocked the more advanced gadgets, its very easy to find a good combo, and never use anything else.  I wish the late game did more to force you too challenge yourself.

36461980.review:
Heat Signature is a fun game for I'd say the first 5-10 hours. It gets very repetitive towards the endgame and only becomes fun for your average completionist, and even if you are the completionist, the achievements are quite easy.

Story and Lore:
There are 4 Factions. Offworld, The Foundry, The Sovereign, and the Glitchers. Your goal is to liberate the different nodes in each of the faction's territory, ultimately liberating the stronghold of the faction. Liberating nodes is quite simple, really, do missions, gain enough progress to liberate the next node. Other than that as the main hook of the story, there isn't anything much else. Characters come with personal missions, steal this, rescue him, kill her, and that's really the only thing about the characters that is unique, aside from the randomized starter gear. You can find a few NPCs to talk to after liberating a stronghold that provide a background on the inner workings of the Faction, but not that much.

5/10 Story.

Gameplay:
Hotline Miami, but with slow motion, and in space. You get a mission from the missions board varying in difficulty, and will pay more the harder it is so that you can purchase more gear for your character. Then, you get in your pod, fly to the ship, and lock on. 

Once you're inside, you have to complete your mission. You can pause time and make whatever preparations you need to while paused. While learning it, it's very interesting, as the feeling of killing many enemies at once in one room using only a few wrenches is nice, but after playing the game for a bit, it again gets very repetitive. Pause, hit, move on.

There are various things to help you do your missions, teleporters that only work if there's an unblocked path from your character to your destination, teleporters that swap you with another person, and teleporters that bring you to your destination temporarily. There are things that make you invisible, make you 5x faster than everything else, give you a shield. There are only 3 types of guns, with a few characteristics making them unique. Basically, there's not a lot of gear yet in the game.

7/10 Gameplay.

Summary:
Sorry, I suck at writing reviews.

But as I said in the start, it's fun for a while, but get's very repetitive, not much else to do aside from the same old missions on the same 4 faction ships varying in size. I would only recommend getting this if you aren't limited to a small budget, like me. It's a nice quick fun experience but I have a very limited budget for steam, so if you have like, 5 bucks or something, save it up instead of getting this.

Overall: 6.7/10

36371619.review:
One of the best things about this game (after short, skipable, intro): 

You load it up, you're in the game world. 

No loading screen, no menu screen, you're just sitting at the bar and ready for character select, like you never even left. Perhaps a bit strange.  . but it's one of the things that kept me coming back. It was just so easy to load up and get to work liberating the system. There's no frills - just fun gameplay.

It's been a long time since a single-player game kept me coming back like this. I think Hyper Light Drifter was the last. Some people might not like the core gameplay loop, but I did, I never got bored of it. 

Also, when you liberate the Glitchers stronghold, the girl you talk to has some really neat flavor text.
You also might even feel a bit bad for murdering Offworld Security given their philosophy on non-lethal combat and anytime you take a mission for them, you bring a non-lethal weapon.

My only big complaint is. . around an hour of gameplay or so, without fail, the game begins to drop from 60FPS to 30, then 20, then lower. Not sure what is up with that. . but. A simple restart fixes it. . and since the game just drops you in. . it's only a mild annoyance -- but should be fixed.

I'd love to see more variation in ship design and maybe even space stations for some additional variation, rather than just constantly attacking ships.

It's also hard to tell which environmental objects may give you cover (which you figure out eventaully ). . but some sort of lighting system would help that.

I was also a bit surprised that bumping into a target ship doesn't trigger any alarms. That'd make that aspect a bit more engage. Maybe some ships would and some wouldn't, etc

I could talk further about the gameplay (there are probably loads of reviews for that) but there are some other reviews for that, this were the small things that stuck out to me.

36352243.review: game is fun, lots of ways to take down ur enemies, heck yea

36333970.review:
I'm not sure that I can recommend Heat Signature quite enough. 

Get it. Play it. Play it more. Crash through everything until you are frustrated and die frequently and lose and retry and DO think about the story of your character.

It's not a broad, sweeping, epic. It's not a hundred thousand word professionally voiced cut scene enhanced sweeping tale. It's straight forward. What are you trying to do? Kill the guy that tortured your friend, rescue your son, steal the thing so you can retire, etc. 

Some of those might hit a nerve. Rescue your son was the one that got me. 

After a lengthy, desperate, poorly planned incursion in which I exhausted all the resources I had brought along just getting TO my son and preventing the ship from leaving, I was pinned in with him, unconscious, facing a dozen armored, shielded enemy with nothing to fight them. 

Using the natural game mechanics, I blasted us through the hull into space and with mere seconds to spare caught him with my pod by remote, and then myself. 

I'll admit, my eyes were a little wet by the time we got back to the station.

A game that can naturally create emotional situations and desperate encounters, that does so without heavy scripting and lots of dialogue and voice acting, is really special. For that reason, I suggest you get it, play it, feel free to suck at it, and see for yourself. 

Heat Signature really is something special.

This is like a zoomed-out Hotline Miami, with weird sci-fi items and some vague semblance of a plot.

It's top-down view, you infiltrate/storm enemy ships made of a grid of rooms, with the intent of doing some particular mission.  The missions are basically always kill someone, knock someone out, rescue someone, or steal something.  You open a few more options later on.

It's good fun, and it has an interesting feature where your guys who get caught can be transferred to your steam friends' games and they can try to rescue them and finish their story as well.

All in all, a good time.

36274606.review:
Heat Signature is a classic example of a "programmer game" -- it's full of things that sound REALLY COOL in theory, and were probably incredibly fun to implement, but after the novelty wears off you realize they don't actually engage very much with the player's decision-making process. Missions quickly get repetitive, gimmick solutions you've done once or twice are generally not difficult enough to execute for them to stay interesting afterwards, and the grind gets even less tolerable when a character dies and you get to start from (mostly) scratch.

People have compared this game to Hotline Miami, but it screws up one of the most essential things Hotline Miami got right. In that game, when you die, you INSTANTLY get to try again. No loading screens, no fuss, nothing. In Heat Signature, if you screw up in a mission you get knocked unconscious (and thrown out an airlock if someone finds you in time) a process so slow that the developers gave you a fast-forward button to make up for it. Something very similar applies if you succeed in a mission -- you either have to fly the captured ship home (which can be done on autopilot, but still takes time) or manually pilot your pod home (which takes time and attention towards the end since you have to decelerate to dock.)

I suppose it's possible that when you get much deeper into the game than I am now there might be some purpose to this downtime -- maybe people come and attack you while you're in transit. As it stands now, though, it's just completely pointless delay between action sections I'm not completely happy with in the first place.

About 8 hours in and am still really interested and of course I'm finding new things. To sum it up quickly for you this game will get boring if you don't like to experiment. This game is really just a sandbox that you should experience by experimenting with weapons and tools to try and figure out how you want your objectives completed. I believe there's 4 ship styles which is pretty cool but I hope that Tom will continue to support his game with new content. So far he's put out a good image by adding the small halloween update so hopefully he keeps supporting this game and trys new things. The music isn't bad by any means but there's not enough tracks and a couple of the tracks just aren't that inspiring and feel like they're missing soul and creativity, though there still are good tracks. Gameplay, obviously the important one, is good. The item system is nice and the only thing that differentiates an experienced character with a newer one is what items you have. Perhaps more RPG elements would help this game? I am not sure. The story is basically a sandbox as well since you choose who you want to play as, funnily enough if one of your guys gets captured while trying to save his sister you can end up playing as the former's partner and try to rescue your partner that way he can rescue his sister. 

Overall this game is doing something new which regardless, deserves recognition for. The gameplay is satisfying and you really need to experiment to truly experience this game. The visuals are nice and the characters breathe and act human if you pay attention closely enough. The music can be improved and I hope more content is added in the future for the longevity. $15 is a little steep IMO for this game so I'm hoping that Tom continues to support this game so players will be inclined to keep this game or purchase it for the first time. As of now I'll give it a 3/5, It's definitely above average especially for an indie game and it sets itself out with awesome gameplay and good ideas, but it just needs more content from the dev. I recommend.

People that liked games like Hotline Miami, Gunpoint or Ronin will probably find some decent fun with this title too.

There is very little going on story wise or variation in gameplay, basically you'll keep doing what you do in the first missions. Just on bigger enemy ships, with more and more additional mission success conditions (i.e. killing no enemy crew) and as you liberate more and more stations a bunch of fancy toys to play around with.

At the beginning you might die quite a bit, once you get used to the game it gets rather easy. The always available pause function helps a lot too when you find yourself in hairy situations. Don't get too atached to your player characters, you are expected to retire them after they have a bunch of missions under their belt (and lots of cash for superior gear). You don't have to do that of course but the more missions a character does the more useless they become for liberating more stations  (and therefore unlocking more gear).

Bonus points: Devs really care about this game, there have been many patches since launch (although if balance choices were always the best is arguable.

Last but not least over Halloween ships with skeleton crews are literally run by skeletons and if one of your characters die they become a playable skelington instead!

36134118.review:
This game has a lot of the things I like about roguelikes (procedural generation, emergent gameplay) and none of the things I don't (permadeath resulting in hours of progress lost).  Technically, it [i]does[/i] have permadeath, but it's not the game-ender that it is in most roguelikes.

As you complete missions, your character generates fame which allows you to liberate new stations and thereby unlock new items in the shops.  When you inevitably die or get captured, sure you lose that particular character and all of the items on them, but your liberation progress and all of your unlocks remain.  Once I got used to that and stopped worrying so much about losing any one character, I started enjoying the game a lot more.

One piece of advice: [b]play the defector missions[/b] (click on an already-liberated station from the liberation screen).  These are the game's "puzzle mode"--you're given a specific loadout to accomplish a goal and unlimited, consequence-free retries.  By their very nature, these missions make you learn new ways of handling situations, or show you loadouts you never would have considered before (e.g., silenced automatic rifle + slipstream).

I can highly recommend this game to anyone who thinks the concept sounds even a little bit cool; I went into it thinking it would just be "ok-cool," and it exceeded all expectations.

36091229.review:
Gameplay is super fun, the pause mechanic gives you time to think about what your doing (and do it) without needing godlike reaction time, it makes the game nice and relaxed as long as you remember to pause, but it doesn't take away from the action and badassery. 
It's also pretty fun how quickly things can go downhill, but how you can almost always recover as long as you think hard enough, sometimes the game plays more like a puzzle game than a top down shooter. Minute-to-minute gameplay is probably a 10/10 for me. There aren't a lot of ways it could be done better.

The game has some flaws too though, stealth can get kinda boring when you play it too safe, if you don't take some risks you're basically sitting around waiting for enemies to walk off from their group so you can clunk them and drag their body off, then rinse and repeat 'till the ship is empty. But you can always just ignore that playstyle. 
The game can also get kinda repetitive since there's almost no story and you're basically doing the same thing (infiltrating ships) over and over again.

TL;DR gameplay is almost perfect but the game can get repetitive. 8.5/10

36087784.review:
Had to come back and edit this review - this is quite a good game for the price. 

Before I couldn't recommed this because after a few post-release patches, all of a sudden this game suffered from intolerable slowdown \ framerate issues. A google search and some tinkering resolved that, though. (If you are having slowdown problems that go away after restarting the game, this worked for me, set the SleepMargin value to 15: https://steamcommunity.com/app/268130/discussions/0/1496741765123664804/ )


My only complaint is that there really isn't much depth to this game - you see everything it has to offer in the first few hours (every enemy type, every item type, etc) and the procedurally created environments seem like a bit of a shortcut around the developers creating thoroughly thought out maps. I think at least for the defector missions they should have created static layouts that challenge the player. If you get a layout in a defector mission that is particulary difficult, you can just restart endlessly until you get an easier layout. 

But anywho, this is quite a brilliant game. The developers dump you into this world of violent space piracy with only minimal training, kit and cash, and thats the brilliance of it. I'm almost 40 hours in (and nearing completion) and I'm still learning new and creative ways of dealing with the obstacles put before me with the equipment that I have on hand. As you go on you get much better at doing more with less, and coming out victorious from an enemy ship with a loadout that you couldn't imagine taking on this sort of a challenge with before is rewarding and fun. Its simplicity is what forces you to find increasingly creative solutions

Not the most complex or deep game ever created, not by a damn sight. There is no Triple-A story to follow or top-end graphics, but it isn't being sold for a Triple-A price either. Its simple, but still a whole lot of fun for the right gamer. If the developers come out with an expansion with new types of enemies and clauses I'd buy it without thinking twice.

35971617.review:
Amber Gyasi is an old hand at infiltrating ships, but she's never faced a challenge quite like the Offworld ship she's about to jump onboard. The client is adamant that no-one see or be harmed and that Sojourn Monoceros be taken back into custody. Amber doesn't ask why, not when this much acid is offered.

Docking the breaching pod into the ship as quietly as possible, weaving through the detector arcs of the defensive guns, Amber slips through the airlock and immediately activates her slipstream device, her perception functioning at 10 times the normal speed as the rest of the world turns to slow moving putty. A couple of guards in a nearby huddle start to raise their heads to look at the blur of motion they can see but Amber will be long gone by the time they get over to the airlock to find nothing amiss.

Rounding a corner Amber has just enough time to see the automated turret before slamming on her trusty stealth shield, cloaking her in shadows rendering her all but invisible from the front. A second group of guards are standing by the turret, both equally oblivious as she hugs the walls, snatching a key card off one of their belts before slipping backwards through the door they were guarding. 

Her onboard HUD flashes up a local map interfaced with the ship internals - there's some valuable loot in a crate guarded by more turrets and guards up ahead, with no-one inside. If only she could walk through this bulkhead she'd have it made - and so she activates her Visitor teleporter, appearing in the room and quickly opening up the cargo container to grab a key cloner - this could come in handy. She only has a second to appreciate the find before the Visitor abruptly yanks her back to her previous position.

Enough with the side objectives - the target is in a room up ahead with three innocent guards and a turret. Amber swallows and readies all her gadgets - this is going to be tricky. Activating the slipstream and stealth shield, Amber fires up her Visitor and appears behind the target, almost directly on top of him. She slams a prepared glitch trap set to outside the ship and backs up, trusting to the Visitor and Shield to keep herself safe as she directly interfaces with her breaching pod remotely, detaching it from the ship. A couple of seconds of intense piloting later and Sojourn is unconscious, secure inside the pod and restrained by the catching mechanism.

Right. Now how do I get out of here?

-------

Heat Signature is an amazingly addictive little space roguelite game where you get to, with ample use of the pause function, act like a ninja obsessed with futuristic toys or a gun toting lunatic breacher who leaves a trail of bodies in his wake. I highly recommend it, especially for the price!

35930727.review:
To put context into this: I'm a bit of a curmudgeon when it comes to games. I've sunk hundreds of hours into the flash version of Binding of Issac, and then I sank hundreds of hours into Binding of Issac: Rebirth as well. Once upon a time I had a 10% ascension rate on nethack.alt.org which is not record breaking, but not too shabby either. I either really, really love games, or drop them after a couple of hours, and whereas I used to think how much I like a game was based on it being hard or action based one of the things I value above all else is how consistent the rules are and if I have the tools to bend them so I can succeed.

With that said, I can say (with my very particularly tastes and my very particular expectations of a game) Heat Signature is absolutely a hands down great game. The title looks at first like Hotline Miami, a top down twitch shooter, but the pause mechanic in Heat Sig allows you to do arbitrarily complex actions from the pause screen. Given the opportunity to deliberate, choose a course of action, and carefully execute it without the stress of live action makes the game play almost like a puzzler when the shit hits the fan- which happens on almost every mission.

It reminds me a [i]lot[/i] of Nethack where you're thinking between turns in the face of assured death- however Heat Sig seems as though the entire game was made to be built [i]around[/i] moments of assured death and trying to escape them, rather than games like Nethack that just [i]have[/i] plenty of moments of assured death where the lucky, brave, and exceptionally knowledgable can sometimes can eek their way through.

The creator has described this game in the genre of "Things Going Wrong", and I've also heard him describe the ideal situation in a game as a "Salvageable Catastrophe". Nothing plays with your emotions more than being completely screwed and seconds from capture or death, only to end up making it out alive by hook or by crook. And sometimes "crook" means accidentally blowing a spacecraft in half so you only have to deal with the smaller, more manageable half. Or hell, intentionally doing it, it worked out fine last time and your hands are sort of tied.

I also called out the original Binding of Issac because the original flash BoI had a very restrictive set of rules that governed it, but an expert in these rules could play them off each other and achieve almost any goal by manipulating them directly. My go-to example of an expert tearing that game apart is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dGhjlGPzT0k, where the game world's opportunities are wide open and careful deliberation allows him to tear the game apart to his advantage. There's the [i]game[/i] of shooting enemies and getting powerups, then there's the [i]metagame[/i] of maximizing your ability to get power ups and items.

In Heat Sig the metagame isn't quite this intense (if the game relies on hidden rulesets for item pools, then I don't know it), but the game mechanics allow for [i]exceptionally[/i] creative problem solving to circumvent enemies or problems on their face through a careful manipulation of the game world. The [i]game[/i] is about shooting enemies and capturing bad guys, but the [i]metagame[/i] is about warping the game world to make this easy. This includes a variety of things I've done on purpose (assassinating the pilot so the ship I'm on can't dock at an enemy base and capture me along with it) to and endless number of things I've stumbled on by accident (the aforementioned tearing a ship in half mid-fight, the remaining enemies flew off into the distance and I could pilot the smaller half back to a friendly base as there was no one left to fight on it). The game rewards creativity exceptionally well, and only a few times have I thought "maybe this will work" and been disappointed, and I was usually disappointed because the off the wall tactic worked too well and obliterated the guy I was trying to capture or send my rescue-ee off into deep space too fast for me to go and catch him.

In short, I am really taken with Heat Signature and advertise it to anyone who will listen. There are a bunch of other great mechanics that are worth investigating on their own for how they work just so well (the permadeath mechanic, timed levels, the limited inventory space vs the variety of enemy types, and the tradeoffs between teleporter mechanics), but suffice to say I just powered through my first galaxy and will be back to play a second galaxy. I seriously hope an expansion is a planned or in the works, because the game feels like it scratches the surface of what a well realized set of game mechanics can be used for.


Addendum:

I forgot to mention the cons to the game, which any good review would give. The first and biggest drawback is that some of the space ships you find yourself on have amazingly busy tilesets visually, and that makes it very hard to identify what is going on and where enemies are. My first sit down with the game I actually had to take a break because my eyes started hurting trying to parse the glitcher ship tilesets- I may be a wimp about this with my ageing eyes but this should probably be looked at.

Another notable issue is that there is a memory leak somewhere, and the game will slow to a crawl after hours of play. It's a testament to the game that despite individual levels being 10 minute spaceship hijacking vignettes, a memory leak that shows up after hours of play is kind of a big problem. Closing the game and re-opening clears it, but seriously. This isn't amateur hour, this detracts from an otherwise stellar game. The game stutters when you return back to an asteroid, so I'm guessing the interior never gets cleared from memory collectly but re-loaded on each return.

The last element is that the larger main story and the "Galaxy" itself feels like it needs a better narrative. The small procedurally generated storylines of missions don't hook into at the larger scope of the "Galaxy" much at all, and the disconnect is disappointing when you sink 30 hours over 2 weeks into the game (cough).

To add a final note to the matter of the main storyline, [spoiler]the game ending is very disappointing. It ends with a sort of "but you did all that work for nothing" twist that is clever, but it also is akin to a disappointing ending you shouldget get on easy mode with better endings available once you've completed the game on Hard. The game offers no evidence that this is the case. I'll probably go through the process of trying again, freeing all the asteroids, and then actually following through and completing all the defector missions. I hope by that time, if completionism isn't rewarded at present, that some sort of better ending is patched into the game by then[/spoiler].

35927761.review:
Heat Signature is set in a region of space where four factions are at war with each other. Over the course of the game, the player controls several different mercenaries for hire, who are working for an independent client, trying to liberate space stations from the control of the factions, with the ultimate goal of ending the war. Each of your characters also has a personal mission, which could be getting revenge on someone who hurt a family member, or stealing a valuable item to pay off a debt.

After accepting a contract from the mission board of a friendly space station, you’ll pilot a small shuttle through space, and dock with a larger spaceship. You then control your character from an overhead perspective, as you wander around the spaceship interior towards your objective, fighting or evading enemy guards along the way. Each ship has a unique, procedurally generated layout. Action is real time, but you can pause to assess the situation and make a plan.

Contract objectives include killing or capturing a specific target, rescuing a prisoner, stealing a piece of technology, or hijacking the ship (which requires you to kill or knock out every guard on board). Some contracts are given a further twist with clauses, including bloodless (don’t kill anybody), silent (don’t set off an alarm) or enigma (don’t leave any living witnesses). Failing a clause doesn’t prevent you from completing the mission, but it reduces the amount of money you earn.

If guards see or hear you they will raise the alarm, which triggers the pilot to return to base. If you're still on board when they get there, you'll be captured, but you can kill or knock out the pilot to stop the journey, giving you time to complete the mission. Some ships have turrets that can kill you, but guards will just knock you out and throw you out the airlock. You’ll then have a few seconds whilst floating in space, to remote control your shuttle and catch yourself before you die of suffocation.

If your character is killed or captured, you start a new character with no progress lost in the overall campaign. Your new character’s personal mission might be to rescue your old character, and if successful, you can play as the old character again. You can have four characters active that you can switch between at a friendly space station.

The really enjoyable part of the game comes from the variety of gadgets available for use on missions. You can either buy them from a friendly space station, or find them in cargo holds aboard spaceships. This review would probably be a mile long if I tried to list all the cool stuff you can do, but here are a few of my favourites.
-	Use a crashbeam to deactivate a turret, or a subverter to make it shoot your enemies.
-	Some guards have energy shields protecting them from all types of damage. Deactivate it with the crashbeam, or use the subverter to cause their own bullets to bounce back at them.
-	The slipstream slows time, allowing you to attack multiple guards before they can react.
-	Use the sidewinder to teleport past a group of guards, or teleport directly behind one for an easy attack.
-	The swapper lets you switch places with a guard. Swap with one who just fired at you, to kill them with their own bullet.
-	Most spaceships have several internal doors that are locked, requiring you to collect keycards, held by guards. Or, you could just use the keycard cloner to make a copy from a safe range, even if there’s a wall between you and the guard.
-	Glitch traps are mines that let you set a teleport destination for any guard who steps on it. Set the destination outside the ship, so they suffocate to death.

Some guards also have special equipment, including strong armour that can only be penetrated by special weapons, and heat sensors which alert them to your presence even if you're behind them or in another room. Some can teleport to the location of suspicious sounds and some have bombs linked to their heartbeat which instantly detonate if you kill them. There’s a strong tactical, almost puzzle like, element to the game, figuring out the best way to use your gadgets to bypass each ship’s security.

Some of the funniest moments are when your plans go wrong, and you have to quickly adapt. One time I used a crashhammer (powerful non-lethal melee weapon) to knock out my target, who I had to capture alive. The problem is, this weapon hits with so much force, my target flew down a corridor and smashed through an exterior window, sucking us both out into space. I only just managed to catch us both with my shuttle, before we died. I had a similar experience with a glitch trap, which doesn’t teleport your character, but apparently it does teleport people that you’re trying to rescue.
 
Of course, no game is perfect. Enemy AI has a few flaws. Often the best tactic to use against groups of enemies, is to ambush them one by one on their patrol routes. However, it feels strange that the other guards don’t think “hmm, that guy has been gone for a while, maybe something is wrong?”. And whilst guards will react if they see corpses, they don’t seem to react to blood stains or weapons lying on the floor. Its also unbelievable that each ship seems to only have one pilot. Once you’ve dealt with him, you have infinite time to complete the mission. You can even leave the ship, head back to a space station, buy some new gear, go back to the ship, and no other guards will have taken over flying the ship while you were away.

And although it took me 18 hours to finish the campaign, I think I’d seen everything by the halfway point. Once you’re powerful enough to eliminate one of the factions, the rest of the game is basically just repeating the same mission types over and over again until you liberate enough space stations to take out the remaining factions. Whilst those missions are still fun, I was kind of hoping for a new type of mission or a new piece of late game tech to freshen things up again.

Overall, Heat Signature is one of the best games I’ve played this year, and I strongly recommend everyone to check it out. Its easily worth a full price purchase.

35925636.review:
Soooo, Heat signature. Lots of fun, Kinda bland, Kinda fun. 
Let's go over pros and cons.

Pros:
Gameplay -> This game feels great when you're good at it. Killing everyone who stands in your path, or stealing something on a huge ship without being seen by anyone. But that Is what can bore you. If you play to win, it becomes less and less fun (This applied to me with the last hour or two). If you play to lose however, the game becomes so much better. Doing the hardest mission with just a wrench may be difficult (almost impossible) but if you are insanely lucky you might complete the mission, just.
 
Music -> I'm not that much of a music lover. But the music doesn't make me want to kill myself, sooo, it will pass for me.

Graphics -> It can run on my shit PC and still looks fairly polished. So I guess this will pass as well.

Tension -> You know when you get to a hyped up final boss in an RPG or loads of people are counting on you for something? Well I felt that way several times (especially early game) during my time playing Heat signature so far. Few games do this for me, I guess that's a plus.

Achievements -> This is the first (and most likely only) game I have got all the achievements for (I spent 4 hours getting "one careful owner). The achievements gave me a bit of a drive to play more of the game and gave me a few ideas to have some extra fun. They are quite plentiful (46 in total) and they aren't stupidly difficult (apart from one careful owner)

Cons:
Glitches -> Many glitches; Many fixes. Not sure where to stand on this one but hey. I played through the game without losing my save, or getting trapped, so I don't particularly care.

No workshop -> Grrr. If there was workshop I could easily get another 30 hours out of this game. It will most likely come in the future, but it stays as a con for now. [This could get rid of the boredom after many hours]

Boredom -> I already spoke about this earlier. If you try too much, or you play the game carefully. You will get bored (eventually). Luckily everything is here for you to have the fun you really want.

Price -> Not so sure on this one. I definitely got my money's worth but a lot of people haven't. If you can see yourself playing this game for 10+ hours go for it. If not wait for a sale or something.


Well that shall do for now. Pretty good game. Just finished it. Might go start all over again. 

P.S. If you don't buy the game I shall send 50 concussion hammers your way from my everything gun...

35878832.review:
Summary:
Good base, but lacks challenge, cohesion, and polish.

Certainly this game "scratches an itch," but it's essentially a series of loosely assembled mini-games without enough challenge or payoff.  I was a big fan of the developer's previous game "Gunpoint," and although there are some highlights in Heat Signature, it missed the mark for me even though this is essentially my favorite type of game (rogue-like space strategy).

Story:
The galaxy is at war, and your goal is to end the war by... killing a lot of people.  But don't worry, as you slowly take over the entire galaxy, no one does anything to stop you or get back at you for murdering all those people.  Or even lock the front doors on their space ships.

The personal missions of each character were a nice touch, especially if you've lost a character, since their parent/partner/etc can train up to get them back.  But ultimately, and for no apparent reason, every station is filled with cloned wrench-wielding super-spy assassins. 

The ending was interesting, and added more than I expected, but frankly it only took away from the achievement of uniting the galaxy and did not leave a good final impression.

The dialogue was good, and I particularly enjoyed the conversation with Geneva Stonelock, but in general there wasn't much use of dialogue or character development.

Gameplay:
It was fun to figure out for the first couple of hours, since the game doesn't spoon feed you the mechanics, but ultimately once I figured it out, I could beat an "audacious" mission without trouble using a brand new character.  If a character ever dies, it's no big deal, because there's no "punishment" for losing a character, and every character is destined to be "retired" anyway, and they are only unique in the items they carry.  I ended up keeping one character in reserve for the final two faction liberations, but by the second one, the deadly, teleporting, armored guards looked more like stooges trying to keep up.

You spend a lot of your time flying around meaninglessly in a small ship going between your base and target ships.  It would have been much more fun if there were any weight to this time, but the only mildly engaging element, docking, could easily be avoided with a cheap ship that auto-docks.  If there had been more docking choices, such as a second dock that was advantageous but you had to fly through ship defenses, maybe that would have been fun.  Or fuel. Or ships hunting you.  But as the game stands, you can take your time and bounce off the side of a ship 15 times and no one cares.  No one fires at you, no one sounds an alarm, nothing. 

There's no sense of urgency and you can probably finish the whole game by taking easy missions, and then doing the 4 samey hijackings to finally eliminate each faction.  I didn't go that route, because the game is actually pretty easy after the first couple hours, and then it's just a grind because you have to retire your well-equipped characters and then start all over from scratch 12-18 times I'm guessing.

The time spent in battle is quite trivial once you've unlocked the hammer.  Seriously, why are the two most powerful weapons a wrench and a hammer?  You can walk up to a group of 4 guards with guns (maybe more) and hammer all of them unconscious before they can even get a shot off.  Your hammer has an 8 meter range! 

You can also knock out a few guards and then pick up all of their guns.  Since the cooldown time applies to each gun, you can just fire gun 1, switch to gun 2, fire that one, and just keep switching as you mow down a grouping of bad guys as though you have an auto-aiming machine gun.

There are several types of missions, but the gameplay is almost always the same, regardless. Kill the captain first to stop the alarm, then do whatever.  In fact, I basically killed the captain first then took over the ship 90% of the time, because the enemy ship can automatically set a course for your base, but your ship can't for some reason, and it allowed me to skip the "now fly home slowly" mini-game.

I liked the "damaged pod" minigame, but since you can pause to see what quicktime events you need to perform, it was also trivial.

Lack of Polish:
There are lots of little oversights, especially in the UI.  I'm playing in 4k so some of that usually pops up, but these seemed like general issues, such as labels covering up objectives, or buttons overlapping each other (so for example pressing "back" may take you into a mission because there was another button under the back button and the game didn't shut off collisions on the hidden button). 

In the mission select screen, I would choose missions based on the gear I had, and the pause button is what's used to brings up your gear, but if you pause in the mission select screen it just overlays your gear on top of the missions and you get an ugly pile of unrelated text.

You can also teleport items to yourself while you're unconscious, sometimes ships collide and sometimes they don't, etc.

Conclusion:
Certainly, there are things to enjoy here, and I'm glad people seem to like it and the dev is (hopefully) making good money.  I look forward to their next game.  I just wish Heat Signature had come out 6 months later, with better combat balance, a more polished UI, a sense of urgency (like FTL's encroaching fleet), some character variation (maybe "quirks" like in Rogue Legacy or Darkest Dungeon), a better tie in for the liberation missions (where you play with an assigned set of limited gear), and a sense that anything matters.  Killing lots of people doesn't matter, skipping missions that seem to easy or hard doesn't matter, ramming your ship into another ship generally doesn't matter, getting "spaced" doesn't matter, getting captured doesn't matter, even dying doesn't really matter.  This could have been a great game, but I can't really think of a reason to recommend it other than that other people seem to really like it. 

It's my hope that the developer sees this and uses it to improve Heat Signature or a future game, although I'm clearly in the minority so maybe I'm just wrong ; p

Heat signature Where do I start with this game?

I found this game in the "backyard of steam" and I found a treasure.

This game is made by the studio that developed GUNPOINT and the studio has delivered to my expctations with the promise of a "space smuggler/Han Solo-sim".

The game is heavily inspired by their previous project gunpoint and hotline miami, adding to the mix some roguelite elements such as randomly generated galaxies, ships, missions, and the weapons/explosives/trinkets.

You play as a series of different free-agents for a rebel organization whose purpose is to eliminate  4 diferent factions, however every agent has also their own personal mission which promotes replayability and gives some meaning to the run saving a captured friend/stealing a secret weapon/complete their vendetta against someone that killed a loved one for you.

The game is played on a eagle view perspective like hotline miami and combines the madness and puzzle like rooms of such game with the tactic and slow-mo mode of gunpoint.

Beautifull music and good lore

- Cons:

Can be repetitive when you start with a fresh agent (collecting funds/weapons/trinkets for your run)

No trading cards/level editor =(  (at the time I have wrote this review 21/10/2017)

This game is great.

It's from Tom Francis, who made Gunpoint. If you've played that, it's got some of that humour, even more polish, and is at least as good.

It can be played in long stretches or short bursts, and it lends itself to a "I wonder if this will work" type of gameplay that feels especially rewarding. 

For example, with no bullets left I needed to save someone on an enemy ship, but the enemy was going to reach their destination in two seconds (capturing us both), so I teleported us to the only room with a window and baited a turret into shooting me (and the window behind me). We both got launched into space just before the enemy docked, and I managed to catch us by remote controlling my ship to chase us down before either of us suffocated.

Smaller, less dramatic versions of that type of problem solving occur all the time, and make the game good. The occassional bigger moments like that one make the game great.

35824279.review:
Fun, addicting, and at times a bit repetitive. 

Pros: Creative combos and engaging 'consequential' physics engine lead to creative problem solving, not always bound by author's preconceptions. For example, if you have a 'leave no witnesses' mission, and you've left behind a few guards you can't kill, you can blink up to a capture target, activate a stealth shield and toggle vision to bait the nearby guards and your capture target to a room. Then you can throw a wrench at the window to suck all of you into space, and with your remote control pod you can scoop up yourself and the capture target. This kind of creative problem solving is very fun, and is the soul and spirit of the game. The generated worlds and missions leads to emergent story telling keeps the game fresh longer, but at times can seem grindy. The flavor text on weapons and items is humerous and refreshing. 

Cons: AI seems a bit wonky at times. Guards on alert won't alert nearby guards, for example. The pause and swap items mechanic is intended, but leads to an 'infinite hands' syndrome, where the player can blink in, pause, subvert one guard's shields, pause, fire his gun at a target, pause, throw his gun at a target, pause, switch to longblade, pause, dash and kill with longblade, dash and kill with shortblade, pause, throw longblade, pause, and blink away all in about 0.2 seconds of game time. At first it seems rewarding, but later seems cheesy. The character dialog is uninspiring, but unimportant, so you're not forced to read through it. 

Should I buy this game? At $15, I would support buying this game.

35823062.review: An absolutely fantastic sci-fi game! You can do some of the easier missions if you'd like, but the real fun comes from the harder missions, from getting into impossible situations and finding clever ways out of them.  If you're a fan of sci-fi, you should absolutely check this game out.

35821793.review: Highly fun, deeply strategic, enough variation to support lasting gameplay and different play styles; and as challenging as you want it to be.

35802374.review:
A wonderful little gem of a game that somehow takes the gameplay of its spiritual precursor, Gunpoint, and adds tons of depth and mechanics while also successfully transitioning it to an isometric, procedurally-generated title.

HeatSig is a game about bite-sized space heists.  You pick from one of four characters who happen to be sitting at a bar in space, and take them from humble beginnings with a wrench and one other unique item to being one of the most well-equipped thieves/assassins/hijackers in the galaxy.  The game serves you up a large array of missions of varying difficulties, some with special optional objectives that increase your pay, so there's almost always something for players of every stripe, be they stealthy or aggressive.

There are some small problems, though.  While liberating stations via the galaxy map adds an element of persistence to the game, it really only affects what you can buy from shops.  You have a stash you can send spare items to, but once your character dies, so does the stash.  This is further complicated by the fact that your character can only sustain so many injuries before your survival time drops to zero, and there is no way to heal yourself between missions.  One minor mistake takes 6 seconds off your character's initial 30-second survival clock, until you hit 0 seconds and the next hit kills you.

This implementation of permadeath is quite frustrating.  The game doesn't throw so much top-tier loot at you that it would be unbalanced to be able to stash some items for your next character - in fact, it would add a sense of choice between taking your best gear with you and risking its loss, or keeping it safe for someone else in case the next heist is your last.  The other option would be adding the ability to recover your survival clock for a hefty fee.  You couldn't do it every time you got hit, and you'd have to choose between health and buying new gear, but it would ease the sting of permadeath.  Having to start a new character and farm Easy and Medium missions (there is a notable gap between Medium and Hard) just to get some decent equipment is just busy work.

Perhaps most counter-intuitive of all is that the game drastically slows your progression towards your next liberation if you play one character too much.  It seems to think that people are more interested in playing as part of a cast of geared-up characters rather than just one - but this option would only really be attractive if you could somehow swap items between characters. I'd happily build one guy for stealth, one for offense, etc., but I'm not allowed, so I might as well just hoard all my stuff on one mercenary - or at least I would, if doing so didn't literally decrease my progression speed by a massive 95% with no way to remedy this.

HeatSig is best when you're rolling with a fully-geared character, using a mix of teleportation, stealth, and melee weapons to carve up your enemies.  There's a handy pause feature as well that allows you to stop time whenever you like to consider your next move, or group of moves.  There's nothing like planning a sequence in your head in the pause screen and then carrying it out exactly as you like it - and I don't think I'll ever get tired of sucking myself into space by shooting out a window as soon as I've completed my mission.

There's also the option to complete a personal mission for each of your procedurally-generated characters.  A nice touch, and definitely something to look forward to as you progress.

Liberating space stations also unlocks Defector missions, which are played with a character other than your own who always starts with the same weapon set.  It's a little slice of Hotline Miami tucked into HeatSig, though the layout of the ship you're invading changes every time you restart, so you can somewhat cheese the Defector missions into giving you a favorable spread, though the number of enemies and their gear remains mostly the same.  Still, it's a good, consequence-free way to take a break, and more effective practice than the built-in practice mode.

All told, there's a huge diversity of gameplay stuffed into what is actually a very tight, refined gameplay loop.  It's a game you can play for ten minutes or several hours at a time and have fun for the entirety of your time.  There's no penalty for simply failing missions either, so you're really encouraged to experiment and see what tactics work for you.  With a few changes to make the galaxy seem more alive and add some more persistent progress, this could be my game of 2017.

35781629.review:
So, I read some of those incredible tall tales of heroics (or infamous stories of remarkable heists?)  in this review section and thought: Okay, sounds interesting, but what is a Slipstream? And what is this game all about?

I've read some comparisons - FTL meets Hotline Miami, for instance, which admittedly feels wrong to me, but honestly, I liked both games and I love this one, so if you, too, like both the more tactical/strategic FTL and the more rythmic, frantic Hotline Miami, maybe you'll be happy with this, too. To me, it's more like Ronin or Gunpoint meets The Masterplan with FTLs aesthetics (and a suitable space scenario). 

It's essentially a top-down shooter made for Mouse and Keyboard, with puzzle elements, random loot and heavy roguelite elements. I won't spoil the start of the story, but at some point you'll be playing as one of a number of more-or-less randomly generated characters, trying to fulfill missions to sow chaos and liberate space stations while also trying to earn money to get intel on a (also generated, character-related) personal story mission.

You do that by flying around in a pod (having a mission is optional, but makes sense) and dock that pod to the ship containing your mission objective (or other, random ships that appear around you) and then walking through the rooms of the ship, using melee weapons and guns to stun or kill members of the crew, hack or break sentry guns, unlock doors with keycards and applying a wide range of interesting gadgets, such as projectile-reflecting or stealth shields, time-manipulating devices and various kinds of teleporters to get to your objective.

You can always Pause the game and do a few things from there, such as change your equipment, check ranges and strategize, and even if unpaused the game will significantly slow down for critical moments (such as being spotted or while taking aim). Also, anything lying around (in opened crates or from downed enemies) can be instantly teleported to you for direct use. Convenient!

The controls are simple, intuitive and the pacing and feel is really great, enabling the kind of crazy antics that you read about in most reviews (and while not necessarily "easy" to pull off, they get astonishingly doable with some practice). While the game is very simple upfront, it is built relatively complex and allows for a lot of the things you'd expect (and some you probably don't!): Turning opponents shields on themselves, turning sentry guns, using airlocks or breakable windows to have people sucked into space - it's even possible to board another ship and control that and start shooting at the ship your mission target is in! And if you find yourself sucked into space - you can remote control your pod and catch yourself (and your target, if need be).

Equipment can be found on opponents and in cargo containers, as well as bought at a shop (which will gain additional stock as you liberate stations). You can only carry a set amount of equipment pieces (but you have a character-based, unlimited stash), but aren't restricted by type (so you could go all guns, or no weapons, or anything like that...). Equipment can come in various forms: Melee weapons are unlimited, normal guns use common ammo (which is tracked separately) and most other stuff has charges, either one-time charges (once spent, they're spent, and if the item reaches zero, it's gone for good), rechargeable (limited charges per mission, but refills automatically when you land on your station) or even auto-recharging (recharges during the mission). Items also have attributes such as concussive (non-lethal, required to capture people, if need be), armor-piercing, silent or some such, and modifiers such as long-range or high-capacity for some of the gadgets.

All of that, and money, is character-bound, meaning: Character dies, everything is gone - money, equipped stuff, anything in the stash. Only liberated stations remain. If you don't want to continue a character right now, you can switch between characters (but they will only have access to their own stash and inventory). You can switch back later.
Once your character has completed their personal mission and/or liberated some stations, they become too famous and less apt at liberating stations. You can then retire those characters, permanently removing them from your roster of playable characters. They get a nice plaque with their name and detailling everything this living legend accomplished (stations liberated, personal story fulfilled) and you get to pick one of their items, and a name for it, and that item (with that name, and a reference to your player name in the item text) can from there on out be found by any of your or your steam friends characters. A nice legacy.

In the end, it's a game about planning, and failing plans, and improvisation, and using all the tools at your disposal. It can be stressful, but incredibly awesome as well. It's a game of daring, audacious acts and epic wins, a game where I found myself gleefully hacking a sentry gun to kill some enemy guards, but one of them surviving and sounding the alarm (which starts a timer), then using a slipstream (time-manipulating device) and a sidewinder (teleporter that needs a clear route, however convoluted it may be) to get to the ships captain to knock him out (cancelling the alarm timer) - but alerting too many guards in the process, so now I was stuck in some corner of the ship, with some weapons and a visitor (a teleporter that can teleport through walls, but teleports you back after two seconds). So I did what any reasonable person would do: Used the visitor to teleport into a room with a window, fire one shot against a wall. Get returned to the original location, while guards swarm the room to investigate the noise. Use another charge of the visitor to teleport to just outside the room, in the hallway - I think one or two of the guards still saw me as I took aim to blow the window out. Boom. Half a dozen guards sucked into space. The mission suddenly got a whole lot easier.
