35741964.review:
GIve this game a couple plays. The first game or two I did not know what to make of it, it was all sinking in... that said:

This game is brilliant.  I've been playing games since 1984 and I can count on one hand the amount of times I've been inspired this much by a single game.  1) Xcom UFO Defense (the old microprose version), 2) The first Metal Gear game 3) Final Fantasy for the NES 4) Faster Than Light (FTL) 5) Heat Signature.   

You play a bandit/hero/terrorist/villian/assasin/person trying to get by/um... it's complicated... who boards ships, does horrible things to the crew under seemingly impossible conditions, and somehow makes it out alive.  It is all under the umbrella of you trying to "free" space stations but really who cares about that. The story takes a waaaaaaaaay back seat to the game play here. 

The gameplay: (an example)
1) take the mission, you gotta kill some dude on some ship, with very little time to do it. Oh by the way he has a shield, and you don't have anything yet to penetrate a shield.
2) fly out to the ship as fast as you can, the clock is ticking on this mission (not all missions have timers)
3) you meet and board the ship undetected, lucky for you there is a skeleton crew, but time is running out because you fail at piloting your little pod. 
4) You don't have time for keys, so you get past a keyed door by using your swapper which literally swaps you with your target. 
5) You drop two guards with your wrench and pistol, the gunshot has alerted your target who comes running at you, shield lit up. 
6) you turn with your pistol and blow out the window behind you as your target enters the room, sucking you both out into the vacuum of space. 
7) you remote pilot your pod to pick you up before you die, your target is not so lucky. 

See there are a million ways to complete a mission, you can be a door-kicker and come in like a typhoon, or you can be a sneaky little ninja who drags the bodies of his victims back to the pod leaving no trace he was ever there. 

Loot in the game is fantastic, and say you want to jump aboard a random ship that happens to be bumbling past you on the way to your mission, just to check out its cargo??? Feel free, but you may get more than you bargained for. 


This game is phenominal. One of the best games I have ever played.

Your characters' purpose in this world is to break into spaceships and capture/murder/steal over and over. Slowly gaining equipment and skills in order to complete their personal goal. Then once that is done you pick a new character and keep going.

It is amazing how much fun it is finding new ways to get around problems. Don't have an armour-piercing weapon? Try hacking the turrets. Can't get through their shields? Try stealth, or luring your target near a window and blowing them into space.

You can get a good 15-20 hours out of this before it starts wearing a little thin.

What is in the game is good. The core gameplay is fun, there are many different ways to tackle any given ship depending on the items you have, and it can be incredibly fun to try a new strategy, like completing a mission without hurting anyone by carrying around a bunch of different teleporters to avoid line of sight.
The main problem for me is that, after a while, a lot of the gameplay just kind of repeats itself. The ships don't really get more diverse, just the same structures but bigger. You will also have seen most of the item types after just a few hours of play, after which you'll only slowly upgrade those same weapons to have more ammo, range etc. This is not helped by the fact that the game actively encourages you to keep using new characters, as the rate at which you liberate systems grinds to a halt after about 15 missions with the same character.

If the idea behind the game looks fun to you, I would recommend it, just don't expect to lose dozens of hours, at least in the current version.

Why I decided to pick this game for the "Choices Matter" award:

In Heat Signature, there are many situations that can easily be dealt with, such as knocking someone hostile out, or by jumping out of a window when you realise that you can't complete the mission. 
However, there are MANY more situations in which you have to plan out something to get out of the horrible situation you have gotten into. For example:

You have taken a rescue mission. You get onto the ship and use your teleporters to get to the target. You pick up the target. You walk out of the room, screw up and get spotted. There are now ~ 7 guards with armor chasing after you with guns, and you don't have any weapons that are armor piercing. You see a window nearby. when examining the achievements, you noticed that there was an achievement for chucking a rescue target out of a window. You run to the window and proceed to throw your target out of the window, and are sucked out into space. (Along with your target, and any guards who were close to you.) You remote control your ship, and catch yourself, and the target, and proceed to your home base. 

I hope that Heat Signature gets the award.

Тот самый случай, когда sandbox не означает «ты можешь делать тут что хочешь» в казуальном смысле, но именно так играется в конкретной игровой ситуации на комбинаторном взрыве простых механик. А ещё она хороша гриндом. В ней правильный и приятный flow, с погружением в состояние, с гибкой сложностью и удовлетворяющим прогрессом. Недостатков тоже не мало: искусственный сюжет и сеттинг существующие «для галочки», никак не оформленный момент между «я понял про что игра» и «я втянулся в репитативный геймплей», превращающийся для многих в «разочарование», несколько брошенных на полпути механик, не интегрированных в процесс интересно, но всё же засоряющих интерфейс. Тем не менее, недостатки понятны, просты и не перевешивают удовольствия, если на них не зацикливаться. По сумме же [b]“Heat signature”[/b] – почти идеальный симулятор infiltration-а.

Pretty much as soon as you get decent gear on a character it's suddenly no longer any good for gaining liberation points so you need to start another. 35648874.review:
What a fantastic game (and value)!
I'm a long-time gamer who is now in his 30's and often has trouble keeping interested in new games, but I never had that issue with this.
As you've figured out, this is pretty much a sci-fi version of hot-line miami that allows you to pause and has a slew of cool gadgets.
Because the levels are randomly generated and the combination of available weapons/gadgets are usually different this game never gets boring. A few of my friends also got the game and we will reminisce over the adventure of our different characters. One cool feature is that retired or captured characters from your game can show up in your friends game, which is a great little feature.
In my opinion this game is the best value for the price out of any game I've seen on steam. I really can't recommend it enough.

35647094.review:
From previews of the game my main concern was the game would get old after a few hours, so I'm pleased to report that that is definitely not the case and I absolutely recommend this game.  I enjoyed all of the 32 hours I spent liberating 2 galaxies in order to get all the achievements. This is because the game gives you plenty of different ways to pull off impossible-cool stunts during your missions. The tools, opponents and systems enable a ton of fun creative options for you, and if you learn to use them all you'll have a great time. The writing is also witty. I especially like how the in game practice mode tells you “how to be cool” - that's exactly how you'll feel after neutralizing a room full of alerted guards through creative use of teleporting and abusing item cooldowns.

	That's the good, now for the bad. While the game does have more than enough variety, it still suffers a little from small variety related problems that if fixed, would make it much better, and get me playing the game some more.

	For example, once you've done one stronghold liberation mission, there are 3 more you need to do that are exactly the same level of difficulty even if the load-out of the enemies are different. It would be nice if the difficulty of these missions ramped up somehow, or otherwise changed. It makes me feel like I'm just doing the same thing 4 times at the end of the game. I've already done a lot of hijack missions anyway, so letting me bail out without neutralizing the entire crew actually makes them easier.

	More difference in guard kit would also be appreciated. What equipment guards can use feels really limited compared to what the player can use and the lack of variety does make the game feel a little more monotonous then it should. Where are the guards with grenades, front facing shields, EVA suits, machine-guns, heat signature masks, etc?

	I'd also like to see different responses for alerts. Right now when you alert a crew the ship just flies back to base, but there are other things ships could do, like call for reinforcements or rescue. It doesn't really seem that interesting or balanced that you can just disable a ships engines and get infinite time to do your mission (after which the ship and crew just drift, forever). The guards should be able to call for a ship to rescue them. If you hijack a ship, the faction should probably send another ship to figure out what happened to it.

	The map feels really static. Allegedly these factions are at war with one another, but you'll never see a station change hands except when you capture one yourself. This might be one of the reasons why some players feel the game is grindy.

	Every faction uses the same system of escalating security levels between the airlock and objective which just feels really weird and makes every ship feel alike after a while.

	While the game has some neat interacting system mechanics, there are a few things obviously missing. For example, you can't enter a ship by throwing yourself through a broken window, you can't shoot out a window from space, you can't use breech grenades to enter a ship from space, and you can't cross a breech from one internal section of a ship to another.

	The interface could be better. The layout is weird, with bits of important information placed on sides and in corners, where it's least visible. 

	The layout also moves things around when it really should be fix them in place.

	It seems like sometimes pressing f does the same thing pressing e does, and I'm still not sure exactly why or when.

	Graphically, the background tiles could make guards pop out a bit more. Ships are very obviously tile based and there just aren't that many tiles, leading to ships that feel really similar to each-other, even between two different factions. 

	It doesn't help that every faction shares the exact same functional parts, even if the overall shape and internal space is different. Offworld security ships could have holding cells, Foundry ships could have functioning and dangerous refinery/factory areas, and other stuff for the other factions. But nope, it's just airlocks, engines, empty space, terminals, weapons rooms, cargo rooms, alcoves and bridges for everyone.

	Don't let my list of criticisms stop you from buying the game. As long as you're creative you'll play it for at least 20 hours before getting the least bit board. It's only after that that you'll start to hope the game gets some improvements in the areas I've listed here.

35645936.review:
Pure genius. It's like Hotline Miami and Gunpoint had a baby (which makes sense, this being the developer of Gunpoint.) The rogue-lite mechanics work briliantly, and while there are a few items and strategies that are noticably more effective than others, almost every tool and tactic at your disposal is viable on its own if you use it right. But it's when you combine them that Heat Signature really shines. When you start coming up with clever ways to combine gadgets in ways that make them exponentially more powerful, massive 7-key ships that would have taken you ten minutes to tackle (assuming you survived) become your playthings as you find and learn to combine more powerful weapons, teleporters, hacking tools, bullet-time powerups and shields (as well as collect versions of those gadgets that give you more uses per mission). Learning these combinations is absolutely essential for the tougher missions that require you to do things like go totally undetected in a ship swarming with guards, or steal something from a ship full of explosives where the guards all wear explosives that go off if you kill them.

The gameplay itself is like a thinking man's Hotline, where you can pause at any time and plan your attack or try to work your way out of the sticky situation that follows when your plan goes sideways. Sometimes you paint yourself into a corner you can't get out of though, and that's another thing Heat Signature really gets right. Instead of the frustration of YASD (Yet Another Stupid Death) that's so common in roguelites, taking a hit downs you but doesn't kill you. Instead, the guards throw you out of the airlock and depending on whether you're stunned or wounded you have a short or a shorter timer to remote control your pod and snatch yourself out of space. Each time you're wounded and retrieve yourself the timer gets shorter, making for increasingly tense rescues as your survival time dwindles while your character's gear level grows. You'll probably wind up with a few characters dying on you, but far more often you'll be incapacitated on the ship while the alarm goes off and they fly to the nearest station, capturing you. But if you're captured, you get to rescue yourself as another character and get another chance to retire as a living legend.

Another brilliant bit of the game is the "defector" missions, which are infinitely repeatable, puzzle-like challenges that unlock when you capture a new station. Some of them are relatively easy (take over a ship with an infinite use teleporter and an armor piercing knife) and some of them are mind-bendingly hard (teleporter and armor piercing knife, but the armored guards are rigged with the aforementioned explosives and no one else has an armor piercing gun for you to steal.) They're totally optional though, which makes the difficulty fun rather than a barrier to progression.

I could write volumes about Heat Signature, but I've said enough for a Steam review. If the words "roguelite action-strategy" or "defenestrate yourself into space" sound at all appealing, you will have a good time with Heat Signature. It is without a doubt the best game I've played all year.

35645521.review:
very very fun for a good five or ten hours, and then tapers off with a lack of any meaningful progression (at least it feels that way) and an unfun skill tree. nothing really feels like it has any value. the space stations are only different aesthetically and provide no difference in gameplay other than being a shop or mission hub. past a certain point you just feel like youre doing missions for the sake of doing missions, and the modular design of ships feels very random and thrown together and there never seems to be any coherence to any of the ships. there are really very few missions and not enough modifiers (save for 'clauses' which dictate how much you get paid) that alter missions on a dynamic front. 

overall, id recommend as the dev is great and puts a lot of time and effort into what he does and it pays off, as it did with this game. its design and concept is very fresh and new to the industry just as Gunpoints was - just keep in mind at some point (unless youre a die hard completionist and love seeing things through to the bitter end) past the 10 hour mark youll hit a really hard progression wall thatll deter you from continuing the game any further.

35632612.review:
I enjoyed playing Heat Signature while I did, and may come back to it.  The gameplay is a lot of fun and I enjoy the concept behind the game.  Basically, you play one of several scoundrels who take on jobs to steal items, or assassinate targets, or hijack entire spaceships.  You start off with a weapon and an item to help you, and accumultate more along the way.  All of this is to earn money to complete a personal mission, which is generally much, much more difficult.  As you complete jobs, you also gain fame, which allows you to unlock more regions, which also unlocks helpful weapons or items.  

The gameplay loop is pretty fun for a while, but you quickly reach a point where your character only has the option to take on difficult missions, and it's hard to get items necessary to complete the more difficult ones.  I did not complete any of the personal missions due to their difficulty.  I just got frustrated with always getting too difficult missions, so I reached a point where I would intentionally get characters killed off so I could create a new one, do easier missions and unlock more of the galaxy.

But sadly, it just got a little old for me.  It was the same thing over and over, and I lost interest.  I may come back to it later.  I do recommend it if you're a sci-fi nerd like me or just want to play something different, but I don't see myself ever completing the game.

35607751.review:
At 6 hrs played I feel very comfortable calling this game good and worth your $15.00 USD.

I say this because I've had more fun and more nail bitting adreneline moments in those 6 hours than I do in many other games, even those I reccomend as well. It is rare for me to get super invested in a game challenge, but i've had my heart pounding in my chest as I barely squeeky out of a tight spot, literally jump out of my chair screaming when I manage to pull off a seeming impossible task thought a series of quick moves that were very clever of me if i do say so myself, and laugh my head off when I spend an hour meticulously executing a plot mission only to screw it up at the last second and go back in a second time to finish it off.

The game is good.

There are two mistakes that people seem to be making: Trying to just run in and wing it, and giving up after you fail. For the first, just pause a lot, all the time, in the middle of combat, pause more. Remember that you can aim things like the wrench or gun from the pause menu and it will only unpause when you fire. For the second, think of yourself as playing a movement, not playing a characher. I've had characters last 2 missions before getting captured. I've had characters that fail over and over but don't get captured (because i'm trying to play beyond my equipment, or got impatient). and after I complete a personal mission they get retired. Characters are expendable, and the game seem to throw you the better tech sooner/faster the more stations that you've captured.

35605376.review:
I just got information for my personal mission to steal a very expensive-looking thingamagob. Take a look at the mission - just my luck - huge ship with lots of guards (around 50 or so) and everyone has a shield, making them immune to any weapons unless you disable the shield with crashers or subverters. I only have 1 rechargable crasher with 3 charges - definitely not enough to clear the ship of guards. 

With progressive clearing of the ship from opposition out of question I resort to stealthy approach: using 2 high capacity rechargable stealth shields and 1 self charging slip stream which I just won from a mysery crate I carefully maneuver around the guards, pickpocketing keycards right in plain view of their teammates. Managed to walk all the way to the middle of the ship without alerting anyone and got next to the pilot. I'm thinking: hey if I knock this guy out there will be no alarm response and thus no risk of getting captured or ship getting away. The only weapon I have at this moment however is a very loud automatic stun gun. Failing to realize that I'm about to alert half of the ship guards I disable the pilot's shield and shoot him off his chair. 

Guards come converging at me from all directions having their shiny shields I can't disable and about to hand my ass over to me on a platter. Using stealth shield and splitstream I manage to sneak my way out of the charging guards only to realize that one of them, standing in the middle of the resulting clusterfk has the keycard I need to progress further. Coming back to him is suicide - other guards won't let me near him to pickpocket. 

That was the end of a quiet approach. In order to progress further I would need guards from other side of the locked door to open it for me. And so I took out my trusty fully automatic stun gun and made some noise. Guards came charging through the locked door keeping it open just long enough for me to slipstream through under cover of my stealth shield, and using the pause to defly grab the so much needed keycard from the guard at the back of group. 

That was the end of it - my target was just behind the door I had keycard for, so I grabbed it, and fired one last shot of the stun gun - trough the window. Picking myself up with the pod before suffocating, I successfully stole the priceless thingawhatsit and was able to retire in peace, passing on my automatic noise maker to future generations.

35604482.review: This is one of the most fun games i have ever played :)

35604475.review:
Very cool little rogue-like. You start out in a bar with a selection of four randomly generated characters with semi-randomly generated personal missions you work to achieve (I.E. "Capture the X that killed/tortured my Y", "Steal X to pay off a debt", "Kill the X who Y'd my Z", etc.) which will allow you to make one of that character's items an "heirloom" that you can name and find with subsequent characters (or that your steam friends can find). The main goal of the game is to capture the Strongholds of each of the major factions found in the game, those being-

Sovereign: An intergalactic megacorporation looking for nothing but profit
The Glitchers: Teleportation obsessed space pirates
The Foundry: Asteroid miners who built all the stations you'll be taking over
Offworld Security: Space Cops who don't kill. Ever. (Even though they love to throw people out of air locks)

After you take enough stations from a faction (earning permanent upgrades along the way) you'll have a chance to hijack a faction's siege ship and send it on a suicide mission to take over that faction's stronghold. And that's pretty much the main "goal" of the game. However, that's not what it's all about. It's really all about the stories you make during your gameplay. Using the active pause function, you can plan out every move you could want to make second by second (or go all Hotline Miami and never pause once) and systematically rip rooms apart as (in)efficiently as possible. For example, say you were spotted by several teleporting armored guards equipped with energy shields and OH NO! You don't have any AP weapons or ammo, and you JUST ran out of shield subverter charges! Not to worry, THROW A FUGGIN WRENCH THROUGH THE SHIP WINDOW AND SUCK THOSE MOFO'S INTO THE VACUUM OF SPACE!  What's that? Now you and your capture target are hurdling through the cosmos at relativistic speeds? No problem! Remote control your breaching pod and pick the two of you up before you die alone together in the cold unfeeling void of space. 

The only thing that could make this game better is if workshop support were added. We've already managed to create a browser based save editor for making custom characters, but it isn't quite officially supported. Overall, I would honestly consider this a strong contender for Game of the Year.

35591964.review: Fantastic game. I've never seen anything like it. I like the developers and I like the gameplay. As for story, it writes itself as you'll see by many reviews with tragic and/or heroic stories made by players. The real fun of this game really shows up when you've mastered the mechanics and get yourself into/out of crazy situiations with nothing but wit and a few accidents. Some say it gets old after the start, but those who think so are missing out on the core of this game. The core isn't the wild stories or the head bashing breaking/entering action. The game doesn't limit you by skill (as you'll see by the pause menu and actions) but it challenges your mind with out of the box puzzles and workarounds that the developers have the game organically generate. 9/10 game.

35585746.review:
(There's a story at the end if that's your thing)
If you know how to play the game, the hardest missions are still possible. Sure, they might have Energy shields and armor, but you can disable shields and penetreate armor. Yes, it's hard to take down a shitload of people that all have shields, but you don't really need to. You have stealth shields and your own emergecy energy shields, breach grenades and EVEN MORE slowmotion. Difficulty isn't the problem, for me at least. Even without the proper tools you can still push the kitted guards around, or knock them in to the void, or blow up the room they are in. It's not easy, but you can always overcome the obstacle. Here, have a list.

Timelimit-Kill the pilot, or destroy the engines
Shields- disable them, knock them into space, sneak by using a gadget, or just steal the keycard without killing them
Armor-Armor piercing weapons, and everything mentioned straight above
GUARDS EVERYWHERE- Stealth shields or whatever they're called, energy shields, or being a pure badass and using all of your weapons at once, seriously, switching weapons takes no time and you can throw almost anything

As for just general fun shit, I REALLY like the concussion hammers, and slipstreams (Basically even more OP slowmo)
The hammers will either knock the enemy out, or knock them really far back. The slipstreams are really good for taking out an entire spaceship worth of guards all running at you, best paired with a super shotgun.

I think the game's pretty fucking good. It drops down in fun level after the first 5 or so hours, but it's still really fun, and contrary to many of the negative reviews, it's not actually hard if you unlock some of Sovereign's Tools and gear before you decide to go and throw yourself at a "Mistake" level mission. (remember, stores are a thing in each station. The more you play, the more stuff available)

Ok, now I'll share some stories!
I was performing a characters personal mission. I had to go through a giant sovereign ship filled with guards, to avenge a fallen loved one. ALL Enemies had energy shields, so I brought 3 crashbeams to take out shields. 2 had 3 uses, and the other only had two. I used them wisely, sneaking throught the ship, usually lining up guards and taking out two shields at a time. I made sure to only kill the guards that NEEDED to be killed, so I could maximise my distance with only 8 crashbeams, taking out the occasional group in a flurry of silenced shots and blade strikes. After a while, I realised I COULDN'T make it. I didn't have enough crashbeam uses left to get there. I pressed on though, with hope that I could make it, I HAD to try. I took out another group of people, but one shouted INTRUDER! and shot me. My time was now cut in half. I was out of crashbeam uses, and being carried towards the airlock unconcious. They threw me out, in to space. I had 12 seconds to catch myself with my pod, (Via remote control) or bleed out and suffocate in space. I cought myself with 6 seconds left, which meant next time I was thrown out the airlock I'd only have six. Back in my pod, I rushed towards the airlock, to try and reboard the ship just so I could take out it's engines and disable it to give me as much time as I needed. Before I re-docked however, I flew too close to the ships window. A guard saw my pod. They knew I was out there. The guard manning the missiles, also knew I was out there now. My pod got shot, but I repaired it. Of course, my pod was still damaged, and even running on limited emergency fuel, but flyable. I redocked, using as little fuel as possible. Then, I used my silenced shotgun to take out all of the fuel tanks, located in the back of the ship, right next to where I docked. The guards heard this so about 4 were sent to kill me. I did not have 4 crashbeam uses left. I had 0. But, by the time they got to me, one tank was still left, and I shot it as they walked into the room. the next 3 seconds lasted an eternity. the entire room was going to blow, and the only way out was threw the guards. That didn't matter though, because even if the room blew up with me in it, as long as I wasn't shot, I'd have about 30 seconds of oxygen to catch myself again with my pod. If I was shot though, I'd only have 6 seconds of blood before I passed out and died in the void. Ok, now just a tiny break from dramatic story telling: I was writing this part thinking I ended up dead, THEN, I remembered, that was from another story. So, in this one, it doesn't kill me. I was remembering ANOTHER, similar, but different missiong I played. So I DIDN'T get shot, and had thirty seconds of Oxygen to catch myself. 35585507.review:
One of the very first characters I played as was Proxy Jumals, a mercenary space Marine who specialized in kinetic breaching of ships.  I would often use grenades and unsilenced weapons, prefering to set up ambush funnels and traps, and stealthily clearing a ship to the point that I could turn the rest of the ship into a Home Alone style death-maze until I could take command of the bridge.  

As the old saying goes, "there are old mercinaries, and bold mercinaries, but there are no old bold mercinaries," Proxy was killed when a missed shot sailed over her shoulder into a fuel barrel and ejected her into space, beyond the reach of my pod.  

Heat Signature is an awesome game that combines great elements from games such as Faster than Light (FTL) and Hotline Miami to create an incredibly interesting mix of real time reactions combined with thoughtful tactical consideration.  

The weapons and abilities in the game are a mix of fun and interesting ways to adapt and overcome the tactical challenges presented in visitng, boarding, searching, and seizing ships.  
The rogue-like elements are a fun and interesting way to add depth to the game, in the sense that you can come up with the backstory of all the various characters in the rogues gallery of revolution.  With each new character that I played, I imagined a backstory based on the starting weapons they would carry and would often role play that character until their capture, death, or retirement.  The multitude of ways to solve the tactical challenges presented in the game allowed you to play the game however you wanted.  

I definitely recommend this game.

At this point I can pretty reliably beat the difficult personal missions with a very fresh character, or even as the first mission if I've saved up enough liberations.

35575627.review:
I’m busy with life things and so don’t always have a lot of time to play games, let alone write reviews (this is my first proper Steam review). At the time of writing I’ve put 13 hours into Heat Signature, which is a lot for me; the game has grabbed my attention like no other has for a long time. 

The game is built around an entertaining core with its ship-heist mechanics; the sheer quantity of gadgets and weapons means that there are tons of unexpected ways to succeed, and fail. It just feels great in the hands.

I also find myself drawn to the role-playing aspects, which is not something I expected. With no scripted narrative to follow, the game becomes about the individual stories of the procedurally-generated characters you take charge of, each with their own look, ship, starting gadgets, and personal missions (a bit like the ambitions in Sunless Sea). All this is wrapped up in a procedurally-generated galaxy unique to you, which your characters are collectively working to liberate, one space station at a time. You see, hijacking a ship and completing its mission (assassinate, rescue, steal, etc.) fills up the “liberation” gauge, which upon filling allows you to annex an adjacent station belonging to one of the galaxy’s factions, into your independent empire. I presume “completion” of the galaxy comes once all these stations are independent, at which time the galaxy could be regenerated via the menu option; but completion really isn’t the point here I don’t think.

It’s all about the stories that emerge from your antics role-playing the many characters - one wants to rescue their husband, another wants revenge on the person that killed their sister; all characters have some form of motivation like this. So the game for me is a roguelike RPG, with stories emerging from the delightful mix of mechanics and procedurally-generated scenarios - the ultimate achievement for videogame narrative in my eyes. It reminds me of Sunless Sea in many favourable ways, but with less authored content and more gameplay mechanics; and like that game, all your characters have an affinity with one another. 

The game has an addictive “one more go” quality, meaning you always want to do just one more ship before you turn it off, because it is just so fun to play.

The ambient soundtrack is hypnotic, and I happily whiled away an afternoon playing this on my laptop with the speakers on while my wife read on the sofa, such is the pleasantness of the music and sound effects. Coupled with the beautifully simplistic and minimalist art, the game is a pleasure to interact with and spend time in.

As with Gunpoint, the developers’ previous big game, the developer seems to have thought of everything - the interface, though busy, is clear and always has the information I need to hand. The game is robust and polished throughout, with great attention to detail, as in the artistic variations between stations and ships of different factions. It seems very well engineered, and was even solidly playable on a below-min-spec laptop.

In a nutshell for me, Heat Signature is an immersive sci-fi story generator, and its content seems infinite. 

As a final note, I’ve been following its main creator, Tom Francis, for some time on social media and his personal blog. I’ve never met him, but Tom seems to be an incredibly nice, sound and honest guy, and a talented developer and writer to boot! He not only makes games but gives a lot back to the industry, such as with his GameMaker tutorial video series (and indeed if you’re interested in making games, I recommend the Supporter’s Edition, which contains early playable prototypes and documentary videos - not to mention the mesmerising soundtrack). I am very happy to support such a figurehead with my money.

35573384.review:
You messed up - got knocked out and thrown into space. Now they know you're coming, they're heading back to base and you only have 16 seconds to kill your target. No chance. But… you might as well try?

So you get back on board, pause, and look at your tools:
3x Sidewinder Teleporter - instant movement, but not through doors.
2x Extreme Range Key Cloner - OK, you can clone the Level 1 key, Sidewinder to the first door, then when it opens  Sidewinder through that zone too. Then, with your Extreme Range you'll be close enough to clone a Level 5 Keycard… that unlocks all the remaining doors to your target. Then:
2x Slipstream - slows down time, so you can run the rest of the distance. You'll need both of them.
1x Emergency Shield - activated as you charge in front of your target and their friends.
1x Crashbeam - disable your target's shield.
1x Longblade - take them out!

You do it! it works.

Pause. Replan. Only 3 seconds left to escape. But now the target's dead, you can pick up their gun. It's no good against the other guards - they all have shields. But there was a window in the previous area, behind one door.

1. Get back to the door before your shield runs out
2. as soon as the door opens, use your final Sidewinder to teleport to the window
3. Hold your breath and shoot the glass

A successful assassination in 16 seconds.

35564435.review:
This game is brilliant. 

The top down GTA-esque aesthetic really works with the strategic style, like a cleaner Hotline Miami. 

The pausability lends a more measured approach to difficult missions, and enables feats that would otherwise be impossible, but are otherwise very slick. A little like VATS in fallout, without the miss chance. 

There is a subtle layer of humour in the game, which are nice but don't detract from the overall experience. 

The rogue-like elements of the game give a sense of over arching progression, but you also feel a harsh loss if a character dies in the vacuum of space, without fulfilling their destiny (and you lose their cool rare gadgets). Yet, there is a sense of closure, when your 30 mission veteran is bloodied and battle scarred to the point where you can retire them, and giving them legendary status. 

The game swings between almost impossible, requiring split second (in game) precision, and no margin for error, proper planning and execution to quick smash and grabs, which in the late game give you an almost god-like sense of steamrolling an entire ship in 10 in game seconds. It depends on your mood which you choose to complete, whether it's to farm gear on a medium range ship, do some little ships for the money, or take on a large stacked ship for the challenge. There's a definite 'one more mission' addictive feel to this game. 

I don't believe the game is ever unfair in its difficulty, the mission briefs outline the risk, and the rewards are commensurate to that. One exception being armour piercing weaponry is a nightmare to find, and many personal missions require it. (let alone armour piercing non-lethal weaponry!) 

On the downside, I wish there was a little more enemy variation, and I don't know if there will be any kind of updates, DLC or expansions, so I can't say this is a complete negative. The game has not long been out, but I'd enjoy more mission objective variety, clause variety, maybe a new faction, new gadgets and guard gear. This is not really a negative, it's the sign of a great game that it leaves you wanting more. 

Controller compatibility would be a huge plus, as I think it would lend itself to the strategic style in a couch gaming fashion, I find that mapping buttons with xpadder doesn't have the right feel to it, but maybe I just need to keep tweaking it.

35563819.review:
This game is rad. Tom Francis is rad. Do you like sneaking around? You can do that. Do you like blasting into a room and smashing six guards unconscious with a wrench, and the last one flies out a window of the spaceship you're on, and you and that guard get sucked out into space, so you have to maneuver your own little ship to your drifting body to pick yourself up and re-dock with the big ship to get back to sneaking around and killing the hell out of guards and taking their stuff? You can do that, man. That's something you can do a lot of the time, actually. Plus, if you do it wrong and die, you've got a roster of plenty of other cool generated characters to choose from. If your character gets captured instead of dying, you might even get a chance to rescue your old character. If a Steam friend's character gets captured, you could even get the chance to rescue that character and rob them of the opportunity, like a true space pirate.

The galaxy is your oyster, so smash that thing open with a Concussion Hammer or use a gadget to ... well, the galaxy is already in space, but you could use a gadget to teleport it out into space if it were an enemy instead of the actual galaxy. Anyway, this game is very good. It has the "just one more mission" appeal that marks a quality quick-fire kind of game that you could pick up for just a mission, and take maybe a few minutes, or suddenly find your mouth dry, your stomach growling, your eyes red, your butt numb, and your family pleading for you to just stop playing the game already, man, it's a beautiful day outside, but you're like, "Nuh-uh, man, I want to break into more spaceships. That's my thing now."
 
If you pick up the special edition, you get all of the prototype builds too, along with developer commentary videos for each, featuring Mr. Tom Francis. Tom is also cool enough to offer advice on using GameMaker software to make your own rad games, even if you've never done any programming before, and he posted videos to that effect for free to his Youtube channel. Buying Heat Signature supports an independent developer who just wants so badly to make the game and game development communities more open, more accessible, and a more fun place to play and to enrich each other with new experiences. 

Does this sound like hyperbole? Does it sound like a paid plug? What if I told you that everything I've said here is not only true, but that I actually paid to purchase this product myself so that I could write this review honestly? Not a paid plug. No exaggeration. 

Buy Heat Signature, dude. It's good.

35556059.review:
The game has a unique concept and is very fun, but after 2-3 hours the game becomes VERY repetitive. You've basically seen everything at that point.

The AI is awful. The guards huddle up in 1 room, then if you wait a bit one of them will leave to go work in a different room. You kill that guy, wait, and then another guy will leave the huddle. Rinse and repeat.  Simply standing in a room next to the huddle and wait is ALL YOU HAVE TO DO, for almost EVERY mission. I have NEVER seen any instance where 2 guys go wander around at the same time. 

The game itself is easy. As soon as you're spotted, time slows to a crawl. It gives you more time to plan your next attack, but it's a silly mechanic because you can pause the action at any time anyways.  There isn't an option to turn off time slowing down, so this makes the game laughably easy.  You have to kill the guard who sees you before he yells "INTRUDER" and alerts the ship, but when time is SLOW you can easily kill him before that happens. I wish him spotting you played out in real time - it would force me to use pause more and plan things out better.  

The "hard" missions are only hard because they add in shielded or armored guards. All you need to do is grind to find an armor piercing weapon or a weapon to disable the shields and boom, then that mission becomes as easy as all the others.

I wish Steam had a "mixed" review, because this game is sooo close to being great... Fair price, fun concept, but seeing all the other Positive reviews with 10+ hours in the game seems misleading to me. I'm at 6 hours, which I'd say was 4 hours of mindless grinding and 2 hours of discovery and fun.  I'd rate it 4.5/10 as of now.

35552667.review:
Soooo this game is kind of a mixed bag.

Here is the good stuff:
-You can do amazing tricks when you get in to the game
-The random generation of the ships means you never know what to expect
-The combat is satisfying
-The stealth is satisfying (when it works)

Now the shitty stuff:
-Harder missions are impossible until you unlock armour penetrating weapons, and that will take you a good few hours of grinding (unless you get incredibly lucky with your galaxy, not sure if those are random as well or not)
-Personal missions have the same problem early in the game (note I am 3 hours in so far, close to 4 and I am maybe halfway to unlocking the damn armour penetrating weapons)
-The flight sucks, it might be fun as a gimmick at first with the old school asteroids flight system, but after doing it a few times it feels more like a chore than a proper fun system (to me anyways)
-The stealth system can be entirely fucked when you get a timed mission and the randomly generated ship just isn't suitable to a stealthy option, yet has a stealth clause.
-After the first hour you've seen what the game has to give, not much new is going to pop up.
-On certain ship/room types enemies blend in with the background a bit too much and it has led to kills that could have been circumvented if I could actually see them properly (hoping there'll be texture mods to fix this in the future)

Overall for the price point I still think it is a good game, It's good dumb fun and I reccomend playing it in bursts of half an hour to an hour. It's something to do during your work break. Expect to get frustrated with the grind at times and maybe rage quit when a defector mission keeps fucking you over by pure chance with the randomly generated ships.

Overall though seriously I have said a lot of frustrations but the game is fun and due to the amount of weapons there is a lot of weird shit you can do, I imagine if mods came out for it it'd be even better with new weapons and whatnot (although don't expect there to be any considering I doubt this'll be an easily moddable game)

35549045.review:
It's a fun game both for casual play and for sitting down with for an hour or two at a time. Not without its flaws, but they hardly manage to compromise the fun you'll be having.

Visuals are good, controls are simple but solid and you'll rarely find yourself doing the wrong thing despite some degree of contextual controls(which is hard to accomplish! Props to the Heat Sig dev), and the music/sound design is simple but ideal(not cluttered with too many SFX, just a solid backing track and sound effects only when you need to know something's going on).

The good is that the game has a LOT of variety to toss at you, and a lot of fun challenges. 

The only bad is that it takes a bit to start unlocking some of the variety, and it feels like adding a bit more variety to ship interiors and AI behavior would've helped make the game more interesting and a bit less predictable. Sometimes it's just a bit too easy to take advantage of the same AI behavior multiple times in a row, and until the variables start piling up, or unless you willingly challenge yourself, some of the missions are just a bit too formulaic.

Where the game really shines, honestly, is in the Defector missions, where you're given some of the game's more fun tools... but a selective variety of them, forcing you to employ some tools you normally never would(like Swappers, I mean, seriously, in most missions they barely have a point), more stealth and less violence.

The main game is mostly a stealth sim ala Dishonored or Thief, while the Defector missions are closer to puzzle missions, and they're REALLY strong.

If there's something the game lacks, it's a toolkit to develop your own pre-set defector missions and hostile ship layouts, and then to share these with others. Because there's a REALLY strong backbone for making cool missions(especially if you could alter NPC behavior while doing so), but the randomized nature of 90% of the game sabotages the potential a bit.

So, tl;dr it's a 4 out of 5 game, and I really hope the devs plan to patch in that last 1, because it feels like it's just so very close within reach. Definitely get this.

35547135.review:
Though it was a bit challenging for me to decide, I came down on the side of recommending the game. There is an awesome game packed behind many things that annoyed me.

For reference, I'm really not a fan of roguelike games which some of my frustration just comes from that design. But that's not interesting here. I do think that even if you don't really like roguelike games, there is fun to be had here.

The first major annoyance is the game is pretty bad at teaching you things or actually explaining the rules. A few frustrations:
 - The game doesn't actually tell you all of the buttons for everything. I found out about using 't' to throw a weapon and 'shift' on the pause screen to pan the camera from internet comments.
 - Timers. The mission timers starting from when you accept the mission and not when you arrive is frustrating (since travel can take 20s) and doesn't particularly make sense. So just skip the missions
 - Alarms can be stopped up to the instant they expire by killing the pilot. But leaving the ship (by your choice or getting thrown out) does not reset them. But you can re-enter the ship without any notification or visual difference that you might instantly lose your character
 - You can use melee weapons to dash at enemies, but you cannot dash away. This sometimes leads to times when you pause and see a bullet coming but cannot do anything about it.

But these area all small in the end. The fun of teleporting around, swapping with others, and just putting your tools to the test is super fun. The game feels a lot like Metal Gear Solid 5 when taking over a base. There's a lot of approaches and none has to be best, but succeeding even when things start to go wrong feels great.

For me, the best part is actually the practice area (which clicking "restart mission actually generates a new one... which is annoying for practicing against a specific mechanic...). Here, you don't have to bother with the boring and pointless travel between areas. Failure doesn't matter, just try again. Experimentation and fun is encouraged everywhere. And there's still tons of stuff to play with.

So there's fun here, but for people like me, the end of the game isn't the goal. Just playing in the practice area is super fun. I just kinda wish the rest of the game was a bit more streamlined and there were fewer annoyances to make that feel worth while to me.

35532027.review: One of my characters killed over 200 people and layed waste to an entire faction alone. Let's just say he earned a retirement.

35531343.review:
I wanted to like this, guys.  It looked to me like a blend of Monaco and an easy-to-learn-hard-to-master puzzle game, which are both my jam.

But I didn't last a full hour before ragequitting for good, so, in the interest of helping anyone else with my druthers, here's why.  

I like figuring out how things work, trying different ways to tackle a mission or solve a puzzle, understanding how things work, learning how the logic of the game world works, and trying again.  It looked like this game would work that way, but:

1) Getting TO each mission was a giant pain in the keister.  The missions themselves let you pause, let you control the behavior of your character precisely and elegantly with a few clicks, and the game carries out difficult tasks like a headshot or an 8-meter dash-and-bash all by itself -- but to GET to that part of the game, you have to control a ship careening through space at a billion miles an hour, on your own, with zero automation, with nothing but aiming your mouse, left button thrusts, right button brakes.  It is the opposite of the careful planning and meticulous execution that's waiting for you -- it's like playing bumper cars with a blindfold on.  I routinely spent longer trying to REACH my target than carry out my mission, and I hated every second of it.  It felt like a completely different game with the opposite design philosophy of the game I'd watched all this footage of.  If there were a mode that let me skip this part of the game, I probably wouldn't have returned it for a refund.

2) It is really, really hard to tell which of the tiny indistinct humans on the screen is your character.  The camera doesn't auto-center on you -- which is good, because camera control is good in games that need stealth -- but especially when you're still figuring out how to play, it means you spend way, way too much time trying to figure out which of the dudes in the little room is you ... and by the time you have, they've hurled you out into space.  Sure, you can pause at any second, but the little men are SO hard to tell apart that that doesn't help as much as you'd think.

3) You get hurled out into space.  That ... is ... well, I've played puzzle games and I've played roguelikes, and I've enjoyed both, but here's the thing.  It takes me more than literally one use of a mechanic to figure out how to physically, mechanically do it, and then I have to realize I need to.  The tutorial hurls you out into space once, so, okay, sure, the game has technically shown you how to do it.  But suddenly my character is running out of oxygen, and I need to figure out how to do something about it.  And then it turns out what I have to do about it is .... steer my pod again.  My pod.  That I just finished complaining that it was so hard to steer.  So basically your punishment for not even having started to master the precisely controlled, meticulously planned part of the game yet, is that you have to do more of the hard-to-control, chaotic, high-speed, can't-pause-to-control-this part of the game.  At this point I would just give up and let my character die because controlling my pod is very difficult.  I am not physically well-coordinated, and what drew me to this game watching LPs of it was how you could very very precisely control what happened without needing to have great reflexes.  Very frustrating.

4) THERE IS NO QUICKSAVE.  Cat just came in with a rat in his mouth?  Computer crashing?  Toddler screaming in the next room?  House on fire?  Any of the other million reasons you might need to quit this game right this very second?  Tough.  If you try to quit the game during a mission, instead of letting you restart where you left off, the game tells you helpfully, "Hey, if you quit right now, this character will die!  That okay?"  No, game, it is not.  Even when I'm playing a roguelike, and I expect I might lose all my progress at any time, a game will generally let me save and resume later in case, say, the stock pot is boiling over and I need to turn off this software for a while.  This is very basic modern game design, guys.  If I'm spending $$ on something, I need to be able to turn it off when Real Life happens and come back later without the game punishing me for it with a character death.

35528010.review:
It wasn’t looking good. My capture target was surrounded by guards, all protected by shields. I had one charge left on my shield deactivator. I managed to make my target vulnerable, then knocked him out with my concussive gun. The other guards charged me but I retreated into my pod and detached. I then docked somewhere else, fired a gun to draw attention, and then as all the guards ran over to me I got back in my pod and flew back to the first area. My target was now abandoned, and I picked him up and flew away.

Heat Signature is all about boarding and raiding ships, with various goals ranging from "kill this guy" or "steal this item" to more complex things like "hijack the ship by neutralizing everyone on board" or special missions like "rescue a hostage without being seen." There are a lot of things to help you on the way, from standard weapons to things like crashbeams (which short out all electronics they hit) several different kinds of teleporter, and much more.

There are many ways to approach any situation. Say you need an item behind a locked door protected by three guards. You could a) use a shotgun to take them all out at once, b) use a stealth shield to get past them and pickpocket the keycard, c) play the role of the horror movie monster and pick off the guards one by one as they leave to do other things, d) teleport into the room, or e) destroy the room with a breach grenade, then dock your pod to the convenient hole in the ship.

Heat Signature revolves around an at-will "bullet time" effect. At any time, you can press spacebar to pause the game. This allows you to do things like view your inventory, teleport dropped items on the ship to you, swap equipped items, and time your attacks more effectively. The game also slows down when a guard spots you or when you aim a weapon. This setup allows you to do crazy things like clear a whole room without needing lightning reflexes or a time-slowing powerup. Even if you stumble into a guard’s line of sight, you have a few seconds before he identifies you and then a few more seconds before he raises the alarm, triggering a capture timer as the ship you’re on flees. This countdown can be stopped by killing the pilot, or otherwise removing them from their seat. And if you don't like any of your missions you can go out and raid some ships just because!

The characters you can choose from have different personal missions, and have different starting gear. Each time you retire or get a character killed or captured, you choose a new character with a fresh inventory. Items do NOT carry over. Think of each character as a different save file in the same world. However, you can find "heirloom" items --special items you name when you retire a character after completing their personal mission-- in ship crates or shops. You can even find your friends heirloom items! You can also rescue captured characters and rescue your friends’ characters. Combine that with randomized galaxies to get a true never-ending experience.

This game also loves to be funny. With item tooltips like "What if grenades, but faster?" (rapid grenade launcher), to "Few guards, not skeleton guards" (skeleton crew), to "this weapon causes people to die. usually forever" (lethal weapon) and other things that will make you laugh..

This game is surprisingly solid. The only bug I have found is when you try to "jump" from one opening to another, your character spazzes out and gets placed in the airlock.

A typical mission starts in the station, where you have 4 or 5 missions to choose from. You can see each missions’ main objective, pay, and any special conditions the mission might have. By selecting a mission, you can see the guards’ loadouts and get general info about the ship, such as alarm response time, guard quantity, and any special things the ship or guards might have. After choosing a mission, you go to your boarding pod and leave the station. You have an objective marker showing which direction the target ship is. After flying out to the ship, you then must maneuver to the airlock, avoiding the ships spotlights. Once docked, the camera zooms in and you can see the entire interior of the ship. Then you must make your way to the objective. This typically consists of killing guards and taking their keycards, then going to the next group and repeating the process, however you can also pickpocket the keycard or just use a subverter on the door. Afterwards you make your way back to the pod and head back to a station. You can also smash a window for a quicker exit, or hijack the ship and fly back in style.

In conclusion, Heat Signature is a good play and a great game for completionists. It is complex enough to be fun while simple enough to still be understandable. Everything is fair and I never felt that something was unfair unless it was my own doing.

35518283.review:
7.5/10

Heat Signature is a pretty addictive number with some flaws that mostly tie to grind repetition and pretty dumb enemy AI, and balance issues.

For the most part, this game is really fun. Hotline Miami-esque gameplay with a more indepth field of strategy thanks to how pausing works and how every decision you make has to be final. The game has you controlling one character at a time during missions, however over the course of the game you will be responsible for many characters rather than one, each of whom will obtain their own gear and currency, which is where the grind starts to kick in, and where problems arise with the loot and sense of progression.

Luckily enough once you get into the flow of the game this can be quickly overcome due to how quick and easy it is to start up a new character. But my main issue lies with the unfulfilling nature of each character's progression. Obtaining rare and really useful loot is a bittersweet affair, as that character will soon be retired, and then you start a fresh new character. You can't stash items in a pool for all characters to use, you can simply leave behind ONE item that then becomes available as a rare find throughout your playthrough. This is where the game kicks you in the balls regarding any sense of achievement and just makes each new character seem like a slog.

The actual gameplay is very fun and variable, with many ingenius ways to approach succeeding in a mission. There are, however, a few issues with balance. Enemy AI for the most part is pretty stupid. The game may throw some really difficult situations at you, but the penalty for failure is relatively low. Even if you get shot on the ship, you are merely thrown out, just to be rescued via your pod with very little difficulty, until you have reached the blood loss limit where after a half dozen or so times of being shot, you straight up die, which never happened to me during an entire playthrough.

Some items, especially melee ones, are massively overpowered given the dual wielding aspect. Guns for the most part are an underpowered last resort, that are only ever useful if you wish to waive Pacifist bonuses, and don't care about raising alarms. Not to mention ammo cannot be bought, making Armour Piercing guns kinda pointless up against the more readily available restockable nade launchers and Melee alternatives. After a while, it becomes pretty obvious which loadouts are superior, and which items you should unlock for your shop. There's no real reason to not bring alone a Key Cloner, a Sidewinder and Subverters. The game may have made more sense if they had created character skill trees limiting what you could use, making the game infinitely more interesting. As it stands, you have an entire arsenal of gear come the mid game just ready to be bought, making all missions far too easy.

All said, if you like the sound of the action in Heat Signature and aren't put off by the mistakes made with the rpg-lite progression of the campaign, there is a good 15 hours to be had here.

There's a lot to like about Heat Signature: the gameplay is unique and entertaining, the aesthetics are top-notch, and the procedural generation means you'll really never play the same mission twice. 

The unfortunate truth is that you'll experience everything you like about the game within the first hour. After that, you will  likely start to accumulate a wishlist of "Why aren't there..." ideas. Some examples:

... alien races with different traits or abilities?
... cloaked enemies?
... security cameras?
... doors with retinal/thumbprint access rather than physical keys?
... "Bloodbath" or "Massacre" contracts that require you to kill all enemies?
... "Protector" or "Guardian" contracts that require you to defend a friendly ship from invaders?
... robots?
... more distinct patrol/spawning patterns for enemy troops?
... decoy beacons?
... enemies with peripheral vision?
... mind control tools?
... stations to be liberated with perks that are actually interesting?
... theft missions with an objective that you might want to keep, giving you a real choice between completing the mission or hoarding some unique loot?
... obstacles to avoid when flying between locations?

Hopefully there will be an expansion or player-made mod in the near future that will breathe some much-needed life into this game. Until then, I'd recommend holding off for now.

35489929.review:
When Heat Signature at it’s best, it’s phenomenal, but it takes too long to get there.

There’s nothing cooler in Heat Signature when you up against extreme odds and five seconds of in game time takes five minutes of pausing, planning, and executing in slowed time. You throw your wrench against the wall so the guy behind a locked door opens it. Then you pause. Switch to your sidewinder teleporter to get through the now open door. Pause. Teleport your wrench back to you. Shoot your silenced concussive gun at the one guard down the hall then run up and slice up your target before they even know what happened. Then shoot the window and jump into space.

Moments like that are the core to Heat Signature. They’re tense and exhilarating. And, unfortunately, not super common. Most missions either you breeze through or fail. Failure in this game can be pretty brutal. Often one mistake means you’ll have to abort the mission or can no longer play as that character. When you’re just starting out and don’t have access or know-how of certain equipment, this feels frustrating or too luck based. “Wait. Why’d that happen?” and “Oh… I don’t actually have anything that can deal with this right now.” Were phrases I muttered frequently until I better understood the game.

This is a game that some folks will undoubtedly love. It’s has solid computable mechanics that utilize AI randomness well, fantastic but unintrusive writing, interesting emergent storytelling, and an endless amount of procedural content. However, I found the learning curve to be too steep and the game didn’t really click with me until about 6+ hours with it. I wasn’t really expecting or have time for another 20+ experience to actually complete it.

My chief criticism with Heat Signature is its structure. There are persistent upgrades that you unlock, but with each character you’re constantly cycling through overly easy missions only to get to more difficult missions and probably die, or mess up and need to abort. You’re constantly getting set back to much less interesting content.

However when you can pull of those harder missions, it’s amazing. Some of the best gaming moments of 2017. The highs are SO high that I wish I was more excited for the game as a whole. If only it were a compacted 5 to 10 hour game with more of a focus on the emergent story mechanics. As of now, it just feels a bit too grindy and long.

The game does have missions called “defector missions” where you play a one-off character with specific gear. They are probably the best parts and are a great way to learn how the game wants you to play it. Example: I had one that started me outside of the target’s ship with no pod and too guns with limited ammo. I had to shoot backwards to push myself to the ship, get on board, slaughter everyone, and steal the ship. It was rad. But the best thing about those missions is that you can restart them at any time. Failure in them is not much of a set back, other than the ship’s layout being completely different.

As of writing this review I put about 9 hours into this game and liberated one of the four enemy strongholds. I don’t think I’ll be putting too much more time into this game. I like it, and it will likely have a fanatic community around it, but it’s just not quite what I was looking for.

If you’re looking for a good game to play with a podcast on, action-puzzle-like game, or something that you chip away at over months, then Heat Signature is a pretty solid choice. If you’re looking for something more focused, then maybe look somewhere else.

35482832.review:
My first character's life was cut painstakingly short. Having only dabbled in a few easy missions, I took my dagger assassin into a stray ship, that was seen on the way to my mission point. I entered this off to the side ship, and immediately saw several guards with guns. I was in a very wide open area, and saw some loot crates that I thought I could dash to.

Vaulting across the room, one guard saw me and sounded the alarm. No problem, I thought. I sneakily killed one guard who had a key, and jumped into the loot crate room to snag some goods. Now I just have to get off the ship.

Except about 8 guards were now surrounding the loot crate room, all armed with guns. No problem. I'll just switch places with one of them at the last possible second, and make a dash for my escape pod. I waiting for the first of the guards to open the door, and stepped to the side as he unloaded a shot gun blast. Whew. About 10 steps behind him, was a buddy guard. I used a time slow down gadget to run past the first guard, used the switch places gadget to instantly teleport that few extra spaces with the late guard, and made it to about the midway of the massive entry floor before the remainder of the guards surged into line of site and all opened fire. 

My screen was covered in spread shot, from one side of the massve cabin to the other. Even with the slow down time in place, there simply wasn't enough room to outmanuever the shots. One caught me. Okay, just avoid the rest. About 6 feet away from my escape pod, I failed to realize my time slow down was about to expire, and the shotgun projectiles suddenly resumed their full speed, and several of them slammed into me at once. Ouch.

Lesson learned. Do not attempt to explore random ships with only a dagger thinking you're Assassin's Creed skills will somehow subdue the superior defenses onboard.

Moving on, I quickly selected a new character and went back to dagger and longswording my way through several assassination type missions. Fun times. 

Pros of this Game
-Characters experience perma death, but can be retired to preserce their life time stats and achievements
-Killing is fun, and is performed in a multitude of ways, ranging from weapon types to envirenmental assistance
-Mission types are bite sized, meaning you do not have to dedicate large amounts of time to have some fun
-Stats, I personally love stats, especially kill stats. Shallow think to like but too many games forgo this
-AI is well fleshed out. I feel like I can outsmart and outmanuever any of them, but never feel safe enough as to think I can't be caught in return if I mess up

Cons of this Game
-I can see where people may not like the finite mission generation system. A lot of it is cookie cutter and with a small pool of random factors. This can easily be fixed via future updates or mod support.
-With the limited amount of overall loot and special items, it can be very easy to feel like you've seen it all after liberating a few of the stations over the first few hours of gameplay. This is not a negative, but will apply heavily to people who get bored quickly outside the game's base mechanics

Some Suggestions
-Adding some form of player rivalry
 I'd like to be able to take on a contract to beat another player to a mission of some sort that spawns in real time. First come, first serve. Or daily kill, knockout, loot, or mission complete charts that players attempt to stay at the top of to gain additional achievement listings for their characters prestige. 
-Definatly more weapons and loot. This is something that takes work, and can not be expected to be released asap, but at the moment even I can feel the innate lack of discoverable items. Not bad for me, but many others will feel distaste.
-Add missions where living witnesses eventually come back and attack your station, or try to intercept you enroute to your next mission. Would let players intentionally draw more prey, or be punished by thinking that person they let live was a good idea.
-More stats! You know we can take the knocked out bodies of our enemies onto our pod or with us when we fly their ship back to our station? That isn't reflected anywhere. My stats need to reflect I was merciful to a few, and imprisoned some as well, instead of just letting them slip back into space to continue their pirate ways.
-Multi Part mission would be cool. Let me string together a succession of selecteable missions back to back before returning to station for reward. Better stats or reward for doing so, either or would be awesome.

A great game overall! For people like me it is perfect, as I adore farming for kill stats, and always enjoy the randomly generated mission objectives, with an overall objective to reach in game.

I love it.

10/10 would shoot the glass out of the window and mistakenly be too close to it and be sucked out again

35481662.review:
The Steam community seems to have a problem with over-rating rogue-likes. Don't get me wrong, this game is good, and really fun, but 95% positive is stretching it. When I buy a game like that, I expect an amazing experience, but there's so many small changes that could be made here, to make huge improvements. I feel like it could have used longer in development before being fully released.

Firstly, the big assertion with this game is 'you get yourself into terrible situations, then figure out how to get yourself out of them'. But if you're like me, and play cautiously, that's not really how the game works. There's never a need to go out of your way to do anything you're not equipped for, you can progress through the game just fine by taking small risks for less credits.

I don't really think you would have to think hard to find your way out of situations to begin with. It takes little more than a glance to see the details of a mission and if you're properly equipped for it or not. Guards patrol by themselves, down hallways and out of the sight of other guards. Even if you run into a room with two guards, two melee weapons makes you practically unstoppable against them. The quicker they strike, the more guards you can approach with ease. Even alert and time-limits, clearly added to give the game more difficulty, are completely negated for the rest of the mission by taking out the pilot of the ship

Then, even when you do get caught and attacked, they just throw you out of their ship instead of killing you outright. You pick yourself back up, and either resume the mission or abandon it, with no real penalty. The core difficulty for this game just doesn't really exist in the way the developers assert, nor how a lot of players would like you to believe. It's more reliant on you not caring about your choices until they get you into trouble, and playing careless, or even getting yourself into bad situations on purpose.

For those reasons alone I would not recommend this to people who 'try-hard' at the games they play. It's just a massive decrease in enjoyment for people like that.

And, realistically, there's not even a huge penalty for taking the easier missions, because there's no way of knowing what missions will hold the weapons and equipment that are actually worth picking up. The weapon and equipment system is completely RNG, but not really that varied. There's a couple of melee weapons, a few guns, and several gadgets, and most of the 'rogue-like' qualities for them is how quickly they fire, the range, and how loud they are. The good ones completely over-shadow the ones that are 'meh', and it leads to just doing several missions until you find weapons you can actually use on the tougher missions.

And the problem of variety doesn't just stop at equipment, characters themselves basically all play exactly the same. The tiny variations in starting equipment rarely makes a difference in the long run, which means each run is more-so dictated by what you manage to pick up while you play as the characters you've selected. Only the final mission offers any real static difference between them, and of course, you can't see what the mission will require of you until after you've been playing as them and gotten enough credits to get intel on that mission.

So let's talk about the changes I feel should be made to make this game deserving of that 95% rating.

First of all, increased equipment variety would make a huge change. Once there's a greater variation in equipment, they can stop handing out items that don't even feel like they were worth picking up in the first place. The goal should be, almost every find means you have a new way of approaching your situations, rather than 'I'll use this until I get a better one'.

Secondly, I do believe they should leave the universe as-is for a 'normal' mode. It's clear that people do have fun here, and a lot of casual players aren't going to be interested in the variety and difficulty that would be offered in my recommendations for a 'hard' and 'very hard' universe.

A hard universe needs to, first and foremost, stop pulling punches with the guards on a ship. There should be fewer single-patrol guards, and it would be ideal to replace them with multi-patrol guards. Each ship should have a number of back-up pilots that are detailed in the mission select screen, and each back-up pilot should go to the primary flight controls to take the helm once it's discovered that the pilot is missing. Perhaps adding some 'blood-hungry' guards that kill you on sight outright would also be a good idea, and this would also be listed in the mission briefing.

Next, the characters should be offer more variations in gameplay. Have characters that walk slower or faster, refuse to use melee weapons or guns or certain equipment, or get 'nautious' after they kill or die faster in the vaccume of space. Give all of them one or two negative traits, and perhaps ocassionally a positive one, so that every character feels unique, and must be played in a unique way. 

Hard mode should also not mention details on enemy equipment, other than including if you need armor piercing weapons in the basic mission details. Increased enemy variations for all modes would also be great, and add a lot more flavor to the aspect of this change. After a number of failed missions a character would be forced to retire, meaning that doing well would actually be a requirement to progress, and you could no longer fall back on just abandoning your goal if you think it's too hard.

Very hard mode would offer MORE negative traits for characters, and NO mission details, other than the primary and side objectives for that mission. Credits offered would give you a general idea of the difficulty, but even the overall time limit would have to be discovered upon arriving at the ship. This would make every mission more tense, and really give a sense of accomplishment once you've done enough with your character to feel comfortable retiring them. Additionally, the back-up pilots would go to any available flight-control once there is an alert of an intruder on the ship.

I know that just having a thumbs down is doing to net me a lot of 'not helpful' replies, but honestly, I write this review because I want to see this game be better. I love the foundation, I just think there's so many improvements that could be made to move it from 'good' to 'great', or even higher. 

If you find yourself interested in spite of what this review mentions, I would say buy it when it's on sale. Otherwise, wait to see what happens in post-launch.
