35230570.review:
[b](ASIDE: I have an odd, desperate urge for someone to mod this into a game set in The Expanse universe)[/b]

Heat Signature managed that rare thing: a procedural game with character and wit. It hits a sweet spot whereby it can be enjoyed by relatively casual gamers such as myself while also having evidently high challenge options for mroe hardcorep players.

Although operating in quite a different way, the procedural, interconnected nature of the player characters and their generated motivations feels reminiscent of Shadow of Mordor's semi-procedural enemies. It succeeds in imbuing the world with a greater sense of depth and investment.

That the mechanics are exquisitely interlocking helps.

Also, the simplicity of the game's spacey bits doesn't stop it from feeling MORE SPACEY then a lot of space simulators. It captures the feel of ship-to-ship shennanigans perfectly.

35230123.review:
easily one of my favorites of this year and one of the best indies in a long while. i've had this game pinned to the top of my wishlist for what feels like forever, and i've been following tom francis since he first announced the game. it's exactly what he said it would be, and that's the beauty of it.
you *do* go inside the spaceships, use a variety of equipment in a staggering variety of ways, and leave the spaceship. while this might not sound like much, the potential for systems interplay and procedural generation (of everything from names and missions to the entire galaxy you play in) make this game longer than it has any right to be, and enjoyable for every second you play. 
everything about this game is emblematic of what makes indie games great. peek around the game's directory for a while - you can puzzle out what makes this game tick just by reading into its assets. the supporter edition has even more devlogs, and - can you believe this was made in gamemaker? i know, right?
its truly a wonderful game that more than lives up to its promise, and id recommend it to practically anyone. do yourself a favor and buy it.

35230076.review:
Audacious quest: Rescue Zhaneta Gemini. Enigma clause (no living witnesses). Large ship. Warzone. 19 second timer once alarm sounds. How is this even possible?

Take the quest anyway. Fly to the ship and dock at an entrance. Target prisoner is on the other end of the ship, 9 or 10 rooms away plus locked doors. Once I dock, a countdown to a warship attack starts. That's about 15 seconds away. But what's this? The room the prisoner is in, is next to two rooms with windows.

I have a hunch, and pull out without stepping foot past the airlock, causing no alarms. Disengage my pod, and start inching my way over toward the windows from the outside of the ship. Not too close, because normally, windows also act as searchlights, and if you go in range you get seen and exploded. I hover around the side.

15 seconds pass. Enemy warship attacks my target ship. Just as I had hoped, a missile blows open the two windows, negating their searching capability and also turning them into dockable points for my pod. And also starting the 19 second panic alarm before mission failure.

But they're next to each other, and in the chaos of space, my pod latches onto the wrong one. This puts me two rooms away from my target, but with a wall between us. Nope. I back out and detach. A second after I detach, a missile smashes into the window I was in. That rips apart the entire ROOM from the ship, sending it spiralling away into space. Close call. 14 seconds left.

I nudge my pod along the side of the ship, and latch onto the correct window. Pause the game. 11 seconds left. But no guards around! I run in to the first room, then adjoining room, pluck Zhaneta from her bed, and carry her back to the pod. 8 seconds left. Detach. Fly off amidst a shower of missiles and head back to base.

Just another day in the life of a rebel fighter. And there are many more like that, tales of insane deeds performed by legendary heroes in subzero space with no living witnesses to corroborate their story.

===

This game is very fun, and on top of that I really enjoy games where friends can impact your game - this game lets you find items left behind by friends when they "win", and lets you rescue and recruit characters left behind by friends when they "lose".

I will briefly touch upon some of its key points that may not be obvious at first glance after reading its store page.

[list]
[*]It can, I suppose, get repetitive if you are always perfect. Part of the draw of the game is screwing up, then using the tools at your disposal to overcome a seemingly impossible situation. That is an amazing feeling.
[*]It is more forgiving than it seems at first. As long as the enemies aren't wielding lethal weapons, all you really have to do to win a majority of missions is take the pilot out of the pilot seat, which nullifies any alarm timer. Then you can experiment, and even if you get knocked out by the enemy and tossed out an airlock, you can use your pod to catch yourself and come back in. And even go refill your rechargeables back home first if you like.
[*]Look for the Offworld Angel pod in the liberation star menu, near your starting base. You want to liberate and unlock that ASAP (it's a great beginner/safety pod).
[*]Subverters can unlock doors.
[*]To progress the overarching nebula "quest", you will need to use many different characters, whether you win or lose with them. Once you have done too many missions with one character, they start contributing less to the global progress bar because they're too famous and don't inspire as much rebellion. Which is fine, it changes things up. I retire all my characters once (if) they complete their personal mission.
[*]You can "gear up" without being on missions by just flying around the nebula and pressing right click now and then to look for nearby ships.
[*]There was a bit of a learning curve bump between Normal and Hard for me, larger than the jump between any of the other difficulties. Don't give up right there though. I am absolutely terrible at the game, and I would say that actually makes the game more fun for me, because there is a lot of forgiveness built into the game and the screwups make for intensely awesome recoveries!
[/list]

Edit: More tips now that I've 100%'d the game:
[list]
[*]When you are straight up looking for ships to pirate, the Glitcher's Tick is the best pod. The snap range is huge, so you can literally fly around the nebula spamming E and F.
[*]You can apparently use, and retire, "Steal X Prototype" items. There's apparently some great and wacky combos of items, some good, some bad.
[*]If you play it before your friends, and don't seem to be getting the Heirloom achievement even though they've since retired some items, you may have to delete and re-install the game to force their Steam Workshop items to sync up.
[/list]

i really wasn't expecting to like this; the idea of missions being timed or being put on a timer sounds really frustrating to me, but this game actually does this well.

35228708.review:
Heat Signature is amazing. 

Let's just make sure my feelings are clear. 

It's a brilliant blend of action and stealth capabilities, as you try to board ships to murder, knock out, or steal. Random generation of ship layouts and guard loadouts means that you will never have the same experience. 

Tons of tools to get around and beat people with. Nice sense of progression as the game moves along. The retirement mechanic for characters is a good way to memorialize the actions of your heroic few that don't get lost in space.

35228681.review:
Although this game may not have lots of content, it's much more fun to grind through than many other games have been. I've had characters stuck on recharging gear for their entire playthroughs (up until they died during a mistake mission) and I've had characters who continuously get self-charging weapons and teleporters through random item boxes and retire with no challenge. 

If you are playing to beat the game you are playing wrong.

The point is not to grind the missions for the ending.
The ending is there so that when you've ground through so many missions you get a "reward", so that it wasn't all pointless (besides the fun you should've had)
If you don't like the missions, well that's the entire point of the game, there's no point in playing.
Play to enjoy the missions, make your own objectives, build up your characters with your own imaginative story and goal. 

I have created 7 different saves that i have played about 4 hours on each one, (and about 100 that i deleted because i didn't like the colors). after a certain point missions get easy because my characters have all the items they need, so retire them and get new characters for harder missions, if you end up just buying all the top-tier gear in the stores, make a new galaxy so that you can get the challenge back.

play missions that you don't think you can handle
get killed
get captured
get your pod destroyed because you were dumb and flew into sight of a ship
teleport yourself outside of your glitch tick somehow
blow a ship in half so you don't need to stealth back through a ship 
see what happens if you use this mysterious device they want you to grab
ghost through missions, taking 30 minutes where you could just bash one person over the head and leave if you weren't challenging yourself

if you just do the bare minimum to get through the game you will not have fun.

35228395.review:
Heat Signature thoughtully combines some of the best gameplay hooks from modern games and then shoots the whole thing into space:

* The fast top down combat of Hotline Miami
* The slow-motion tactical improvisation of Superhot
* The active pause, ship boarding and space intrigue of FTL
* The creative systems-driven stealth infiltration of Gunpoint and immersive sims

But it adds up to something more than the sum of its parts, consistently generating thrilling and ridiculous personal stories of subterfuge.

35228000.review:
[h1]Overall[/h1]
A great space-themed combat/stealth/puzzle* game with rogue-lite elements, such as permanent death**, randomly generated ships with random missions and loot and limited*** set of tools that you can acquire and learn to use in unique ways. Definitely worth the fair price if you're into this sort of thing. (Or.. just try it out? After all, you can refund a game if you've played it less than 2 hours.)

[h1]Like[/h1]
[list]
  [*] Various difficulty levels and additional mission requirements to match and test your skill.
  [*] There's multiple layers of goals so you always have something to aim for: Dealing with an encounter, finishing a single mission, finishing a character's personal mission and liberating the entire galaxy.
  [*] Only has a very basic story to justify the gameplay. You can instead make your own by stepping into various characters and choosing how to play with them. Perhaps based on their personal mission, or starting equipment, or what hardships they encounter during your playtime.
  [*] (*) You can pause the game at any time and take as much time as you need to plan.
  [*] (**) Depending on how you screw up, you may get a couple of chances before the eventual end of your character. The "captured" lose condition allows you to rescue your old character with a new one.
  [*] The game encourages you to start over even if you manage to survive, by slowing the galaxy liberation progression with a well-known character and allowing you to pick a unique name for a weapon to find later on if you retire them.
  [*] Steam integration: Find named items by your friends' retired characters or rescue their captured ones - if they missed their chance.
[/list]

[h1]Dislike[/h1]
[list]
  [*] A few oddities and glitches that aren't really annoying, let alone game-breaking.
  [*] Some things are not communicated well enough. It's apparently easier to get the rarest items by buying loot boxes using money you earned from missions instead of looting ships..? I've accidentally left my character to asphyxiate in space because it wasn't clear that they weren't in the pod. I killed an NPC I was supposed to capture. ...you can throw things!?
  [*] (***) While the weapons and tools are quite "balanced", I wish there was more to play with.
[/list]

35227999.review:
This is an amazing game that is very similar to Hotline Miami in terms of the actual gameplay. Where it differentiates itself, however, is in the tactics department. At any moment in Heat Signature you can pause the live gameplay and make an educated decision regarding your next move or action. This take on game tactics is further improved by the vast amount of options at your disposal during that pause in gameplay. 
  For example you could find yourself assaulted by two guards, one of which has just fired a shot at you. You could: 1) Use an item that swaps places with that guard, which will kill him with his own bullet and then dispose of the second guard while he is confused. 2) Teleport behind the shooting guard and knock him out with a wrench then fire a shot at the second guard before he figures out what is happening. 3) Use an item to slow down time then side step the bullet and dispose of each of the guards with your own gun. These are just three options which come to mind, but there are countless other ways to handle this specific situation.
  The vast amount of variables and options create an amazing science fiction themed toy box for you to play around in for countless hours. I was a participant in a beta for this game and have clocked many hours in addition to my current steam counter. 
  This game has a ton of content for the value and if you're a fan of the gameplay of Hotline Miami, you should not be disappointed.

Heat Signature has been a fantastic experience so far. You really can approach an objective from any angle, and the game actively encourages experimentation and diversity of playstyles. The stealth feels tense and rewarding, the action over the top and thrilling, the space travel a delicious wrapper around the whole package. Your character is powerful--very powerful--which feels super fun, but one small slip up and you're liable to be thrown out into space, so the game is not easy; its balanced perfectly I'd say. Optional mission criteria (like completing objectives without killing anyone) and the constant creation of new characters keeps the game from feeling too repetitive most of the time. My only complaint is on high-difficulty missions, they generally challenge you by having guards with lots of shields and ships with lots of turrets. So far I only know one way to counter these foes, and its more of a slog then giving me a thrilling choice of tools.

But overall, I love this game. Great for a long play session or a quick pop-in to your space station. Plus, you can flee a space ship by shattering a window and hopping out into space. Or you can kill a target that way. Smashing windows is great.

35226357.review:
Heat signature is a delirious romp through space. You get a random set of equipment and a breacher pod and then wreak havoc across an unsuspecting galaxy.

All the gadgets have uses and synergize together for all kinds of crazy problem solving.

Sneak around stealthily or go brash. Non-lethal take downs or copious bloodletting. The choice is yours and they are all satisfying.

It's a game that fosters implicit story telling. One example is the story of Chantel Fury. A woman out for blood. But then an opportunity to save lives arose. If she could free a faction stronghold, the galaxy would be one step closer to peace. So she set aside her quest for vengeance to tread a gentler path. She made it to the bridge of the siege ship without knowing she'd have a scant few seconds to escape the impending blast. She had no teleport, shield, or stealth gadgets, but she did have a slipstream. She was certain she would die, and yet she couldn't leave this life without a fight. And so she ran. She dodged bullets and guards and streaked across the ship at breakneck speed. She couldn't believe her eyes as she watched the siege ship's end from the cockpit of her pod milliseconds before she'd have joined it's fate.

And this is but a small part of Fury's tale.

Seriously. Buy the game. You won't regret it.

35221867.review:
Resumo

Semanas antes deste jogo sair, eu estava jogando FTL enquanto assistia um episódio de The Expanse(Doors and Corners) quando tripulantes de uma nave inimiga invadiram a Osprey que eu comandava no jogo... Pensei o quanto seria interessante ter uma mecânica de invasão e estratégia com pausa, como em Door Kickers, em um jogo com contexto similar a FTL e um tanto daquela esquizofrenia do combate de Hotline Miami. Acabei fazendo um mapa para Door Kickers chamado Boarding the Osprey (disponível no Workshop)... e isso justifica, provavelmente, minha automática paixão por Heat Signature. Se você gosta de FTL, Door Kickers e Hotline Miami, você vai gostar de Heat Signature. Um excelente jogo de ação/estratégia com pausa livre com mecânica refinada, competente apresentação visual e ótimo preço.

Vídeo Análise: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gsR2ExB6wGg
---------

Dos mesmos criadores de Gunpoint, Heat Signature (ótimo nome) é um jogo sobre invadir naves no espaço e viver incríveis mini aventuras completando missões de roubo, assassinato, rapto ou resgate enquanto expande o domínio de seu grupo pela Galáxia.

Uma primeira parte do deslocamento no jogo é através do espaço. O jogador controla um personagem cujo principal meio de tranporte é um Breaching Pod. Uma pequena nave projetada para abordar naves maiores. Uma vez atachado à nave, o Pod se abre e o personagem está livre para desenvolver e executar sua estratégia para alcançar o objetivo.

Há diversas formas de completar sua missão. Você pode adotar um estilo furtivo e eliminar toda a tripulação sem ativar alarmes ou completar o objetivo sem matar ninguém ou simplesmente portar uma Katana em cada punho e fatiar todos em seu caminho. Algumas missões irão impor cláusulas especiais como não matar nenhum tripulante, não ativar alarmes ou não deixar testemunhas vivas, tais cláusulas rendem melhor recompensa, mas não são realmente obrigatórias.

O sistema de estrutura das naves é bastante simples (modular) e muito dinâmico, sendo possível, por exemplo, partir uma grande nave no meio e transitar entre as duas metates durante uma missão enquanto essas metades cruzam a galáxia em constante movimento.

A constituição cênica combina bem com a execução do combate com pausa, dando ao personagem uma capacidade de resolver problemas limitada quase sempre apenas pela imaginação do próprio jogador. Você sentirá que cada personagem é poderoso na medida em que o jogador domina a mecânica e os itens disponíveis para realizar a missão e usa a imaginação para tentar manipular a situação. O retorno visual do uso de itens e armas é também muito bom.

A conformação modular das naves e a apresentação simples (mas competente) do jogo, assim como em jogos como Doorkickers e Hotline Miame, abrem incríveis possibilidades para modificações (como edição de naves e missões) e eu realmente espero que isso venha a existir no futuro.

Galáxias são geradas proceduralmente assim como a distribuição narrativa. Existe um determinado personagem padrão e quatro personagens aleatórios com morte permanente. Cada um destes vem com sua própria missão pessoal que destrava quando o personagem alcança os níveis mais difíceis de missões e entrega 200 pontos de dinheiro para o personagem que libera a missão pessoal. Assim que um personagem morre ou é aposentado ele é substituido por outro.

A distribuição narrativa não vai além da contextualização breve disponibilizada por dois personagens e na missão pessoal de cada um. É eficiente naquilo que é o objetivo de sua existência para o jogo: contextualização mecânica-narrativa e não mais que isso. Outra característica compartilhada por Doorkickers e FTL.

Ao realizar a missão pessoal, o jogador pode aposentar o personagem que poderá aparecer no jogo de outro contato seu na Steam que também possua Heat Signature, podendo também rotular uma arma deste personagem como lendária. Este item lendário poderá aparecer durante outras sessões do próprio jogador e também no jogo de contatos da Steam.

Para cada estação conquistada na Galáxia, o jogador tem uma missão única com limitação de equipamento usado. Fora essas missões (que não são obrigatórias, mas trazem vantagens mecânicas como novas armas e outros recursos), o jogador é livre para adotar o estilo de equipamento que desejar ou pensar ser mais conveniente de acordo com o que ele destravou até o momento. 

Com esses elementos, o jogo promove um ambiente de agradável ação com razoável dificuldade e boa curva de aprendizado com o aumento gradativo das dificuldades disponíveis para cada personagem. Os diversos estilos disponíveis são um estímulo a mais jogadores que gostam de mecânicas que possibilitam experimentação.

Algumas faltas que podem ser apontadas são:

1 – Música: Poderia ser muito melhor se fosse um pouco mais frenética com variações dinâmicas durante pausas. Os sons do jogo são bons, mas a música realmente é pouco variada e deixa a desejar.

2 – Não há imposição de uma distribuição de pontos de habilidade por personagem. Apesar de terem missões pessoais e visuais diferentes, personagens funcionam da mesma forma, sendo o próprio jogador o responsável pela imposição de limitações ou estilos distintos.

3 – Personalização para compartilhamento dos personagens aposentados é limitada.

4 – Há uma variação para a forma visual das naves, mas todas as variações (de acordo com a facção) funcionam basicamente da mesma forma (exceto os pods pilotados pelos personagens jogáveis, cada variedade possuindo uma função especial).

5 – Há pouca variação entre as estações e missões não acontecem em nenhum outro ambiente que não seja uma nave. Isso é, claro, parte do contexto, mas seria interessante ter missões em estações ou ambientes diferentes.

6 – Não há tradução (até o momento) para Português-Br

Mas a relação de preço e qualidade deste produto é uma das melhores entre jogos do gênero e de magnitude e complexidade similares. Um desenvolvimento de três anos que rendeu um produto simples, mas competente e muito divertido para aqueles que gostam de ação, estratégia com pausa e aventuras no Espaço. E eu recomendo Heat Signature pelo preço total  de R$ 27,99.

35219225.review:
Her name was Orchard.  Yeah, odd name but does that really matter especially after you pull the sort of stunt she did?  I don't think so and if you ask me, others wouldn't either. 

What does matter is that stunt; her's was an interesting story, what with a daughter who fell into the wrong crowd and wounded up being a prisoner to the Glitchers.  Never did find out why but she wasn't the first person I've heard of ending up in a cell with those tech crazy freaks. 

Orchard's a good mom so she does what any decent parent does, she digs.  She gets the info she needed but it ended up being costly--200 credits if I recall right and to get all of them required a lot of work, most of it pretty damn sloppy truth be told.

She started the job with a wrench and a three charged swapper--given the lack of lethal weapons, she probably preferred to get around folk than kill them so she did that to the best she could.  She got shot at least five times in those early days but she did amass the credits and a lot of expensive and well-to-do gear--the sort of stuff that would get you shot five more times over if the wrong sort of person learned you had any of it.

Well, after enough close calls she finally finds the ship where her baby girl is being kept.  She breaks in and wouldn't you know it? Every damn guard on that ship is carrying a personal shield that blocks even her graviton hammer from whisking them to la la land. Does she have anything to bring down those shield? Yeah she does but it only has three charges and there's at least twenty or so of those sheltered bastards.  

So, what does a mom do? She abuses what she found--it was a five charge slipstream, lets you move faster then a man could blink an eye, all she appeared to these folks was an odd blur moving from room to room, stopping to malfunction a door that was in her way until finally, she's carrying her daughter over her shoulder--exhausted but relieved to finally have her baby back, flesh and blood whole at that.

Charge on the slipstream is gone.  Her swapper? One person at a time--she's not leaving without what she's come so far to get.  There is one little idea but its risky--the room, the one and only way into the cell where she's at has a panel that when damaged will take away a whole section of the ship.  

She had found a grenade in her second mission--kept it for a special ocassion.  It wasn't going to get more special than this. 

She throws it, waits for the shake and the blaring sound of alarms echoing in the place along with a warning that they were heading to a station some fifteen seconds away.  There's no turning back here...

Her and her daughter go jetting through the black, nothing but a fast ship and a prayer standing between the two of them and a cold death.

When she arrives on the station she takes her daughter and vanishes.  She didn't want this kind of life and now that she got what she wanted she could leave it behind--her graviton hammer was left behind though, folks have gotten around to calling it "Orchard's Lullaby" in honor of one crazy, truly caring mom. 

If you happen upon it...well, who knows? Maybe something of Orchard will get passed along with it.  A person in this line of work could always use a little hope and a lot of luck.

35218932.review:
玩了近15小时了，给大家说说一点个人经验。
[olist]
    [h1]科技：[/h1]
有的科技会使商店解锁新的贩卖物品，推荐先解锁反电子设备，护盾，隐身，破甲。当点完科技后会有个挑战任务，目前没发现不做会有什么后果。
    [h1] 经验：[/h1]
当一个角色完成任务后会提供科技经验，但随着人物的成长（就是按下暂停后右上角的progress进度条），经验会越来越少直至1%。这时需要去最上方的那个地方让角色退休更换新的角色。[spoiler]当然，你也可以留着他好好爽♂爽。[/spoiler]
    [h1] 装备：[/h1]
一般前期需要先搞到一把消音武器，一把长刀，一把冲击枪。接下来可以靠在敌人船上收刮箱子得道具，偷钥匙是个很好用道具！如果任务有护甲兵，可以去买点雷。再然后就根据你所拥有道具安（烧）排（杀）战（抢）术 （掠）

    [h1]战斗技巧：[/h1]
No.1，当你使用武器时，会显示一个弧线和一个白圈，弧线代表了攻击距离，白圈代表了声音范围，即如果开枪时有敌人在白圈范围内就会发现你。
No.2，如果一个房间有大量敌人无法处理时可以等他们巡逻，来一个杀一个（可以长按F加速），但要记住把尸体放在房间角落，不然下一个敌人还没走过来，在路上发现尸体就直接拉警报了。
No.3，当触发警报或者接的是限时任务时，只需要把开船的杀掉倒计时就会结束。同时探照灯会关闭。
    [h1] 进阶版[spoiler]（骚操作）[/spoiler][/h1]
    No.1：
有的房间中间会有能量管 [strike]炸药[/strike]（就是一个斜着的橘黄椭圆管子），被致命型武器命中后（自己或者敌人都可以！），隔2s左右会发生爆炸将房间摧毁并把与之相连的通道上的东西抛入太空。同时创造出一个可以让小船连接的出口。
于是，当你遇到一大群敌人无法处理时，可以把他们勾引到有能量管的房间，开启自己的护盾，和敌人[strike]同归于尽[/strike]。当遇到抓捕任务或者刺杀任务且目标身上有护盾时也可以这样玩，他们会被抛入太空不会死，这时用小船他们装上就OK了。
当然，当任务完成后你想开自己的小船回家但回船路程太远，你也可以炸掉房间，然后把小船开过来接你。


    No.2：
每艘船上都会有窗户，就是发射探照灯的房间。当窗户被破坏时会将房间及房间相连通道上的物体抛入太空。但不会创造让小船对接的对接口。[spoiler]也可以用来抛尸23333[/spoiler]
同理，可以用来处理大波敌人，也可以用来处理棘手的目标，当任务完成后也可以主动从窗户出去，然后开小船接自己。
这里先要介绍一个道具——Glitch Trap：放置一个陷阱，当敌人碰到陷阱时将敌人传送到你指定的位置。（自己不会触发陷阱）
将这个陷阱放到敌人的必经之路上，把目的地设到窗户，然后敌人碰到陷阱时就会被抛入太空23333333，这样不但搞定了敌人还不会留下尸体。
[/olist]
暂时就想到这么多，就先这样吧。
最后，祝大家玩的愉快~~~~~

35214297.review:
Heat Signature feels like a crazy hybrid of Hotline Miami and FTL.  The Hotline Miami comparison should be clear, but the similarities with FTL go further than the sci-fi setting.  The game features a time-slow mechanic whenever you are being spotted, and has a pause feature that allows the planning of your next action while simultaniously opening the inventory.  It feels much more like a tactics game than an action game because of this.  Mix in some strange, strategy changing loot and some rogue-lite mechanics, and you have a really exceptional package.

Music is evocative of HotMiam, but HeatSig's most impressive artistic direction is the universe scale.  I realize that the graphics are not so taxing that it would make these effects a technical marvel, but the lack of loading screens really goes a long way to depicting the scale. 

Tight controlls, dope setting, 10/10 favorite of 2017 by a long shot.

35212951.review:
Vega collected the 200 to track down the monster that tortured her partner and made her move. But she was ill-prepared. Six attempts at getting to the bastard, six times flying bleeding out the airlock. This time she persisted. And this time she was trapped with no way to escape on the fleeing craft as it docked in enemy territory.

***

Orion had followed the trail of rumors about his partner to a shady backroom filled with rebels and thugs. A hunch materialized as an offer, secrets for sale if he would just do a few favors for the underground. For Vega, for the only woman who cared about him, he would have to become a force of nature. He would have to become a legend.

They were bouncing Vega from outpost to outpost, shuffling her around just ahead of him. But finally he was ready. A knife to the back, the hiss of the sidewinder glitching him down empty hallways to ready ambush points. He popped the switch on his visitor and stepped through space to where Vega was curled in the fetal position. Two seconds -- long enough for her to turn her head and see him, long enough for him to grab hold of her before he was whiplashed back into a hallway just as the guards raised their guns. And just as quickly he was gone.

***

"Maybe you should give it up," Orion said. The rifle he'd picked off a Foundry elite was hung up on the wall like a trophy, barrel cold.

"Would you have given up?" Vega asked.

"What I did... that was a debt. But this... this whole thing... most of the scars that would have healed have healed. There's nothing else for it. Just forget him. He's just one man."

Vega checked her loadout. "Aren't we all?"

***

Vega rammed the Angel right up to the airlock loud enough to shake the ship. She flew out through the opening seal andpinned a guard through the back with her longblade. As the sentry gun teed her up from down the hall, she ducked back out of sight. A spatial hop with the sidewinder put her right behind the sentry gun and with a spark of electricity she tore out its heart.

She stepped through the opening door behind her, ready to bludgeon and slash her way to the monster at the other side of the ship -- just as missiles from a rogue fighter craft tore through the hull and sucked several bodies out into space. The alarm sounded and the memories of her captivity rushed through her head. "I'm sorry," she muttered, thinking about the debt she would never be able to repay. About the monster that would always be just out of reach. She dove back into the Angel and detached from the ship as whirlwinds of fire were sucked through the tears in its hull.

And there, faintly through the port viewscreen she saw him. Limbs flailing, hands grabbing at his throat as rapid decompression hurtled him through space. The man who broke Orion. Vega pulled the angel up just close enough to stare into the torturer's eyes as the life faded from them. If she couldn't have revenge, she would at least have closure.

***

Yeah, crap like this happens all the time, 10/10.

35212335.review:
This game is about chaos.  Or rather, controlling chaos.  If you love planning things out and then watching those plans fall all apart in wonderfully unpredictable and oftentimes ridiculous ways, Heat Signature is the game for you.  It's also one of the few games out there with non-terminal failure states.  That is to say, failing isn't necessarily the end.  Getting shot doesn't necessarily result in death, you will have a short period of time to remote-control your ship and rescue yourself each time, but each time it happens the amount of time you will have next time is shorter, and eventually your character will die.  However, as a true roguelite game, you can just come back with another character and continue.  

And there are more fates than death for your characters.  For instance, they could also be captured by the enemy, at which point you can rescue yourself with another character.  Essentially, you aren't really playing a single character, instead you are controlling an entire organization whose goal is to eventually liberate an entire galaxy.  However, each individual character you control has thier own personal goal that drives them.

I first played this game back in beta and it really has come a long way.  I think the strongest part of the gameplay lies in the gadgets and equipment you can use on missions.  You can buy these things in the home station, or find them in missions.  Their various uses and unpredictability of the situations you will have to use them in make the game interesting and continue to provide you with challenges as you progress through the game.  

Missions are the main way to progress, though there's nothing stopping you from going out and exploring the sector on your own.  Ships can be found flying between stations, doing their own thing, and you can board them looking for loot or capture them if you can take out all the guards and pilot it back to your home base.

Altogether, this is a fun game with a simple but effective concept and mechanics that are easy to learn.  So far it seems like there are enough challenges at higher difficulties to keep the game interesting for a while, but I'm not far enough along yet to say for sure.  If nothing else, the game has alot of replayability, and you can change galaxies at will to change things up if you want.

35211477.review:
Heat Signature is a top-down Ronin/Gunpoint style of game where you move around freely and then everything slows down in combat, and you are able to look around and plan every strike. This is great in theory! But the game has some up's and downs.

Good - Very tight, responsive controls. Moving around and planning and execution feels exactly like it should. The gameplay itself is kind of stealth/action oriented depending on personal preferences and the overall loop has you going to a mission, winning or losing, and then repeating the process with some other ship/mission.

Bad - Extreme difficulty. Any difficulty past hard may as well not exist, I was able to beat maybe 1 in 20 tries on the higher diffuclty missions. So i just stopped trying them. I was ok with picking medium/hard, but eventually the game shoe-horns you into ONLY being able to pick these extremly high difficulty (including your primary character goal) missions, so it becomes frustrating as you get stuck trying to progress and simply cant. 

The big issue is the guards with shields. They absolutely roadblock the entire game. You can bring a shield destroyer with you but it doesnt matter, because while you might be able to shut down 3-6 shields, the level will have around 20+ and so you just look around in disbelief as to what you are supposed to do. Some missions are quite literally impossible. 

Overall i do like the game. When it comes together and the challenge is just right, it's very satisfying and enjoyable. But the difficulty problems limit how much i can possibly enjoy or recommend it, so if you are a person that struggles with high difficulty games, be careful with this one.

35211204.review:
Heat Signature: Because Ice can't sign autographs.

Heat Signature is simply a fun game.
Can't spend hours on it, like a quarter of a match of Civ5 that makes me go "Wait, it's 5am already?! I just had lunch a minute ago!".
But for an hour, or two, a quick mission or see how many outposts I can liberate in a row before I forget to retire someone, it's an incredibly fun and adicting game.
It has a feel of Hotline Miami, mixed with FTL, mixed with a bit of Dark Souls 2 "hollow system" everytime you die. When you get shot, you lose time you can keep alive next time, so your life gets shorter and shorter each time.
An advice I can give people, is to take your time, plan, and remember to pause a lot. It'll save your arse. A lot. An assload of a lot.

35209491.review:
Heat Signature is an extremely well executed interstellar stealth game. The random ships are different enough to provide countless enjoyable experiences but also similar enough to allow for the player to create their own strategies that work in many scenarios. Death is punishing, forcing you to start as a new character, but the game makes beginning again an exciting experience, so you never feel like the game is enragingly hard. 

PROS:
-Massive replayability
-Lots of items to unlock and collect
-Random levels
-Player can decide their own way to play (Sneaky or forceful? Kill everyone or only the target?)
-Mixes strategy with luck (where will the guard go?) very well
-Any mission can be done with starting items, if you are good enough

CONS:
-Some may find that the ships are repetitive.

BUY IF YOU LIKE: Gunpoint (same devs), Binding of Isaac (random adventures w/ dodging and skill), Hotline Miami (top-down shooter)

35209079.review:
Zacznę od tego, że gra przypomina Hotline Miami ale znacząco się od niej różni. Po pierwsze mamy aktywną pauzę, po drugie przeciwnicy nie alarmują się od razu, po trzecie jest sporo różnorakiego sprzętu w klimatach sci-fi (teleportery, klonery, hakery itd.), po czwarte misję i sprzęt wybieramy sami wydług uzniania i po piąte gra nie ma jako takiej fabuły - to spora logiczno-zręcznościowa sci-fi piaskownica opierająca się na proceduralnym tworzeniu leveli. Z początku mnie nudziła, ale wraz ze wzrostem poziomu trudności i pojawianiu się nowych modyfikatorów całość nabrała rumieńców. Najlepsze jest to, że gra pozwala improwizować - nie masz czym zabić kolesia w zbroi? Wywal go w kosmos. Nie dasz rady zdobyć klucza do schowka? Teleportuj się do środka. Tego jest naprawdę sporo i człowiek ma wrażenie, że cały czas udaje mu się wywinąć  jakiś nowy numer. Do tego jest trochę latania kapsułą, decydowania które sektorych chcemy zająć i niewielka dawka dobrego humoru, a na deser specjalnie przygotowane misje w których odgrywamy z góry zdefiniowane role. Zapomniałem jeszcze dodać, że gra ma charakter rogue-lite ale nie jest to uciążliwa mechanika. Powiedziałbym, że zachęca to zmiany postaci i próbowania innego podejścia.

Plusy:
+ Proste podstawy rozgrywki...
+ ..rozbudowane o całą masę przedziwnych możliwości
+ Swoboda działania
+ Tempo rozgrywki 
+ Przyjemna oprawa audio-video

Minusy:
- Brak fabuły nie przeszkadza, ale nieco więcej tekstu byłoby miłym dodatkiem
- Gra rozkręca się dopiero po 2-3h grania

I've been playing through the game and am very happy with the purchase. It sets out to allow fluidic gameplay with versetile use of tools and very much accomplishes that. You can approach the game from so many different angles and using your own creativity and enginuity to do so. One of my personal favorites when dealing with the Foundry is to commandeer a ship and blow off the enemy's engines. Easy pickings. 

However I feel this game could have more to offer. The tool selection is good. I couldn't ask for a whole lot more there. The weapon choices are decent. But I feel more could be done with ships and systems. For example a power core. hit it too many times and the majority of the ship goes up in flames. Or sever a part of the ship from the core and it looses power. Requiring a space suit if you want to traverse the section. an artificial-gravitational generator (arti-grav-gen for short) which if disabled/destroyed slows movement of any characters without magnetic boots. And of course life support, disable it and the air starts running out. 

I'd also like to see breach charges you can use to escape a ship post haste. 

IDK. But I feel as though there is a gap to be filled.

35207599.review:
Goodstuff:
Having played 2 hours or so of this game i've gotten a feel for flow of gamepay and the overall flow, im beginning to understand all the different weapons and gadgets and im interested to see how much i can improve my skill. This game is very satisfying in that; clearing a ship can be both an extreme challenge and a dawdle depending on your preference, how you prepare, your skill and your reaction time. Something i've noticed in my 2 hours is (as with Gunpoint) Heat Signature is very polished in it's little details, for instance; every station has a different design, stations get named after characters who liberated them and you can do unexpected things such as rescuing a hostage by blowing up the room next to them so they shoot off into space.

Gripes:
This game NEEDS customization of pretty much everything and much better story/lore, other than developer budget i see no reason why not. Customization options should include: Name, Gender, Ethnicity and Clothes/Armour (I'll get back to this). In terms of story/lore i feel Heat Signature does well during the tutorial phase and then begins to fizzle out. im interested to learn about the four factions and The Drift as a whole, i want missions to have briefs just to give me some motivation as i murder countless members of X faction to steal Y project. My final gripe is that while the weapons in Heat Signature seem fleshed out there are no armor options or upgrades at all which I found odd, Armour could have been an interesting mechanic; say having heavy armour being highly protective but loud so that enemies in adjacent rooms can hear you. I understand this would take away from the Hotline Miami element this game has struck but it is a personal preference of mine.

Misc:
Pods are cool and all but i want a ship, a big fucking battleship.

-Buy this game-

35207040.review:
游戏虽小，但是非常耐玩，强烈推荐。简单地说一些心得。

背景和目标：游戏设定我们一开始有一个初始星球，随着完成任务，会逐步“解放”其他星球增加基地的数量。游戏提供四个可供选择的英雄，除了初始装备不同基本没有什么区别。在基地接任务之后，离开基地飞到外太空，跟着指针就可以找到目标飞船并登陆。

飞船操作：左键加速，右键刹车，基本就是一路朝着目标左键，快到的时候右键，把速度降低，飞船会相对目标静止，然后用左键微调直到目标位置，会有个小箭头指示你从飞船屁股上侵入——正面敌人能看到你并且击毁飞船，这个时候要按照指示按下相应按键，否则你的飞船就爆炸，英雄消失。

英雄：英雄是随机的，只有一条命，被抓走或者窒息都会导致这个英雄消失。但是英雄不会直接死，敌人无论是用枪还是近战武器打死你，都只是引起警报同时把你丢到外太空。英雄进入外太空之后你可以遥控你的飞船接走英雄。要特别注意，只要你引起警报，敌人飞船就会直接飞向最近的基地。只要你英雄在敌人船上，而敌人到达基地（倒计时到0），你的英雄就被捕，英雄消失。

敌人船长（驾驶员）(重要)：只要干掉驾驶员，倒计时就消失，这个船不管你触发再多次警报，船员也只会把你丢到外太空，你遥控飞船接到人可以重新反复多次入侵。所以干掉驾驶员基本就等于通关。因为驾驶员位置相对固定——100%在船头有个很明显的座椅，而且没有任何自卫能力。驾驶室通常也只有驾驶员。所以与其找任务（任务通常在最里面）不如先去处理掉驾驶员。

敌人：大部分敌人都是四到五人一组，然后依次按固定的路线巡逻。所以只要等待耐心观察，总能一个个收拾掉。但是要特别注意敌人也是穿装备的，这个在你接任务的时候能看到。所有敌人里最难处理的是护甲敌人和护盾敌人。

护甲敌人：护甲敌人是黄色衣服的，你攻击的时候会听到金属的叮叮声。只有带穿甲的武器可以打带护甲的敌人。

护盾敌人：护盾有两种，一种是看到你的时候激活，一种是永久激活。带着护盾的敌人几乎是无敌的，刀枪不入。杀死护盾敌人最好的办法是传送陷阱，把他们传送到外太空去。因为这个游戏敌人ai很低，只会沿着固定路线巡逻和追击，所以个人认为这个游戏最有用的道具是（5/5 自然充能的传送陷阱）

资源和道具：资源就是钱、子弹和穿甲子弹。子弹主要是在打敌人的过程中拾取，用途不是特别大，因为这游戏敌人往往4、5个一组，如果用枪还来不及干掉几个敌人就拉响警报了，与其说是枪战，倒不如说是太空2d刺客信条。

杀死/击晕：武器有两种，一种致死，一种击晕。有的任务有要求必须全部杀死或者不能杀人。或者暗杀、绑架。所以要根据不同情形准备不同的武器，最好是两种都带。

近战武器：锤、短刀、长刀、枪、散弹枪、步枪六种，其中锤的升级形态是没有攻击间隔的高级版本，但是不穿甲（橙色装备大概100p左右价格），短刀和长刀的区别就是攻击距离和攻击间隔，个人认为短刀比较好用，因为敌人都是四五人一组，一个个杀距离不是问题，杀一群长刀就不如短刀好用。

枪械：因为是平面的，所以散弹枪就是魂斗罗的散弹枪，比手枪、步枪好用。所有的枪都有击晕版本，击晕版本不需要子弹。枪械的静音和射速是专用词条，静音是无声、消声，肯定是越低越好。但是射速不是越快越好，因为最快的射速是自动。自动有个缺陷就是你按住左键或者右键就保持激发——可是这游戏最需要的是瞄准，你刚准备瞄准，嘣嘣两枪已经打出去了。不但会触发警报，而且因为这游戏所有敌人都是一枪死，连发几乎没有任何意义。

装备：装备分为白色、蓝色、橙色、黄色和任务物品。平时我们刷的主要是橙色、黄色物品。在基地左下角的商店买一个6、70一个的赌博礼包，是装备最主要的来源——没错，赌博。因为基本上做一两个任务就能赌一次，而稍微好一点的装备如果靠从商店买基本比礼包贵。

别问我哪来那么多钱。我刷了几乎所有的装备，发现这个游戏的装备几乎是固定的（因为词条很少），总共大概十几类几百种排列组合。我把大家需要用到的给大家总结一下。

1、扳手：白字的扳手只要1块钱，角色可以自带，是游戏最有用的道具。橙色扳手只是没有攻击间隔，攻击距离长，其实和白色扳手没有本质区别。

2、短刀/长刀：根据喜好，刀的升级版是可以穿甲，只要是从礼包开出来的刀必然带穿甲，但是和普通的刀区别也就仅仅是这个了。刀的刷新率大概也就是5%左右，换句话说你要淘一把带穿甲的刀要至少20次。但是不要子弹的穿甲刀几乎是后期必须的。

3、传送装置：sidewinder，传送装置有好几种（普通传送、传送再回原地的、和敌人互换位置），我用的最多的是sidewinder，这个玩意在抢时间杀船长的时候特别有用。传送装置可以带的词条是 数量 1/3/5 自然填充/回基地填充 1.5倍/2倍距离，所以最好的传送器是5+自然填充+2倍距离，几乎你想怎么用就怎么用。3+自然填充是基础。

4、偷取钥匙：key cloner，这个和传送装置一样并列四大必带装备，因为有时候时间不允许你等着一个个干掉敌人，也不能冲上去杀杀杀，就最好用key cloner远程偷钥匙。因为一个关卡一般不过3、5把钥匙。高难度有6把以上，所以key cloner要刷到一个3发以上蓄能，最好是自然充能的。

5、传送陷阱：Glitch trap护盾敌人最好的清理方式，一个5发自然充能的护盾陷阱作用很明显。

6、瘫痪装置：这个游戏高难度任务都带很多炮塔，炮塔会朝着4个方向旋转，如果你懒得等他的间隔，最好的办法是提前瘫痪掉提高容错率。

7、时间暂缓：瞬间提高角色速度，降低敌人速度，这个游戏被敌人看到的时候时间流逝会变慢，但是你的人物速度不会变，用了时间暂缓装置人物速度会变快有点快银的感觉。这个装置和短刀配合，可以瞬间秒掉一组敌人。前提是敌人都没有护盾。

以上7个装置基本上可以处理你在游戏里有可能遇到的所有情况，角色基本就无敌了。还留有一个空位用来放任务道具。需要破窗的时候按空格在左边可以看到所有地上掉落的物品，随便拿把敌人掉的枪（瞬间传送到你手里）就可以破窗。



目前为止其他一些心得：

1、保命：任务做不完没有任何惩罚，但是只要人物消失，装备和钱就归0，所以宁可做不成任务也不死。这游戏有时候普通难度的任务比困难的任务给的分也不低。

2、模拟：在基地可以进行不要命的模拟，easy模式给你5个普通敌人，hard模式会随机护甲、护盾敌人。多拿模拟模式练手很重要。

3、暂停：随时按空格都能暂停，导致这游戏看似是即时制，因为这个方便的暂停功能你也可以当成回合制游戏玩。暂停以后所有装置都可以瞬发。

4、最难处理的任务：护盾boss+捕捉，我到现在还没搞清楚这种任务该怎么处理，因为带护盾的boss只有一种处理方式就是用陷阱或者利用窗户把他弄到外太空去。但是这游戏除了英雄以外，在外太空最多存活不到10s，你还来不及用小飞船去捕捉人就死了。所以目前我还没研究出具体怎么处理这种情况的方案。或许以后试试看用传送陷阱把对方传送到自己的小船试试看。

35206950.review:
A mission game in space built around the ability to pause and prepare actions whenever you like. This lends itself to some really crazy gameplay, and taking out entire rooms of guards in a quick flurry of pausing, shooting, dashing, and throwing feels amazing. Teleporters, hacking guns, and stealth shields add another layer alongside special mission conditions such as no alarms or no killed guards to offer a surprising amount of replayability.

The progression system of retiring mercenaries and slowly unlocking more equipment is also pretty cool, and I love that you can see the items your steam friends have retired, and get the chance to save their captured mercs. 

My only real complaint is that certain guard traits like shields or armor can be really daunting to deal with unless you've unlocked some subverters or other equipment, but even that's pretty minor, given that you can always beat them with grenades, depressurizing rooms, and stealth. 

The game is a bit sparse with instructions at times, and knowing things like F to speed up space travel or the fact that you can pilot hijacked ships and use their rockets to attack other ships (and create a new opening to dock with) would be good information to tell the player more directly, but if you like discovering new tactics or interactions and becoming a space-badass that slashes and warps through a ship in effortless, fluid motion, definitely give Heat Signature a try

35204063.review:
Hands down the best small game I've played in ages. Incredibly unique in all the ways that count nowadays, simple design with huge potential and a ton of love put into it. Oozes that 'open' spirit missing from developement post big money gaming, keeps the spirit alive. Charming art design, simple sound that delivers and doesn't try too hard. Music is cute and beepy boopy but gets you in that space operator feel. The creativity possible with the game elements at its base is extremely wide open and situational; I don't think there is another game of it's kind that does everything this does so tactfully without a single hint of ugly DLC moneygrabbing or content choking, my hat is firmly off. 

The combat mechanics are clean and simple, delivering a very uncluttered experience. The pause menu system is useful and spartan like I feel they should be. No consolization Y-wheel bologna, opens alot of possibilities and creates a puzzle system feel. The space piloting element of the pod feels just like how you think space would be in 2D like those old flash games that turned into infinite space etc- clunky but not for the sake of bad controls. 

Docking in motion is fun at its base and when shit gets hectic you invoke the COME ON TARS in yourself and dock with that floating chunk of wreckage holding your rescue target (bless you warzone rescues with tight limits). The pods are all quite different and I gotta say, the Brick is a hoot to just smash shit with boy howdy. Window diving and catching yourself with your pod always feels just so godamn fun, the vacuum element is sweet. There is so much to discover in such a tightly packaged GAME that I can't say enough good things. 

This game has invoked a feeling of early 2000s, dreamer game design with big universes done simply- space feels like space. The dev doesn't squeeze your ass for every dollar, the game is priced very nicely. It is just, good. Please play this and get the experience, it's one of those gems.

Very good.

I've only presently played for 2.5hrs, but it's really good, and I can tell I'll be playing it alot more, probably mainly as a Pick up and Play filler between main interests.

You are an infiltrator, flying your ship to target vessels and clamping on to their hulls limpet fashion. You enter covertly and proceed to fulfill your contracted objective, be it assassination, stealing equipment or rescuing individuals. You get in and get out, and in most cases you leave the target ship and all its crew dead in doing so, floating out into the abyss. Contracts are rated by difficulty, and are very quickly played through. You dont rank your character with XP, instead you become more capable through the loot gained on previous missions, or loot purchased within a freindly space station. The Harder the contract the more pay. To make things more interesting each character has a back story, with a long term personal objective, such as carrying out a Revenge Killing, and the information you need to get closer to achieving this long term goal is expensive, and you start of practicaly broke ...so this adds to the flavour of the game by giving your character purpose throughout your play through. In my total time of 2.5hrs I have gone through 4 characters and have lost them all!   :(    If your character is captured you can even find his old partner as a playable character, who's long term goal is to rescue his incarcerated capadre, and by doing so lets you pick up where you left off! You can retire characters, I guess you do so anytime after they have achieved their personal goal, and in doing so you are making them a historical legend, to be compared with others (high score?)
.
This game is great! Easy to Pick up and Put down, yet a lot of depth to be found within, a really good Indie game for long or short duration play.

35199647.review:
This game encourages thinking outside the box. Literally. In any other space based game, decompression would be fatal, or incredibly dangerous. In Heat Signature it is merely another tool in your toolbox... did I say toolbox? I should really have said your massive wheeled toolchest. The solutions to problems in this game are plentiful, and many obstacles can be overcome in multiple ways, allowing for a wide range of creativity.

The combination between frantic top down action and tactical gameplay is fantastic. The gadgetry is often as hilarious as it is useful, especially when you start bringing about teleporters that all function in different ways, time dilation devices etc. The enemies commit the fatal sin of letting the vacuum of space decide your fate, if they manage to hit you, which means that with a little skill, a death is not necessarily going to be a death, though it will get harder to survive next time.

The persistence of characters in the universe is very well done and the game actively encourages changing characters often, sending others to the hall of fame, or letting newer blood continue unlocking gear, until you can return to them, and tool them up with the kit necessary to do their own personal mission.

The game will, eventually get a little repetitive, however I've put close to 4 hours in so far and I'm not even close to having explored every possible route. I have however discovered my favorite, which involves wrenches and decking everyone in the face with them.

35198420.review: It's an underpriced gem. Unique and engaging blend of game concepts (but still focused on clear ideas), with a high level of polish hinting at a lot of developer passion. First "roguelike" that really clicked for me - the core mechanics and player freedom are balanced just right to create memorable experiences and unexpected twists without relying on a scripted story. Intense but not stressful, thanks to the ability to pause anytime to plan the next move; almost gives it a turn-based feel. Can be played on easier missions for a while, but for some of the later progress you have to go through at least a few harder missions. I hit a wall early on, but luckily didn't give up until my skill finally improved. There are many items/gadgets that can help, but over time I've also started enjoying playing with minimal items (e.g. whatever comes with a fresh character) for an even more focused experience. It can absolutely be possible to pick the hardest available mission with a completely fresh character with no fancy items, and still beat it because there are so many ways to achieve your goal - immense satisfaction. Even though there's no real story, the game's mini-universe actually feels pretty immersive - there are no transitions between screens, it's all seamlessly mousewheel-zoomable from a close-up of your character all the way to a map of the entire universe. Music is great and adds to immersion as well. The concept is new, but other games came to mind for certain aspects - "hotline miami in space" is probably the closest, but it can also be more stealthy/tactical almost like the old "commandos" games.

35195612.review:
(TL;DR- Great and Fun Game. Only issue is that it sets you up to fail as you progress with a Character)


This game is amazing. Its basically a mix between FTL and HotLine Miami. It's super fun and being able to get a little creative with accomplishing missions is also great (Like, in an assassination mission, boarding the ship, killing everyone, then killing off everyone except for the target. Get in a duel with Target, but shoot out a window and then reboard the ship and bring it back to a station to sell its loot.)

The only gripe that I have is that once you get attached to a character, there is an insane difficulty spike. What I mean is, when trying to select a new mission, every mission will be either labeled as Hard or higher. In my experience, it doesn't even matter which station you go to, because no mission will be easier than Hard. When you get to this point, you are basically being set up to fail, and the character you enjoyed playing as will either get captured or die.
Personally, I prefer to play through Medium level missions, because I like to play at my own pace.
There isn't a reason to do this to the players, since each difficulty yields payment that scales with the difficulty. Someone farming easy or medium missions won't make as much as they would on higher difficulties, and even if they are making more, that cash could be used to get better equipment for harder missions.

If the devs would implement the choice for players to play the difficulty level they want to play, this game will be one of my favorite games here on Steam by far. Please consider implementing this, Suspicious Developments.
Thanks.

35194974.review:
Often described as "Hotline Miami in space", I thought I would really like this game. I did at first, but after playing for awhile I found that the lack of cohesive story line (at least that I could discern) and lack of purposeful level design really set it apart from HM. Which isn't to say that there is no story line, it just seems split up among 100 random characters you play. I didn't play so many of those characters that I could see if they were repetitious or not, but ultimately the mission they send you on to complete your story line is one of the 3 kinds available. Those 4 were assassinate, capture, steal or hijack. There might be different stipulations with those sure, like don't sound the alarm or don't kill anyone, but really you're doing all the same things.  The small amount of weapons, enemies and mission types quickly make the game boring. I enjoyed the simple graphics, they felt right at home with the gameplay. And the gameplay was what really shined in this game. The use of pause, slow mo and teleporting lets you solve scenarios in creative ways. Unfortunately you start to see those same scenarios over and over again very quickly.

It isn't that I don't think this game can be fun, it can be! But there really isn't a lot of depth to it, and once you reach the bottom of that very shallow pond you may find yourself feeling disappointed like I did. On the other hand, I really wouldn't blame anyone for loving this game, and if the developer adds some content I feel like it could be a really great game.

35194354.review:
I cannot recommend this game enough. It perfectly balances power-fantasy with nail-biting tension. 


I'd like to post my most recent mini-story (as that is the point of the game, all the stories you create):

     Journey Sagitta, professional assassin known for blinding speed and deadly precision, has retired. Sagitta left behind his favorite slipstream. It was a rechargable high-capacity model that proved invaluable on nearly every mission. New to the space pirate career, we have the young and ambitious Catch Vision. Her father told her stories about the legenday Sagitta, and Catch (thinking it would make him proud) dedicated herself to becoming the next great assassin. She filled out countless contracts, killed without mercy, and was about to finished her personal contract when the ship she had boarded flew into a Sovereign spaceport. Captured. She feared it was over. Who would rescue her - a murderer? For days - weeks - she was alone on Sovereign transport ships. On one mostly normal day, Catch heard the familiar sound of a teleporter, something she has used many times herself. "It could be a glitcher raid," she thought of the different possibilities, "or a space pirate, or-." Something that had not crossed her mind was her own father, Carbon Vision, in his old age, single-handedly clearing out an entire Sovereign ship to save her. "But how?" she asked, "How did you know how to find me?"

     "It's not my first time in space, dear." He grinned, "plus, my old friend Sagitta gave me a hand." He holds up Journey Sagitta's Slipstream and tosses it to her. "Now let's get out of here." 

     Back at home on one of the spaceports, Catch shows her father the Orion device. "I don't know what this does, but I knows what it's worth: enough for both of us to live safely." Catch and Carbon enter retirement and become legends of their own. Carbon passes down his finely crafted Self-Charging extreme-range swapper, and Catch, her rechargable extreme-range sidewinder. Together, they liberated 8 spaceports (including the Sovereign stronghold) and killed ~200 Sovereign.


TL;DR - Father rescues daughter, killed a lot of Sovereign, became legends.

35194012.review:
Heat Signature is a clever game which sticks to a golden rule: failure should mean a setback, not an end. Every spaceship heist will have its moments when you think your burglar-astronaut is utterly screwed. The guards catch a glimpse of you sneaking into a saferoom, or you accidentally blow up an engine core, or a stray bullet from a guard smashes a window and sends you hurtling into the void. The genius of Heat Signature is that none of these moments will end your heist, if you're quick and clever.

There are other nice features - roguelike loot, hilarious physics disasters, procedural mission generation - but nothing compares to the moment when you manage to rescue Cristo Elm despite oncoming space marines by throwing him out an airlock and manuevering to save him with a few seconds left of oxygen.

Quite possibly the most creative and original indie release of 2017.

While this title perhaps lacks the depth necessary to push hundreds of hours of play, it in no way detracts from how fresh and exciting the gameplay is.

You could say it has rogue-like and stealth elements, but that's about as far as it's similarities to other games go. It's hard to express just how rewarding it is to board a moving ship, execute a mission, and fling yourself from it with goods intact. It's hard to describe a game with so many elements which are surprisingly simple, yet fused together in a way which creates an experience unlike most others. I've only owned this game for a couple days, and it's already in my top 5 for this year. A shining reminder that we are in the golden age of indie games.

35192129.review:
A roguelike Hotline Miami in space.
Basically, you're a member of the Guardians of the Galaxy.

This is a fun game, with ~20 hours of play if you want to see everything. It can feel a bit repetitive at the outset, then as you start to understand how to best customize kits you can really get into it. At a certian point your team has so many resources that it starts to feel repetitive again, and that's probably between the 10-20 hour mark depending on how quickly you push through it.

In the game, you have a team of characters. Each character starts out new, with basically nothing, and must be upgraded with new and better equipment, earned through missions. The more missions  you do, the more equipment and notoriety you earn. If you don't do something stupid and get your character killed or captured, there are personal missions. With high noteriety, you start to see diminishing returns on mission rewards, which does a good job of pushing you to complete your personal mission. Once the personal mission is complete, your character retires and a newbie takes his/her place. If, as previously mentioned, your character is killed or captured, one of his/her family members will often take his/her place. Their personal missions are to avenge or rescue (allowing you to play as that character again) the character you got killed or captured.

There is plenty of replayability, if you enjoy the format. You can even start a completely new galaxy if you want to begin from scratch.

My biggest gripe is that there seem to be plenty of missed oppertunities with mission variance. There are essentially 5 missions: Steal, Rescue, Capture, Hijack, and Assassinate. Each mission follows the same pattern: fly to ship, board, take something, go back home. For a game with so much procedural content, it would be nice to have seen procedural missions, as well. Multi-stage missions, involving multiple ships, could virtually eliminate much of the feeling of repetition. How about a mission where you steal explosives from one ship, use them to destroy another ship, then plant evidence of the crime on a third ship? Or perhaps you rescue a sick man from one ship, smuggle him through enemy territory on a second ship, capture an enemy doctor on a third ship and bring him back to ship #2, take a cure off a 4th medical transport ship, then deliver everyone to a 5th hospital ship? There are limitless possibilities with the current mission variants; if a few more variants were added in addition to multi-stage missions, that feeling of repetition might go away.

In spite of the flaws, I really love this game. I hope Suspicious Developments continues with it and expands upon its already fantastic foundation. But, even if they don't, I still enjoyed my time with Heat Signature.

35191745.review:
From the developers of Gunpoint, one of my favorite games of all time, comes another amazing title in Heat Signature. 

Iam especially a fan of the combat system, which is satisfying and complex enough to get invested into. This is mostly because of the variety of weapons and items that are available to use. 

Another feature I enjoy is that your randomly-generated characters have personal quests that give a clear goal and a motivation that adds structure to the game so that you aren't mindlessly completing missions for no reason. You can also retire characters once you have completed their personal quest or you just want a new character. When you retire a character, you can name an item that will show up in your friends' games when they play.

Also, pressing F speeds up time by 6x. This is exteremely important and I'm not sure if I just skipped over it in the tutorial or what, but I found it out by trial and error.

Overall, Heat Signature is a great game to play if you're looking for a fun way to burn time. I highly reccomend it.

本作はアクティブポーズタイプのトップビュー型テクニカルステルスアクションである
マップ、ミッション、キャラクター及び能力、武器性能等あらゆるものがランダムで構成されるためリプレイ性は高い

主なゲームフローといえば提示されたミッションを受注し任務を遂行して報酬を貰い拠点を広げていく半エンドレスゲームとなっておりストーリーは存在しない

任務先は宇宙を徘徊する宇宙船でターゲットの暗殺や気絶させて回収、人質の回収が序盤の主な任務となっている
ミッションにはターゲットのみ排除、特定武器で排除、船内殲滅、アラームを発動させず任務遂行等様々なサブオプションが付随する
万が一失敗しても報酬が支払われないだけで他にお咎めは無い
また、敵や船内にあるケースから様々なアイテムを回収したりとトレハン要素も備わっていて、倉庫に預けるも良し売却し稼いだマネーで武器を整えるも良しだ
ミッション関係なしに宇宙を好き勝手飛び回り適当に八つ当たりをかましてくることも可能だ
操縦席をハイジャックすればそのまま乗り回すこともできる

キャラクターはダウンすると敵によって宇宙船外へ放り出されるが、このとき酸素猶予内にポッドを遠隔操作して回収すれば無事復帰することが出来る
死亡した場合はキャラクターロストしてその都度ランダムなキャラクターを選択してプレイ再開となる
拠点でいつでもキャラクターを切り替えることが出来るが、マネーや倉庫は個人割当となっているため他キャラクターへ装備を渡すことはできない
つまり死亡時は同時にアイテムも全てロストすることになる

操作性や操作感は良好で武器はメイン、サブ（LMB、RMB）をセットしておくことが出来、またホールドすることで時間の流れが遅くなりターゲットに狙いを定めることが容易になっている
近接武器はある程度離れた位置から奇襲出来るのだがこれがリズミカルで爽快感を生み出している
またスペースキーで時間を完全にストップさせてアイテムの収拾や使用、作戦をシミュレートする時間として活用することが出来る
アイテムやキャラクター能力の中にはアイテムや敵の位置と自分をスワップさせるものや、離れた位置の端末をハッキング、離れた位置のアイテムを回収、一定時間バリアを張る、敵の感知を遮断するシールドを張るといったものまで様々だ

ビジュアルは一見地味だがその内容は同デベロッパー制作であるGunpointにひけを取らないものとなっている
控えめに言ってオススメだ

35188722.review:
Just played it for 45 minutes. Thought it would be fairly boring, since the way it looks is sorta plain. Ended up being pretty neat.

It's a roguelite where you gotta do missions in order to make money to get a 'personal mission'. Don't know what those are yet. The game controls really well and its got all kinds of quality of life keybinds to make the bad parts better. You fly to a ship, then inside the ship you kill or knock everyone out. Then you can capture them, their ship, or an item on their ship. If you capture their ship, you get money and a random resource.  Seems like there's random ships flying around you can board too, but make sure that you don't get stuck in their lights because they'll shoot you.

You can die but its fairly forgiving the first time you die. Then it makes the respawn process harder to do the second time and by the third time you're basically dead for good. What happens is that they knock you out, put you out into space and make you remote control your own ship to pick up your body. If you don't get picked up in time you die. If you don't return to the boarded ship fast enough, it flies away. If your pod gets damaged and you don't return to motherbase fast enough you die. Every time you run into that scenario the timer is shorter. 

Pretty cool, I hope it can keep up the variety after a few hours because that's the fun of it.

35184730.review:
PROS:
○ Systems based game that begs you to try and break it
○ Unexpected events force you to get creative
○ Unforgiving rogue-alike

CONS:
○ Some performance issues
○ If you're not willing to engage with its systems it will get repetitive
○ Unforgiving rogue-alike

Overall, I am having a blast with this game.

Heat Signature is a top down 2D direct control game about breaking into ships in space. For the two second summary, I would describe it as what would happen if you took the controls and combat from Hotline Miami, and the systems and tools from Dishonored, and combined them into one game.

At first I was concerned with the repetitive game structure. For the most part, you just take and do missions, over and over. But, as I hit harder and harder missions, I found that I was forced to do more and more insane and creative things to get through missions.

In one mission, my capture target had armor that was impenetrable to every weapon I had. But, my mission was to extract him without killing him. So, I shot out a nearby window, sucking everything in the room into space. Much to my surpise, he had moved just out of reach of the room, and didn't get sucked out. So, I turned on a temporary invincible shield, took out a concussive hammer, and hit him over and over towards the window until we both got sucked out into space. Then, I remote piloted my pod and snatched us both from space before we ran out of oxygen. Mission complete!

In another, there was no timer or alarm timer, but I accidently blew up a room with a guard with a key I needed, completely locking me out from later parts of the mission. No problem! I found another smaller ship, hijacked it, flew it over to the ship I needed to infiltrate, shot a missile at the side of the ship I wanted to enter. This blasted a small hole right where I needed in. Then, I ditched my temporary ship, docked with the hole, and continued on my merry way.

If you're the kind of person who tends to take the path of least resistance through systems based games, Heat Signature probably isn't for you. The path of least resistance is a repetitive slog, ending in a difficulty spike that will keep you from progressing. But if you're willing to get creative-- if you like using all the crazy toys and traps and systems in these sorts of games-- buy this game.

35182416.review:
A friend of mine, who's a publisher, has a saying: "If you can't get me interested in what you made in two sentences or less, an entire book certainly won't get me interested". People have a short attention span. So, I'm going to try to sell Heat Sig in a sentence:

[b]You infiltrate procedurally generated starships as a freak time-bending superspy using an array of insane gadgets with Gunpoint gameplay and Hotline Miami mechanics.[/b]

If you aren't sold yet, watch [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hyp3KC4tWO4]this vid[/url].

The good things:
- The gameplay is incredibly satisfying and smooth.
- It depends more on planning and utilizing your equipment and environment than on mechanical skill
- Loads of awesome, random loot
- Permadeath, which stops you from sitting on an overpowered character for too long, while at the same time remaining easy to start anew. It works really well.
- The soundtrack is great.

The bad things:
- After a while, the gameplay gets repetitive. There isn't much in terms of story, so it's just like doing Steam Workshop Gunpoint levels over and over again.
- The ship difficulties pretty much fall into two categories: normal ships, which are always possible to do with some good equipment; and ships where everyone is armored/shielded, in which case you need [i]a very particular item[/i] to even be able to do anything. I wish it was more balanced.

Overall, a pretty solid 8/10 game, in my opinion. Tons of pure, unadulterated fun that you can just jump right into and enjoy - both as a quick, 15-minute break, and a multi-hour timesink.

35178919.review:
[h1]TL;DR, if you love strategy games, top-down shooters, or thinking up creative ways to deal with whatever situation you just walked or teleported into, buy this game. its a great game.[/h1]

And this really is a strategy game, with some rougelite elements. There is permadeath, though it's not at all unavoidable. In fact, only one character has died so far, and it was only because he got shot so many times he could no longer take any more shots and go into incapacitation instead of just dying. Your characters can get captured and you can resuce them with another character; or you can reach a point where your current character can no longer truly benefit to progressing through the overall goal of liberating the entire procedurally-generated astroid belt-thing, at which point you can retire the character and name a weapon or otherwise piece of equipment they have in the off-chance it turns up again in future playthroughs with another character, or maybe in one of your steam friends' games. I named an armour-piercing sword the "Chastity Penetrator", by the way.

Back to strategy though, there is a lot of ways to deal with any given situation without needing specialized equipment. Need to knock out a guy wearing armor but don't have any weapons that can penetrate armor without also killing the target? Wait for him to walk past a window, shoot it out to catapult the guy into space and pick him up in your little space pod. Need to deal with a little cluster of guards but don't want to alert anyone? Grab a bunch of wrenches lying around the place, teleport in there, and pause to switch wrenches everytime you swing one and it goes into cooldown. The "pause, plan and play" style you develop as you get a feel for how to do things is somewhat similar to Doorkickers, another good game, but its more open with a ton of more choices of equipment. Or you could, you know, load up on a bunch of guns and Slipstreams - which are basically steroids without the downsides - and Rambo your way through the entire ship. It's a valid strategy if the alarm is already sounded and you need to finish your objective pronto.

And in terms of the equipment, it's quite similar to Borderlands. There are a variety of traits and equipment types, and the stuff you find are randomly created from those possible choices. I found an automatic silenced pistol that regenerated ammo over time once, and it was glorious. 

Also, again, you dont neccesarily need specialized equipment to deal with a given situation. You COULD wait next to a terminal and whack the guards one by one as they come to do...stuff...on it. But there could be a time limit and you need to deal with them fast. Also that's boring. So instead you teleport into the room and throw wrenches at everyone because you don't need the alarm to trigger and you dont have any silenced weapons. Moments where things go wrong are when this game shines the brightest, as long as you don't mess up getting yourself out. You can theorhetically deal with any difficulty with the starter gear, even if that entails bugging out by throwing a sword at a window to vent yourself to space once you inevitably get spotted and picking yourself up with your pod by controling it remotely.

35178374.review:
A fun little game with a nice theme and good pacing.  More tactical than action-based - although you could play it as a frantic arcade-style game, you'd almost certainly get quickly overwhelmed.

A good range of tools to try out, and you can nearly always find a mission that will let you relax or challenge you, as you see fit.  Missions are nicly bite-sized, with some you can complete in under a minute and others that may take a while due to the challenges you're trying to overcome.  Failure is recoverable.  Usually.

Don't et too attached to your characters; as you inevitably eventually get sloppy or tackle something a bit too hard you'll suffer injuries that eventually lead to your death or retirement - but that's fine, there's always another recruit waiting to step up.  

Includes a series of unlockable "defector" missions, which challenge you to try specific missions with little gear, in addition to the main thread of characters where you gradually build their equipment up until you can tackle the most difficult objectives.

Good replayability, well worth the price of admission.

35178021.review:
長文オススメ記事を書きました。参考にでも。
『お前が血と暴力を求めるならば『Heat Signature』をプレイするべきだ』
https://note.mu/makichang23/n/n6528cd7285d3?creator_urlname=makichang23

「あの宇宙船のコイツを暗殺してちょ」というミッションがある。

お前は素直にステルスプレイと近接武器を駆使してサイレントキルを実行しても良いし、暗殺など関係なしにショットガンをぶっ放してターゲットもろとも乗組員を皆殺しにしても良い。そのへんを飛んでいる別の宇宙船をハイジャックして、ターゲットのいる宇宙船に突撃、船ごとバラバラにして宇宙空間にばらまいてしまっても良い。

この『Heat Signature』は見た目こそ地味で硬派、昔ながらの媚びない洋ゲーだが、その本質は極めてカジュアルで大らかなモノである。

本作を簡単に説明すると、トップダウンシューターやローグライク、タクティカルにトレハンにSci-fi、その他様々なジャンル、要素をゴチャ混ぜにして、宇宙サンドボックスにぶち込んだような作品、という感じになる。

その見た目からホットラインマイアミやFTLの名前が出されがちだが、多分コイツが近いのはヒットマンとかだと思う。一見真面目ゲーのようだけどバカもやらせてくれるようなのが好きなヤツはきっと気に入ると思う。

暴力の要素はもちろんなのだが、ソレ以上にコイツは単純に出来の良い、真摯に作られたゲームで、操作系のストレスやテンポの悪さなんかとは完全に無縁、いつまでもダラダラと続けてしまえる心地よさがある。

キャッチーなビジュアルやコンセプトがあるわけじゃないし、トレーラーを見ても何をするゲームなのかわかりにくいし、斬新で尖った何かがあるわけでもない、しかしコイツには多くの魅力がある。

とにかくコイツは真の男のための真の洋ゲーだ。オモシロさは俺が保証する。マストバイ。

Tips
・宇宙空間に放り出せばみな死ぬ
・ガジェットはガンガン使っていけ
・時間のある限り詰みはない

ある程度装備が整ってきたらSelf-charging称号のついたツールを集めよう。

他にも黄色くてデカいアーマー着たやつにも通るArmour-Piercing称号や、

35177827.review: I am a pretty picky gamer. Yes, I have over 500 games on my account, I do love TRYING new games, though I almost never get hooked... but there's something about this game and the way it's designed, it just feels... really fair. I loved Hotline Miami, and there's definitely some of that top-down-slaughter-em-up flavor here, but it's propped up by a pause-and-plan mechanic that is arguably the antithesis of Hotline's RUN IN THE ROOM AND BLAST EVERYBODY QUICK! Sometimes I just need to hit pause and ask myself, wait, how was I going to do this again? It says it right there in the description that this is a game where you "make terrible mistakes, and think of clever ways out of them." Instead of instadying and instarespawning and building muscle-memory a la Super Meat Boy, there's a lot more panic pauses to the tune of "Oh shit, I totally forgot to grab my armor piercing gun... and that guard I just tried to bonk with a hammer is definitely about to shoot me.. what the hell am I gonna do?" and it's the solving that stupid, simple problem that makes this game fun, but fair. If you couldn't pause, you would die a lot more than you do. And you already die a lot in this game.
